{"uri": "8138502108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:04:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:04:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:03:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/05/21/macron-is-making-a-surprise-trip-to-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-and-indigenous-frustration/", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and indigenous frustration - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Catherine Gaschka, John Leicester And Keiran Smith, The Associated Press on May 21, 2024.\n\nIn this photo provided by the Australian Department of Defence, Australian and other tourists board an Australian Airforce Hercules as they prepare to depart from Magenta Airport in Noumea, New Caledonia, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Australia and New Zealand have sent airplanes to New Caledonia to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory. (LAC Adam Abela/Royal Australian Airfare via AP)PARIS (AP) - French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to riot-hit New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence. \"He will go there tonight,\"\u009d government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia. Six people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy. There have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France. The unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination. The violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III. Paris last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a. \"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\" She gave no details about how long Macron will stay or who he will meet. But Macron will see the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes. With police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300. The Associated Press could not reach those behind the unrest or from Kanak representatives, some of whom have called for calm. The violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out. A priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave. Australia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones. Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands. New Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens. \"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\"\u009d Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\u009d ___ John Leicester {"uri": "8138564411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:40:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:40:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:40:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/488470/Macron-is-making-a-surprise-trip-to-New-Caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-and-indigenous-frustration", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and indigenous frustration - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Repatriated Australian travelers react as they arrive from New Caledonia to Brisbane International Airport, in Brisbane, Australia, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Australia and New Zealand have sent airplanes to New Caledonia to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory. (David Clark/Courier Mail/AAP via AP)\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to riot-hit New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and colonists who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nShe gave no details about how long Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\nBut Macron will see the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe Associated Press could not reach those behind the unrest or from Kanak representatives, some of whom have called for calm.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston {"uri": "2024-05-363575527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "15:44:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T15:44:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T15:42:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/macron-surprise-trip-to-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-9343370/", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and indigenous frustration | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and others who have settled on the island and who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nAlso read | France mobilises police to regain control of New Caledonia airport road\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said.\n\n\"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized. \"Leaving Tuesday night will, because of the distance and time difference, see Macron arrive Thursday morning in New Caledonia, his office said. It said he is expected to stay for one day.\n\nMacron will meet with political, business, civic and youth leaders and aim to \"renew the thread of dialogue\" in search of \"a comprehensive political agreement,\" Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told parliament, where lawmakers stood for a moment of silence for the six people killed in the violence.\n\nInterior Minister Gerald Darmanin said he'll join Macron, along with the ministers for defense and for France's overseas territories. The visit will give Macron and his ministers a first-hand look at some of the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest.\n\nThey announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.The violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, {"uri": "8138900276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "16:09:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T16:09:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T16:09:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2024/0521/Macron-trip-New-Caledonia-riots-Kanaks", "title": "Macron visits French territory of New Caledonia amid state of emergency over riots", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to riot-hit New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on May 21 where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting, and arson, raising new questions about Mr. Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and colonists who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis on May 15 declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms. Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nShe gave no details about how long Mr. Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\nBut Mr. Macron will see the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged, and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests May 21 for a total number near 300.\n\nThe Associated Press could not reach those behind the unrest or from Kanak representatives, some of whom have called for calm.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Mr. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on May 21 to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"", "source": {"uri": "csmonitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Christian Science {"uri": "2024-05-363347428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:27:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:27:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:56:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/macron-is-making-a-surprise-trip-to-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-and-indigenous-frustration/article_2863b388-edce-5967-bc68-46bfb33d2e87.html", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and indigenous frustration", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to riot-hit New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nShe gave no details about how long Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\nBut Macron will see the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe Associated Press could not reach those behind the unrest or from Kanak representatives, some of whom have called for calm.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nJohn Leicester reported from Le Pecq, France, and Keiran Smith from Newcastle, {"uri": "8138308223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "10:11:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T10:11:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T10:10:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/305351", "title": "Macron to visit riot-hit New Caledonia as Australia, New Zealand evacuate nationals", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will leave Paris for riot-hit Pacific territory New Caledonia \"this evening\", the government spokeswoman said Tuesday.\n\nMacron \"will leave as soon as this evening\", Prisca Thevenot said, after more than a week of unrest over his government's voting reform plans rejected by indigenous Kanaks.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand meanwhile sent airplanes to New Caledonia to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens from the archipelago, where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noumea, the capital. The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defense Department.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the Australian-organized flights would also evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government also announced that it had sent a plane to New Caledonia to begin evacuating about 50 of its citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nNoumea's international airport remains closed to commercial flights. Its reopening will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week in New Caledonia following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nAbout 270 suspected rioters have been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew is in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people, which is a popular tourist destination with its idyllic beaches and climate.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, to try to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other violence turned parts of Noumea into no-go zones. Columns of smoke billowed into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who are seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.", "source": {"uri": French security forces are working to retake control of the highway to the international airport in violence-scorched New Caledonia, shuttered because of deadly unrest wracking the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nSYDNEY (AP) -- The Australian and New Zealand governments announced Tuesday they were sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-scorched New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from New Caledonia amid violent unrest that has beset the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane Tuesday to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital, in the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the Government,\" Peters said.\n\n\"In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia after violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew was in effect.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear {"uri": "8137750371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "03:24:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T03:24:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T03:23:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2944752-evacuations-underway-australia-and-new-zealand-rescue-nationals-amid-new-caledonia-unrest", "title": "Evacuations Underway: Australia and New Zealand Rescue Nationals Amid New Caledonia Unrest | Law-Order", "body": "Australia and New Zealand are evacuating their citizens from violence-stricken New Caledonia. With flights coordinated alongside French authorities, both countries strive to bring their nationals home amid ongoing unrest driven by controversial electoral reforms. Six deaths and numerous injuries have been reported, amplifying the urgency of these evacuation efforts.\n\nThe Australian and New Zealand governments announced on Tuesday they were sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-scorched New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from New Caledonia amid violent unrest that has beset the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane on Tuesday to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital, in the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the Government,\" Peters said.\n\n\"In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\" At least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia after violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 pm-6 am curfew was in effect.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\n(This story has not {"uri": "8138989703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "17:15:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T17:15:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T17:14:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/asia_pacific/2024-05-21/france-macron-trip-new-caledonia-13926830.html", "title": "Macron making surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest, indigenous frustration", "body": "PARIS -- French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 20,000-mile round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and others who have settled on the island and who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nLeaving Tuesday night will, because of the distance and time difference, see Macron arrive Thursday morning in New Caledonia, his office said. It said he is expected to stay for one day.\n\nMacron will meet with political, business, civic and youth leaders and aim to \"renew the thread of dialogue\" in search of \"a comprehensive political agreement,\" Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told parliament, where lawmakers stood for a moment of silence for the six people killed in the violence.\n\nInterior Minister Gerald Darmanin said he'll join Macron, along with the ministers for defense and for France's overseas territories. The visit will give Macron and his ministers a first-hand look at some of the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Stars and Stripes"}, {"uri": "2024-05-364269931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "08:03:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T08:03:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T20:59:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.1news.co.nz/2024/05/22/macron-making-surprise-trip-to-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest/", "title": "Macron making surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000km round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonisers and others who have settled on the island and who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nLeaving Tuesday night will, because of the distance and time difference, mean Macron would arrive Thursday morning in New Caledonia, his office said. It said he was expected to stay for one day.\n\nMacron will meet with political, business, civic and youth leaders and aim to \"renew the thread of dialogue\" in search of \"a comprehensive political agreement,\" Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told parliament, where lawmakers stood for a moment of silence for the six people killed in the violence.\n\nInterior Minister Gerald Darmanin said he'll join Macron, along with the ministers for defense and for France's overseas territories. The visit will give Macron and his ministers a first-hand look at some of the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6pm to 6am curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. {"uri": "8138561234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:39:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:39:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/world/french-president-macron-to-visit-riot-hit-new-caledonia-as-australia-new-zealand-begin-evacuations-723940", "title": "French president Macron to visit riot-hit New Caledonia as Australia, New Zealand begin evacuations", "body": "New Caledonia unrest: The French government also announced that it would send hundreds more security personnel to join the 1,500 law enforcement personnel already on the ground.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron will visit the riot-hit New Caledonia, said Paris on Tuesday (May 21) as Australia and New Zealand began evacuating nationals in the French territory which has experienced a week of deadly riots.\n\nMacron \"will leave as soon as this evening,\" said government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot, in a bid to soothe tempers amid the riots which broke out against the planned electoral changes by the French government in Paris, which indigenous Kanaks have opposed.\n\nThe High Commission of New Caledonia, which represents the French state in the territory, said that around 600 personnel would be deployed in the coming hours to join those already sent from France.\n\nThe violence broke out earlier this month over the French government's plans to amend voting laws which would allow more recent arrivals to vote in provincial elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote, as per Reuters.\n\nAt least six people have been killed since the unrest began in the capital, Noumea. Three of the six people killed were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians.\n\nAlso Read | New Caledonia unrest: Australia, New Zealand send evacuation flights, Macron holds security meet\n\nThere have been several confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\nA plane full of Australian tourists who had been stranded in New Caledonia amid a week of rioting and looting arrived in Brisbane late Tuesday, reported AFP.\n\nThe Royal Australian Air Force C130 Hercules was the first evacuation flight to leave French territory since the unrest began on May 13.\n\nThe high commission, on Tuesday, said that the airport remains closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia as commercial flights were cancelled, reported Reuters citing the local government. This comes as the main international airport in the capital remains closed for commercial aircraft.\n\nAlso Read | Protestors block New Caledonia roads as French police pour in\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a post on social media announcing the two flights.\n\nAccording to officials in Australia, around 300 citizens have registered for possible evacuation, but it was not immediately clear how many were evacuated on Tuesday's flights.\n\nThe New Zealand Defence Force plane was expected to carry about \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs,\" said Foreign Minister Winston Peters, adding that they are working with France and Australia on \"subsequent flights in coming days.\"", "source": {"uri": evacuate their nationals from violence-scorched New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from New Caledonia amid violent unrest that has beset the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane Tuesday to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital, in the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the Government,\" Peters said.\n\n\"In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia after violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew was in effect.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear {"uri": "8138815884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "15:17:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T15:17:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T15:14:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/macron-making-surprise-trip-caledonia-120704536.html", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and indigenous frustration", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometer (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and others who have settled on the island and who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nLeaving Tuesday night will, because of the distance and time difference, see Macron arrive Thursday morning in New Caledonia, his office said. It said he is expected to stay for one day.\n\nMacron will meet with political, business, civic and youth leaders and aim to \"renew the thread of dialogue\" in search of \"a comprehensive political agreement,\" Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told parliament, where lawmakers stood for a moment of silence for the six people killed in the violence.\n\nInterior Minister Gerald Darmanin said he'll join Macron, along with the ministers for defense and for France's overseas territories. The visit will give Macron and his ministers a first-hand look at some of the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\n___\n\nLeicester reported from Le Pecq, France, and Smith from Newcastle, Australia.\n\nCatherine Gaschka, John Leicester And Keiran Smith, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8137740248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "03:12:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T03:12:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T03:11:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dw.com/en/new-caledonia-australia-nz-send-planes-to-rescue-stranded-tourists/a-69134952", "title": "New Caledonia: Australia, NZ send planes to rescue tourists", "body": "The governments of Australia and New Zealand said on Tuesday they are sending planes to New Caledonia to evacuate their nationals amid violent unrest in the French Pacific territory.\n\nAccording to reports, hundreds of tourists have been trapped in hotels during weeks of violent turmoil.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed receiving clearance from the French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and tourists from the French territory.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong posted on X on Tuesday. Official reports said there were about 300 Australians in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand is also sending a plane to capital Noumea initially to bring home \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs,\" with more flights planned, New Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Peters said.\n\nOn Tuesday, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said the airport remains closed for commercial flights, leaving about 3,200 people stranded.\n\nThe unrest began ahead of a French National Assembly vote on changes to the New Caledonian constitution, which would enable more migrants on the island -- in many cases from France -- to vote.\n\nDeadly riots erupted after the National Assembly approved the changes to voting rules last week, allowing French residents who have lived in the French territory for 10 years to vote in provincial elections.\n\nSupporters of New Caledonia's independence fear the bill will dilute the vote of the indigenous Kanak people.\n\nThe following violence led to six deaths and left hundreds injured.\n\nThe riots have caused extensive damage, including looted and burnt businesses and road barricades restricting access to food and medicine.\n\nFrench authorities said they will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nOver 1,000 French gendarmes and police are already on the ground, with an additional 600 personnel arriving soon.\n\nNew Caledonia, an archipelago in the South Pacific, has been a French territory since 1853.\n\nFor Paris, New Caledonia is important geopolitically, militarily, and because it is one of the top nickel producers in the world -- a key component and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia after violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6pm-6am curfew was in effect.\n\nA street in Noumea, New Caledonia, is pictured after unrest (Nicolas Job/AP)\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive on Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonisers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted on May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nThe National {"uri": "2024-05-362853811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "04:56:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T04:56:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T01:15:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/20/australia-and-new-zealand-sending-planes-to-evacuate-nationals-from-new-caledonias-unrest/", "title": "Australia and New Zealand sending planes to evacuate nationals from New Caledonia's unrest", "body": "A RNZAF Hercules C-130 takes off from Whenuapai airbase near Auckland, New Zealand, bound for Noumea, New Caledonia, on a mercy mission to rescue stranded New Zealand tourists, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. The Australian and New Zealand governments say they are sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-scorched New Caledonia. (Michael Craig/NZ Herald via [...]\n\nSYDNEY (AP) -- The Australian and New Zealand governments announced Tuesday they were sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-wracked New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from New Caledonia amid violent unrest that has beset the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane Tuesday to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital, in the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia since violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew was in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other mayhem turned parts of the capital, Noumea, into no-go zones. With columns of smoke billowing into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-363242233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:03:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:03:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:01:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/australia-new-zealand-evacuating-nationals-unrest-new-caledonia-9342527/", "title": "Australia and New Zealand begin evacuating nationals from unrest in New Caledonia | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens from the archipelago, where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent airplanes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens from the archipelago, where indigenous people have long sought independence from France. Hours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noumea, the capital. The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defense Department. \"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the Australian-organized flights would also evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government also announced that it had sent a plane to New Caledonia to begin evacuating about 50 of its citizens. \"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said.\n\nAlso Read | Australians stranded in New Caledonia 'running out of food' amid civil unrest\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"Noumea's international airport remains closed to commercial flights. Its reopening will be reassessed on Thursday. At least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week in New Caledonia following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris. About 270 suspected rioters have been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew is in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people, which is a popular tourist destination with its idyllic beaches and climate.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, to try to quell the unrest and restore control. Armed clashes, looting, arson and other violence turned parts of Noumea into no-go zones. Columns of smoke billowed into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who are seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France. The unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.", {"uri": "2024-05-363056467", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "08:32:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T08:32:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T08:06:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/australia-and-new-zealand-begin-evacuating-nationals-from-unrest-in-new-caledonia/article_21d1655f-6fb6-5bb8-8047-80a25236aa3b.html", "title": "Australia and New Zealand begin evacuating nationals from unrest in New Caledonia", "body": "A RNZAF Hercules C-130 takes off from Whenuapai airbase near Auckland, New Zealand, bound for Noumea, New Caledonia, on a mercy mission to rescue stranded New Zealand tourists, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. The Australian and New Zealand governments say they are sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-scorched New Caledonia.\n\nNEWCASTLE, Australia (AP) -- Australia and New Zealand sent airplanes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens from the archipelago, where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noumea, the capital. The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defense Department.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the Australian-organized flights would also evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government also announced that it had sent a plane to New Caledonia to begin evacuating about 50 of its citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nNoumea's international airport remains closed to commercial flights. Its reopening will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week in New Caledonia following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nAbout 270 suspected rioters have been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew is in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people, which is a popular tourist destination with its idyllic beaches and climate.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, to try to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other violence turned parts of Noumea into no-go zones. Columns of smoke billowed into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who are seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8138541768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:28:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:28:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-macron-is-making-a-surprise-trip-to-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-and-indigenous-frustration-5980654.html", "title": "World News | Macron is Making a Surprise Trip to New Caledonia Amid Deadly Unrest and Indigenous Frustration | LatestLY", "body": "Paris, May 21 (AP) French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to riot-hit New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly unrest and where indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president said he'd decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometre (20,000-mile) round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nAlso Read | London-Singapore Flight Hits Deadly Turbulence: One Dead, Others Injured After London-Singapore Flight Strikes Severe Turbulence (Watch Video).\n\nSix people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonisers who want to remain part of France.\n\nAlso Read | Drug Testing for Students in Pakistan: As Cases of Crystal Meth Rise, Sindh Government To Start Drug Tests in All Schools.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nShe gave no details about how long Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\nBut Macron will see the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 pm to 6 am curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe Associated Press could not reach those behind the unrest or from Kanak representatives, some of whom have called for calm.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for about 50 citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, KION546", "body": "SYDNEY (AP) -- The Australian and New Zealand governments announced Tuesday they were sending planes to evacuate their nationals from violence-wracked New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from New Caledonia amid violent unrest that has beset the French Pacific archipelago where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane Tuesday to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital, in the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured in New Caledonia since violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew was in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other mayhem turned parts of the capital, Noumea, into no-go zones. With columns of smoke billowing into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear {"uri": "8138113257", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "08:15:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T08:15:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T08:14:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/world/australia-and-new-zealand-begin-evacuating-nationals-from-unrest-in-new-caledonia/article_7b9ca8c0-5130-5f36-9052-101dd3ab58f1.html", "title": "Australia and New Zealand begin evacuating nationals from unrest in New Caledonia", "body": "NEWCASTLE, Australia (AP) -- Australia and New Zealand sent airplanes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens from the archipelago, where indigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noumea, the capital. The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defense Department.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the Australian-organized flights would also evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government also announced that it had sent a plane to New Caledonia to begin evacuating about 50 of its citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nNoumea's international airport remains closed to commercial flights. Its reopening will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week in New Caledonia following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nAbout 270 suspected rioters have been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew is in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people, which is a popular tourist destination with its idyllic beaches and climate.\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, to try to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other violence turned parts of Noumea into no-go zones. Columns of smoke billowed into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who are seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.", "source": {"uri":
