{"uri": "8138739789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "14:23:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T14:23:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T14:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/macron-heads-to-new-caledonia-as-australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-citizens-after-deadly-riots-13140761", "title": "Macron heads to New Caledonia as Australia and New Zealand evacuate citizens after deadly riots", "body": "Six people, including two police officers, have been killed in the violence which erupted after protests over voting reforms being pushed through by Mr Macron's government.\n\nEmmanuel Macron is to visit New Caledonia following deadly riots in the French overseas territory.\n\nThe French president's visit to the South Pacific archipelago follows reinforced security and emergency measures to bring the unrest under control.\n\nSix people, including two police officers, have been killed in the violence, which erupted after protests over voting reforms being pushed through by Mr Macron's government.\n\nThe riots have left a trail of destruction with shops looted, cars burnt and road barricades restricting access to medicine, food, and Noumea's international airport.\n\nFrench government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot announced the visit - which required a shake-up of Mr Macron's schedule. He had previously been scheduled to be in Normandy on Wednesday.\n\n\"He will go there tonight,\" she said, after a cabinet meeting on Tuesday where the president announced he had decided to travel to New Caledonia himself.\n\nAn extra 1,000 personnel have been sent to the archipelago in addition to the 1,700 already deployed, after France imposed a state of emergency to tackle the unrest, which included a curfew and a ban on the social media app, TikTok.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms Thevenot said.\n\n\"The return to calm is starting to arrive. The situation is not quite totally normalised, but the situation is improving.\n\n\"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nA priority for French officials has been clearing the highway to the airport.\n\nOn Tuesday, Australia, and New Zealand, sent planes to the island to begin bringing home stranded citizens.\n\nAustralian foreign minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights.\n\nA Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in the capital Noumea. The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defence Department.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Ms Wong said in a post on social media platform, X.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand's foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nThe New Zealand Herald reported a defence force plane had landed in Auckland with around 50 citizens evacuated from New Caledonia.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nRead more from Sky News:\n\nOne dead in turbulence on London-Singapore flight\n\nElvis's granddaughter fights Graceland auction\n\nTrouble has flared over a proposed new law that will let French residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years vote in provincial elections.\n\nSome local leaders fear the move will dilute the indigenous Kanak vote.\n\nIt is the latest flashpoint in long-standing tensions over French rule of the mineral-producing Pacific archipelago, some 930 miles (1,500 km) east of Australia.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nThe island held three independence votes in three years from 2018 to 2021, with the closest in 2020 - a 53% to 47% result in favour of remaining.\n\nThe 2021 result was 96.5% in favour of remaining, following a boycott of the vote by pro-independence groups, including the indigenous Kanak population.", "source": We continue to work on further flights.\"\n\nTwo C-130 Hercules planes of the Australian Air Force arrived at Magenta Airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea on Tuesday.\n\nNew Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters said a government plane will bring home its citizens from New Caledonia who \"have faced a challenging few days.\"\n\n\"The situation in New Caledonia remains dynamic, and New Zealand officials are continuing to work with French counterparts and other partners especially Australia to understand what is needed to ensure the safety of our people there,\" Peters said.\n\nThe evacuation of foreigners from New Caledonia came as French President Emmanuel Macron convened a third defense and national security council meeting on Monday over riots in the overseas territory of New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest has gripped New Caledonia for a week, prompting Paris to declare a state of emergency.\n\nFrench territorial High Commission on the island had said that more than 1,000 police officers, gendarmes, and civil security agents were sent to assist the local forces to reinstate order.\n\nThe French forces launched an operation on Sunday to regain access to some parts of the capital Noumea and also to reopen the airport.\n\nAt least six people, including two gendarmes, were killed during the riots, and 240 rioters arrested, the statement noted.\n\nThe unrest was sparked by a constitutional review initiated by Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin in New Caledonia.\n\nIf the changes are adopted, French nationals who have lived on the island for at least 10 years {"uri": "8137726095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "03:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T03:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T02:57:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/australia-nz-begin-caledonia-evacuations-024813764.html", "title": "Australia and NZ to begin New Caledonia evacuations", "body": "Australia and New Zealand say they have received clearance to send planes to New Caledonia to pick up travellers stranded after unrest shut down the international airport.\n\nAustralia is deploying two planes on Tuesday to evacuate some of the 300 of its citizens who have registered for assistance in the French Pacific territory.\n\nThe first of \"a series\" of proposed flights will also leave New Zealand and bring about 50 people home, the government in Wellington said.\n\nThe unrest began last week after lawmakers in Paris voted through changes that will allow more French residents to vote in local elections, a move indigenous leaders say will dilute the political influence of native people.\n\nFour civilians - including at least three indigenous Kanak residents - have been killed in riots along with two police officers.\n\nDozens more have been injured and more than 200 people have so far been arrested.\n\nBoth Australia and New Zealand said they would prioritise flying out those with the most \"pressing need\", with passenger lists being organised by consular staff.\n\nTourists from \"other countries\" would also be assisted, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said.\n\nAs well as witnessing fires and looting, holidaymakers who have been stuck for more than a week have reported food shortages.\n\n\"The situation in New Caledonia remains dynamic, and New Zealand officials are continuing to work with French counterparts and other partners especially Australia to understand what is needed to ensure the safety of our people there,\" New Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\nAround 290 New Zealanders are believed to be in New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester told AFP that he and and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" at the prospect of getting home after being confined to a resort near Noum\u00e9a for over a week.\n\n\"We realise we probably won't get on these flights, because those who have higher needs will get on them, but we at least know we have a way out in the next few days,\" he said.\n\nThe French High Commission in New Caledonia say French gendarmes trying to take back control of the 60km (37 mile) road between Noum\u00e9a and La Tontouta international have \"neutralised\" 76 roadblocks and are now clearing debris such as burnt-out vehicles.\n\nTravel advice by the Australian government has warned people not to try and get to the airport themselves saying the route \"is not yet considered safe\".\n\nThe airport remains closed for commercial flights, and a decision on when to reopen it will be reassessed on Thursday, the local government said.\n\nIt has estimated that about 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia.\n\nFrance has flown in 1,050 extra police to boost security in the territory, with a further 600 reinforcements to arrive \"in the coming hours\", France's High Commission in New Caledonia said on Tuesday.\n\nThe military is being deployed to protect public buildings, it added.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron warned that the military would need to remain deployed in New Caledonia \"for some time\".", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8139224781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "20:39:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T20:39:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T20:39:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/21/world/macron-is-making-surprise-trip-new-caledonia-amid-deadly-unrest-indigenous-frustration/", "title": "Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia amid deadly unrest and Indigenous frustration - The Boston Globe", "body": "Six people have been killed, including two gendarmes, and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting, and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between Indigenous Kanaks, who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonizers and others who have settled on the island and who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe violence is the most severe to shake New Caledonia since the 1980s, when France also imposed emergency measures on the island that became French in 1853 under Emperor Napoleon III.\n\nLast Wednesday, Paris declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nLeaving Tuesday night will, because of the distance and time difference, see Macron arrive Thursday morning in New Caledonia, his office said. It said he is expected to stay for one day.\n\nMacron will meet with political, business, civic, and youth leaders and aim to \"renew the thread of dialogue\" in search of \"a comprehensive political agreement,\" Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told parliament, where lawmakers stood for a moment of silence for the six people killed in the violence.\n\nInterior Minister Gerald Darmanin said he'll join Macron, along with the ministers for defense and for France's overseas territories. The visit will give Macron and his ministers a first-hand look at some of the destruction that turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged, and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters, some armed, and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest. They announced another 22 arrests Tuesday for a total number near 300.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion about France's colonial past. Macron's efforts to address that have largely focused on Africa, where France had colonies and where local frustration in some countries has led to recent calls for French forces to get out.\n\nA priority for French authorities in New Caledonia since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights and would work on further ones.\n\nAustralia's Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the flights would evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government announced an evacuation effort for We continue to work on further flights.\"\n\nTwo C-130 Hercules planes of the Australia air force arrived at Magenta Airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea on Tuesday.\n\nNew Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters said a government plane will bring home its citizens from New Caledonia who \"have faced a challenging few days.\"\n\n\"The situation in New Caledonia remains dynamic, and New Zealand officials are continuing to work with French counterparts and other partners especially Australia to understand what is needed to ensure the safety of our people there,\" Peters said.\n\nThe evacuation of foreigners from New Caledonia came as French President Emmanuel Macron convened a third defense and national security council meeting on Monday over riots in the overseas territory of New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest has gripped New Caledonia for a week, prompting Paris to declare a state of emergency.\n\nFrench territorial High Commission on the island had said that more than 1,000 police officers, gendarmes, and civil security agents were sent to assist the local forces to reinstate order.\n\nThe French forces launched an operation on Sunday to regain access to some parts of the capital Noumea and also to reopen the airport.\n\nAt least six people, including two gendarmes, were killed during the riots, and 240 rioters arrested, the statement noted.\n\nThe unrest was sparked by a constitutional review initiated by Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin in New Caledonia.\n\nIf the changes are adopted, French nationals who have lived on the island for at least 10 years {"uri": "8139668133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:12:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:12:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:10:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/583783", "title": "New Caledonia riots: Tourists evacuated, French President Macron to visit", "body": "SYDNEY/PARIS - French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia late on Tuesday, his office said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, killing six.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand were evacuating tourists from the island as the violence left a trail of destruction with looted shops, torched cars and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nFrance annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946\n\nMacron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nALSO READ: Protestors block New Caledonia roads as French police pour in\n\nMacron \"will discuss with all the forces in New Caledonia\", French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said. \"The objective is to ... prepare and anticipate reconstruction.\"\n\n\"The president is also going there to re-establish dialogue,\" Attal said.\n\nDialogue\n\nInitial reaction showed renewing dialogue will not be an easy task, all the more so as pro-independence leaders blame the riots on Macron pushing through the electoral reform despite local opposition.\n\n\"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, wrote on X in response to news of Macron's visit.\n\nFrance annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one-in-five residents live below the poverty threshold.\n\nThe island lies some 20,000 km away from mainland France, and some 1,500 km east of Australia. It has longed been rocked by pro-independence movements. The past week's violence has been the worst there in 40 years.\n\nALSO READ: Australia, New Zealand send evacuation flights to New Caledonia\n\nThe opposition in Paris, former French prime ministers, and leaders of other Pacific islands have also said Macron should scrap or suspend the electoral reform, which parliament in Paris adopted last Tuesday.\n\nVanuatu Foreign Minister Matai Seremaiah urged France to \"do the right thing, to resolve all outstanding decolonisation issues\" and seriously engage with Kanak leaders.\n\nEvacuations\n\nSome 108 Australians and other tourists landed in Brisbane on two government flights, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on X. A Defence Force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said.\n\nAs she arrived in Brisbane, Australian tourist Mary Hatten said she had been largely confined to her hotel. \"The place was just in a mess,\" she told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.\n\nChris Salmon, who works in the mining industry in New Caledonia, hugged his family and said he was relieved to have left the French island. \"It feels all pretty awful, pretty senseless,\" he said.\n\nThe airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nAround 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritized based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview. \"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nMore than 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defense groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French government doesn't know how to control people here,\" said Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks.\n\nThe situation on the ground was improving but much more needed to be done, French government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said.", "source": {"uri": The business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a social media post on Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \"Australian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\"\n\nNew Zealand, French and Australian foreign ministers held a call on Monday evening, after New Zealand and Australia said they were waiting for clearance from French authorities to send defense aircraft to evacuate tourists.\n\nA meeting of France's defense council later agreed for arrangements to allow tourists to return home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nREAD MORE: France sends more police to New Caledonia to try to restore calm\n\n\"We want to acknowledge the support of relevant authorities, both in Paris and Noum\u00e9a, in facilitating this flight,\" he added. Further flights will be sent in the coming days, he added.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a social media post on Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \"Australian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\".\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections, which local leaders fear will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nThree of six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defense groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission previously said\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\nALSO READ: Australians stranded in New Caledonia 'running out of food' amid civil unrest\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defense groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission previously said.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. Her family are fighting to bring her home - after insurers refused to cover her for one cruel reason\n\nThe Australian Defence Force was on standby to assist and were ready to fly as soon as they were permitted, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.\n\nA New Zealand government plane will also head to New Caledonia on Tuesday, foreign minister Winston Peters confirmed.\n\n'New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,' he said.\n\n'In co-operation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.'\n\nThe New Zealand flight on Tuesday will carry about 50 passengers with the most pressing needs back to Auckland.\n\nAbout 300 Australians have registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs in New Caledonia.\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more were injured after violence erupted last week following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nA Instead, he will be flying to the archipelago 10 time zones away from Paris, east of Australia, that has been gripped by deadly armed clashes, looting and arson with six people killed, including two gendarmes, in the past week.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island where indigenous people have long sought independence from France, and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of some parts of the capital, Noumea.\n\nFrench Army embarking a plane to New Caledonia at the Istres military base, southern France (Etat Major des Armees via AP)\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms Thevenot said.\n\n\"The return to calm is starting to arrive. "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/84-australians-evacuated-from-new-caledonia-via-military-planes-5654737", "title": "84 Australians Evacuated From New Caledonia via Military Planes", "body": "The Australian government is organising more flights to evacuate the remaining 200 citizens trapped in the French territory.\n\nThe first flights carrying Australians returning home from New Caledonia after a week of deadly rioting landed in Brisbane on the night of May 21.\n\nThis comes as French President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to the Pacific territory to deal with the unrest that resulted in six deaths and significant destruction to buildings and properties.\n\nA total of 108 people-84 Australians and 24 other nationals-were evacuated from New Caledonia via two Royal Australian Air Force planes.\n\nOn May 22, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy provided an update on the rescue operation.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" he told Nine News.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave.\"\n\nThe minister said the military planes also helped evacuate other nationalities due to reciprocal agreements with countries like Canada and Japan.\n\nAt present, there are still 200 Australians trapped in New Caledonia who are awaiting rescue.\n\nWhile the French government has planned to organise flights from Noumea to Brisbane on May 22, Mr. Conroy said the Australian government had other backup plans if the flights did not eventuate.\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Penny Wong also said the Australian government would continue to work with other countries to secure more evacuation flights.\n\nPrior to that, the minister had spoken with her French counterpart on May 20 to request access to the territory and received clearance for two flights on May 21.\n\nThe Australian government has advised citizens against travelling to New Caledonia and told those trapped in the territory to limit their movement.\n\nSocialist-led pro-independence supporters voiced their concerns over moves by the French National Assembly to introduce voting changes. The movement is concerned it will weaken the local indigenous Kanak vote by giving voting rights to French residents who have lived in the territory for over 10 years.\n\nThe rioters caused significant damage to the territory as they set buildings alight, looted shops, destroyed vehicles and barricaded roads.\n\nAs the riot escalated, violence was no longer confined to pro-independence protesters and French police and spread to demonstrators and civilian groups of pro-French residents, with frequent clashes between them.\n\nThe French government has deployed 1,000 security personnel to the territory to stabilise the situation, with hundreds more to be sent.\n\nSo far, 270 rioters have been arrested, while the territory is under a 12-hour curfew between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m.\n\nThe president will arrive on May 23 and is expected to stay in the territory for one day.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" French government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said.\n\n\"We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nFrench Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Mr. Macron would meet with local leaders to seek \"a comprehensive political agreement.\"\n\nThree ministers will also {"uri": "8139696460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:36:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:36:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:33:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/2946135-evacuations-amid-turmoil-australians-and-new-zealanders-escaping-new-caledonia", "title": "Evacuations Amid Turmoil: Australians and New Zealanders Escaping New Caledonia | Business", "body": "Amid violent unrest in New Caledonia, the Australian military evacuated 115 people, with additional flights planned. Six fatalities and hundreds of injuries have already resulted from the clashes. French and Australian officials are coordinating repatriation efforts, prioritizing vulnerable citizens. French President Macron's visit brings further scrutiny to France's colonial legacy.\n\nThe Australian military has flown 115 passengers on two flights from the restive French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a French government flight was expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers on Wednesday, an Australian government minister said.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land on Thursday in New Caledonia, where Indigenous people have long sought independence. The unrest has raised new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian citizens accounted for 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane late Tuesday, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy said.\n\nConroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Conroy added.\n\nConroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists so the primary plan is more French flights but ... we do have contingency plans and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Conroy later told Australian Broadcasting Corp.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Conroy added. A New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later Wednesday, the statement said. The New Zealand military would fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg. Around 265 New Zealanders wanted to leave New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian tourist Malisa Plesa said she had hoped to be evacuated by the Australian air force on Tuesday but remained in a Noumeau hotel on Wednesday.\n\n\"We didn't actually receive any notification that we wouldn't be on those flights. We were basically told to standby all day because we could be provided with 20 minutes notice to get on one of these flights,\" Plesa told Nine.\n\n\"However at about 9 p.m. last night we received communications saying that the French authorities will now be coordinating the evacuation of all tourists that still remain within New Caledonia so for us I think that means that we don't know when we'll be able to get home,\" she added.\n\nAustralian tourist Fadi Chemali had been aboard the first Australian military flight to Brisbane.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he said at Brisbane Airport.\n\nChemali had been on vacation with his wife and young daughter for a week before the riots broke out and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were. It has been fairly intense,\" Chamali said.\n\nThe road to New Caledonia's international airport remained closed on Wednesday.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is {"uri": "8139545984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:12:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:12:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:11:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/583774", "title": "New Caledonia riots: Tourists evacuated, French President Macron to visit", "body": "SYDNEY/PARIS - French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia late on Tuesday, his office said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, killing six.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand were evacuating tourists from the island as the violence left a trail of destruction with looted shops, torched cars and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nMacron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nMacron \"will discuss with all the forces in New Caledonia\", French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said. \"The objective is to ... prepare and anticipate reconstruction.\"\n\n\"The president is also going there to re-establish dialogue,\" Attal said.\n\nDialogue\n\nInitial reaction showed renewing dialogue will not be an easy task, all the more so as pro-independence leaders blame the riots on Macron pushing through the electoral reform despite local opposition.\n\n\"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, wrote on X in response to news of Macron's visit.\n\nFrance annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No. 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one-in-five residents live below the poverty threshold.\n\nThe island lies some 20,000 km (12,430 miles) away from mainland France, and some 1,500 km (930 miles) east of Australia. It has longed been rocked by pro-independence movements. The past week's violence has been the worst there in 40 years.\n\nThe opposition in Paris, former French prime ministers, and leaders of other Pacific islands have also said Macron should scrap or suspend the electoral reform, which parliament in Paris adopted last Tuesday.\n\nVanuatu Foreign Minister Matai Seremaiah urged France to \"do the right thing, to resolve all outstanding decolonisation issues\" and seriously engage with Kanak leaders.\n\nItem 1 of 6 France's President Emmanuel Macron waves as he boards his Presidential plane to travel to the Pacific archipelago of New Caledonia in an attempt to resolve a political crisis, at the Orly airport, a suburb of Paris on May 21, 2024. LUDOVIC MARIN/Pool via REUTERS\n\nEvacuations\n\nSome 108 Australians and other tourists landed in Brisbane on two government flights, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on X. A Defence Force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said.\n\nAs she arrived in Brisbane, Australian tourist Mary Hatten said she had been largely confined to her hotel. \"The place was just in a mess,\" she told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.\n\nChris Salmon, who works in the mining industry in New Caledonia, hugged his family and said he was relieved to have left the French island. \"It feels all pretty awful, pretty senseless,\" he said.\n\nThe airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nAround 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritized based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview. \"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nMore than 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defense groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French government doesn't know how to control people here,\" said Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks.\n\nThe situation on the ground was improving but much more needed to be done, French government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said.", "source": {"uri": Australia and New Zealand have sent airplanes to New Caledonia to begin bringing home stranded citizens from the violence-wracked French South Pacific territory. (David Clark/Courier Mail/AAP via AP)\n\nMELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- The Australian military had flown 115 passengers in two flights from the restive French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and would continue to work with France to repatriate all Australians who want to leave, an Australian government minister said Wednesday.\n\nAustralian citizens accounted for 84 of the passengers who were flown in two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane late Tuesday, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy said.\n\nConroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nAnother more than 200 Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to leave the South Pacific territory where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritized the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every\n\nAustralian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Conroy added.\n\nConroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"We're working very hard to make sure as many Australians as possible are on those flights,\" Conroy said.\n\nA second round of 100 New Zealanders were being flown home from New Caledonia via Brisbane on Wednesday after around 100 were flown to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, The New Zealand Herald newspaper reported.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land on Thursday on New Caledonia where Indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe road to New Caledonia's international airport remained closed on Wednesday.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-05-363259872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:17:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:17:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:15:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2945241-macrons-mission-addressing-unrest-in-new-caledonia", "title": "Macron's Mission: Addressing Unrest in New Caledonia", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will visit New Caledonia following violent riots over electoral reform. The riots have caused significant destruction and loss of life. Macron aims to restore order and address local concerns. Meanwhile, evacuations of Australian and New Zealand nationals are ongoing as security forces work to maintain peace.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, leaving six dead. The riots over electoral reform have left a trail of destruction with shops looted, cars burnt and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. The island's business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nSpeaking after a cabinet meeting, French government spokesman Prisca Thevenot said Macron would travel to \"set up a mission,\" without saying what it could entail. Some politicians have called for veteran politicians to be named as mediators, but Thevenot did not say if this was what Macron had in mind.\n\n\"Our priority is the return to calm and order,\" Thevenot said, noting the situation on the ground was improving but more needed to be done. Australia and New Zealand have already begun evacuating nationals from New Caledonia.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said. \"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nThe New Zealand Herald reported that a defence force plane had landed in Auckland with some 50 citizens evacuated from New Caledonia. Further flights were expected in the coming days. Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said clearance had been received for two Australian government assisted-departure flights on Tuesday for tourists wanting to leave.\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia said the airport remained closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings. MORE POLICE\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily. \"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\" Queueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were at work, and another 600 personnel would be added, France's High Commission said. The commission asked French residents who normally live outside New Caledonia to register their details for support to return home.\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote. Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview. Three of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it fails,\" Xulue said. Pro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, The plane can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defense Department.\n\nFRENCH SECURITY REINFORCEMENTS EASE VIOLENT UNREST IN NEW CALEDONIA\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong wrote on the social media platform X on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia. It did not immediately confirm whether the Australian-organized flights would also evacuate other stranded foreign nationals, believed to number in the thousands.\n\nNew Zealand's government also announced that it had sent a plane to New Caledonia to begin evacuating about 50 of its citizens.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said. \"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days.\"\n\nFRANCE GRAPPLES TO REGAIN CONTROL OF VIOLENT UNREST IN NEW CALEDONIA AS DEATH TOLL RISES TO 4\n\nNoumea's international airport remains closed to commercial flights. Its reopening will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week in New Caledonia following controversial electoral reforms passed in Paris.\n\nAbout 270 suspected rioters have been arrested as of Tuesday, and a 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew is in effect for the archipelago of about 270,000 people, which is a popular tourist destination with its idyllic beaches and climate.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nFrance has sent in over a thousand security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday, to try to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nArmed clashes, looting, arson and other violence turned parts of Noumea into no-go zones. Columns of smoke billowed into the sky, hulks of burned cars littered roads, businesses and shops were ransacked and buildings became smoking ruins.\n\nThere have been decades of tensions between indigenous Kanaks who are seeking independence and descendants of colonizers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear {"uri": "8139710576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:46:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:46:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:45:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/world/australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-scores-of-citizens-from-new-caledonia-HHMQ7FIKIFOHXDO7PCCZLK76WM/", "title": "Australia and New Zealand evacuate scores of citizens from New Caledonia", "body": "Six people have been killed during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in the French Pacific territory.\n\nThe Australian military has flown 115 passengers on two flights from the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a French government flight was expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers on Wednesday, an Australian government minister said.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest erupted on May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land on Thursday in New Caledonia, where Indigenous people have long sought independence. The unrest has raised new questions about Mr Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late on Tuesday from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nMr Conroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Mr Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nMr Conroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists, so the primary plan is more French flights, but ... we do have contingency plans, and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Mr Conroy later told the ABC.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA street in Noumea, New Caledonia, is pictured after unrest (Nicolas Job/AP)A French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later on Wednesday, the statement said. {"uri": "8139186773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "20:02:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T20:02:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T20:01:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.sabcnews.com/sabcnews/macron-heads-to-riot-hit-new-caledonia-as-australia-nz-evacuate-tourists/", "title": "Macron heads to riot-hit New Caledonia - SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all South African current events. Africa's news leader.", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia late on Tuesday, his office said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, killing six.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand were evacuating tourists from the island as the violence left a trail of destruction with looted shops, torched cars and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nMacron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nMacron \"will discuss with all the forces in New Caledonia\", French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said. \"The objective is to ... prepare and anticipate reconstruction.\"\n\n\"The president is also going there to re-establish dialogue,\" Attal said.\n\nDIALOGUE\n\nInitial reaction showed renewing dialogue will not be an easy task, all the more so as pro-independence leaders blame the riots on Macron pushing through the electoral reform despite local opposition.\n\n\"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, wrote on X in response to news of Macron's visit.\n\nFrance annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No. 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one-in-five residents live below the poverty threshold.\n\nThe island lies some 20 000 km (12 430 miles) away from mainland France, and some 1 500 km (930 miles) east of Australia. It has longed been rocked by pro-independence movements. The past week's violence has been the worst there in 40 years.\n\nThe opposition in Paris, former French prime ministers, and leaders of other Pacific islands have also said Macron should scrap or suspend the electoral reform, which parliament in Paris adopted last Tuesday.\n\nVanuatu Foreign Minister Matai Seremaiah urged France to \"do the right thing, to resolve all outstanding decolonisation issues\" and seriously engage with Kanak leaders.\n\nEVACUATIONS\n\nSome 108 Australians and other tourists landed in Brisbane on two government flights, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on X. A Defence Force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said.\n\nAs she arrived in Brisbane, Australian tourist Mary Hatten said she had been largely confined to her hotel. \"The place was just in a mess,\" she told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.\n\nChris Salmon, who works in the mining industry in New Caledonia, hugged his family and said he was relieved to have left the French island. \"It feels all pretty awful, pretty senseless,\" he said.\n\nThe airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nAround 3 200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview. \"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nMore than 1 000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French government doesn't know how to control people here,\" said Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks.\n\nThe situation on the ground was improving but much more needed to be done, French government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said.", "source": {"uri": "sabcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all South African current events. nationals from unrest", "body": "Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two flights to evacuate citizens and other tourists from the French Pacific nation.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said 300 Australians were in New Caledonia.\"We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong wrote on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nAt least six people have died and hundreds more have been injured since violence erupted last week after a bill was passed allowing more French residents to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nIndigenous people have long sought independence from France.\n\nSome 270 rioters had been arrested, and a 6pm-6am curfew was in force for the archipelago of about 270,000 people.\n\nNew Zealand also announced it was sending a plane to evacuate 50 of its nationals from Noumea, the Pacific island's capital.\n\nIt will be the first in a series of proposed flights to bring its citizens home.\"Our number one priority is the safety and wellbeing of kiwis trapped in New Caledonia and to get them home safe,\" Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"This will be the first of multiple trips to get kiwis home.\"\n\nFrance has sent in more than 1,000 security personnel, with hundreds more due to arrive as it tries to quell the unrest and restore control.\n\nIt follows decades of tension between indigenous Kanaks seeking independence and descendants of colonisers who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nThe National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks who once suffered from strict The National Assembly in Paris approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents fear {"uri": "8139702915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:39:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:39:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:38:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2024/05/22/australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-scores-of-their-citizens-from-new-caledonia", "title": "Australia and New Zealand evacuate scores of their citizens from New Caledonia", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) - The Australian military has flown 115 passengers on two flights from the restive French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a French government flight was expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers on Wednesday, an Australian government minister said.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land Thursday in New Caledonia, where Indigenous people have long sought independence. The unrest has raised new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian citizens accounted for 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane late Tuesday, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy said.\n\nConroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritized the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Conroy added.\n\nConroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists so the primary plan is more French flights but ... we do have contingency plans and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Conroy later told Australian Broadcasting Corp.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defense Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later Wednesday, the statement said. The New Zealand military would fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg. Around 265 New Zealanders wanted to leave New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian tourist Malisa Plesa said she had hoped to be evacuated by the Australian air force on Tuesday but remained in a Noumeau hotel on Wednesday.\n\n\"We didn't actually receive any notification that we wouldn't be on those flights. We were basically told to standby all day because we could be provided with 20 minutes notice to get on one of these flights,\" Plesa told Nine.\n\n\"However at about 9 p.m. last night we received communications saying that the French authorities will now be coordinating the evacuation of all tourists that still remain within New Caledonia so for us I think that means that we don't know when we'll be able to get home,\" she added.\n\nAustralian tourist Fadi Chemali had been aboard the first Australian military flight to Brisbane.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he said at Brisbane Airport.\n\nChemali had been on vacation with his wife and young daughter for a week before the riots broke out and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were. It has been fairly intense,\" Chamali said.\n\nThe road to New Caledonia's international airport remained closed on Wednesday. - AP", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8138769523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "14:45:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T14:45:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T14:43:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2945519-macrons-visit-to-new-caledonia-a-mission-for-peace-amidst-unrest", "title": "Macron's Visit to New Caledonia: A Mission for Peace Amidst Unrest | Politics", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will visit New Caledonia to address concerns over recent riots sparked by electoral reform. The visit aims to initiate reconstruction and dialogue among local leaders. Australia and New Zealand are evacuating tourists as violence disrupts daily life and essential supplies.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, killing six.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand were evacuating tourists from the island as the violence left a trail of destruction with looted shops, torched cars and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. Some 108 Australians and other tourists landed in Brisbane on two government flights, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on X. A defence force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said. The airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote. Macron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nMacron \"will discuss with all the forces in New Caledonia\", French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said. \"The objective is to ... prepare and anticipate reconstruction.\" \"The president is also going there to re-establish dialogue,\" Attal said.\n\nDIALOGUE Initial reaction showed renewing dialogue will not be an easy task, all the more so as pro-independence leaders blame the riots on Macron pushing through the electoral reform despite local opposition.\n\n\"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, wrote on X about news of Macron's visit. France annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No. 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one in five residents live under the poverty threshold.\n\nThe island lies some 20,000 km (12,430 miles) away from mainland France, and some 1,500 km (930 miles) east of Australia. The opposition in Paris, former French prime ministers, and leaders of other Pacific islands have also said Macron should not go ahead with the electoral reform, which parliament in Paris adopted last Tuesday.\n\nVanuatu Foreign Minister Matai Seremaiah urged France to \"do the right thing, to resolve all outstanding decolonisation issues\" and seriously engage with Kanak leaders. EVACUATIONS Around 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily. \"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\" Queueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's High Commission said. Three of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here,\" said Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks. He said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s and people were scared. The situation on the ground was improving but much more needed to be done, French government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Instead, he will be flying to the archipelago 10 time zones away from Paris, east of Australia, that has been gripped by deadly armed clashes, looting and arson with six people killed, including two gendarmes, in the past week.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island where indigenous people have long sought independence from France, and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of some parts of the capital, Noumea.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms Thevenot said.\n\n\"The return to calm is starting to arrive. The situation is not quite totally normalised, but the situation is improving. We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nA priority for French authorities since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noumea's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of finally being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens.\n\nAustralian foreign minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noumea. We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong added.\n\nThe New Zeland Foreign Ministry said that a government plane would be arriving in New Caledonia on Tuesday to carry 50 passengers most in need of assistance from Noum\u00e9a to Auckland.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the Government,\" Foreign Minister Winston Peters said in a statement.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" Peters said.\n\nAfter days of serious unrest in New Caledonia, the situation appears to be easing.\n\nSix people have been killed so far in the riots on the island 1,500 kilometres east of Australia and over 200 people have been detained.\n\nThe background to the protests by those in favour of independence for the archipelago are planned electoral reforms emanating from Paris. The changes would give French residents the right to vote in provincial elections if they have lived there for 10 years.\n\nHowever, the Kanak population group in particular - New Caledonia's Indigenous inhabitants - have long hoped for their own state. The national council of the Kanaks accused Paris of pushing ahead with the controversial reform without taking into account the resistance of the vast majority of the Indigenous population.\n\nThe former French colony had already gained extensive autonomy through the Noum\u00e9a Agreement of 1998. {"uri": "8138598875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "13:00:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T13:00:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:59:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-macron-heads-to-new-caledonia-as-australia-new-zealand-send-evacuation/", "title": "Macron heads to New Caledonia as Australia, New Zealand send evacuation flights", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, leaving six dead.\n\nThe riots over electoral reform have left a trail of destruction with shops looted, cars burnt and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. The island's business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nSpeaking after a cabinet meeting, French government spokesman Prisca Thevenot said Macron would travel to \"set up a mission,\" without saying what it could entail.\n\nSome politicians have called for veteran politicians to be named as mediators, but Thevenot did not say if this was what Macron had in mind.\n\n\"Our priority is the return to calm and order,\" Thevenot said, noting the situation on the ground was improving but more needed to be done.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand have already begun evacuating nationals from New Caledonia.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nThe New Zealand Herald reported that a defence force plane had landed in Auckland with some 50 citizens evacuated from New Caledonia. Further flights were expected in the coming days.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said clearance had been received for two Australian government assisted-departure flights on Tuesday for tourists wanting to leave.\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia said the airport remained closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritized based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nQueueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were at work, and another 600 personnel would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThe commission asked French residents who normally live outside New Caledonia to register their details for support to return home.\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it fails,\" Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], The situation isn't quite totally normalised but the situation is improving.\n\n\"We are clear: much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nA priority for French authorities since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noumea's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of citizens.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 The unrest has raised new questions about Mr Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late on Tuesday from the capital Noum\u00e9a to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nMr Conroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Mr Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nMr Conroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists, so the primary plan is more French flights, but ... we do have contingency plans, and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Mr Conroy later told the ABC.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening, and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noum\u00e9a to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later on Wednesday, the statement said. The New Zealand military would fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg.
