{"uri": "2024-05-363667789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "17:14:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T17:14:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T17:07:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-05-21/new-caledonia-where-is-the-french-overseas-territory-heading-for-civil-war", "title": "New Caledonia: Where is the French overseas territory 'heading for civil war'?", "body": "Six people have been killed and hundreds injured in New Caledonia - the French Pacific territory that has been gripped by days of deadly armed clashes, looting, and arson.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron will visit the riot-hit island, where burnt out cars litter the streets and some 300 people have been arrested.\n\nThe violence in New Caledonia has led to fresh discussion of France's colonial past, raising new questions about Mr Macron's handling of that legacy.\n\nWhere is New Caledonia?\n\nNew Caledonia is a group of islands in the south-west Pacific Ocean, lying between Australia and New Zealand, with a population of 270,000 people.\n\nIt has been a French colony since the mid-1800s, and became a French overseas territory in 1946.\n\nThe islands have experienced decades of tension between the indigenous Kanaks - who have long sought independence - and the descendants of French colonisers, who wish New Caledonia to remain a part of France.\n\nPerhaps most demonstrative of this was a period of violent uprisings in the 1980s, known as \"the events\", in which dozens of people died.\n\nIt was the biggest threat to French rule in the islands' history, quelled by a series of agreements outlining a path to gradual autonomy for the Kanaks.\n\nBut it wasn't until 2018 that the first independence referendum was held on the islands. Three referendums have now been held, with the anti-independence side winning out each time.\n\nStill, pro-independence leaders have called for another vote, arguing that the third referendum should have been delayed.\n\nMany Kanaks were prohibited from voting in the 2021 vote by mourning customs, following a coronavirus outbreak that devastated communities there.\n\nWhy is it important to France?\n\nThe calculus in France has changed in recent years, as the south-pacific region takes up a more consequential space on the world stage.\n\nAs jostling between the US and China for influence in the region intensifies, French officials fear that China could gain sway in an independent New Caledonia - just as it has sought to do in the Solomon Islands.\n\nNew Caledonia is also one of the world's biggest nickel producers, holding between 20-30% of the world's reserves.\n\nPresident Macron visited the islands last July to emphasise his vision for the French-Pacific outpost.\n\n\"New Caledonia is French because it has chosen to remain French,\" Mr Macron told the crowd. \"No going back. No stuttering.\"\n\nWhat has sparked the recent violence?\n\nThe latest period of unrest erupted on May 13, when French lawmakers in Paris debated making changes to New Caledonian voting lists.\n\nThe French National Assembly approved a bill that would, among other changes, allow residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years or more to cast ballots in provincial elections.\n\nOpponents say the measure will benefit pro-France politicians, and further marginalise the Kanaks by diluting their political influence.\n\nUnder prior accords, voting in provincial elections was restricted to those who had resided in New Caledonia since before 1998, and their descendants.\n\nThe measure was aimed at giving greater representation to the Kanaks who had, at that point, become a minority group on the islands.\n\nOn Wednesday, Paris declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the islands, and rushed in over 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that had lost control of parts of the capital, Noumea.\n\nAt least six people have been killed, including two police officers.\n\nParts of the city have become no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillages, and makeshift barricades set up.\n\n\"The protests reveal the determination of our young people to no longer let France rule them,\" said Daniel Goa, the president of the pro-independence Caledonian Union party, although he called for a stop to the violence.\n\nWhat happens next?\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6pm to 6am curfew in effect, French authorities say security forces are starting to contain the unrest.\n\nA priority for French authorities has been clearing the highway to the international airport, in order to allow stranded tourists to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing citizens home. Some 300 Australians and 50 New Zealanders are currently stranded\n\nPresident Macron's visit will aim to subdue tensions. He will travel to the islands on Tuesday evening, but no details have been given regarding the length of his stay.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume,\" said a French government spokesperson.\n\n\"We are clear: much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nLocal authorities have also called for calm, with the High Commissioner of the Republic, Louis Le Franc, warning the territory is \"heading straight for a civil war\".\n\nFrench Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said re-establishing order was necessary for further dialogue to begin.\n\nBut pro-independence parties say they want the French government to withdraw the reforms before they restart talks.\n\nMr Macron said he was open to reaching a negotiated settlement, but that a new agreement must be reached by June, or else he would sign it into law regardless.", "source": {"uri": "itv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ITV Hub"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overseas_France", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8139712214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:49:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:49:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:46:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-scores-of-their-citizens-from-new-caledonia-5982055.html", "title": "World News | Australia and New Zealand Evacuate Scores of Their Citizens from New Caledonia | LatestLY", "body": "Melbourne (Australia), May 22 (AP) The Australian military has flown 115 passengers on two flights from the restive French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a French government flight was expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers on Wednesday, an Australian government minister said.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nAlso Read | Pakistan: Three-Year-Old Toddler Booked for Electricity Theft in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land on Thursday in New Caledonia, where Indigenous people have long sought independence. The unrest has raised new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAlso Read | Kami Rita Sherpa, Nepal's Everest Man, Climbs Mount Everest for Record 30th Time.\n\nAustralian citizens accounted for 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane late Tuesday, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy said.\n\nConroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Conroy added.\n\nConroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists so the primary plan is more French flights but ... we do have contingency plans and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Conroy later told Australian Broadcasting Corp.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later Wednesday, the statement said. The New Zealand military would fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg. Around 265 New Zealanders wanted to leave New Caledonia.\n\nAustralian tourist Malisa Plesa said she had hoped to be evacuated by the Australian air force on Tuesday but remained in a Noumeau hotel on Wednesday.\n\n\"We didn't actually receive any notification that we wouldn't be on those flights. We were basically told to standby all day because we could be provided with 20 minutes notice to get on one of these flights,\" Plesa told Nine.\n\n\"However at about 9 p.m. last night we received communications saying that the French authorities will now be coordinating the evacuation of all tourists that still remain within New Caledonia so for us I think that means that we don't know when we'll be able to get home,\" she added.\n\nAustralian tourist Fadi Chemali had been aboard the first Australian military flight to Brisbane.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he said at Brisbane Airport.\n\nChemali had been on vacation with his wife and young daughter for a week before the riots broke out and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were. It has been fairly intense,\" Chamali said.\n\nThe road to New Caledonia's international airport remained closed on Wednesday. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nAnother more than 200 Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to leave the South Pacific territory where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritized the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every\n\nAustralian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Conroy added.\n\nConroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"We're working very hard to make sure as many Australians as possible are on those flights,\" Conroy said.\n\nA second round of 100 New Zealanders were being flown home from New Caledonia via Brisbane on Wednesday after around 100 were flown to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, The New Zealand Herald newspaper reported.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land on Thursday on New Caledonia where Indigenous people have long sought independence.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured in New Caledonia during armed clashes, looting and arson, raising new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nThe unrest erupted May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists. Opponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalize Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nThe {"uri": "8139551480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:18:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:18:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:17:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/mess-evacuees-caledonia-tell-relief-030405554.html", "title": "'In a mess': Evacuees from New Caledonia tell of relief", "body": "Australians evacuated from New Caledonia after being stranded during more than a week of violent protests have been expressing their relief at returning home.\n\nTwo Royal Australian Air Force planes landed in Brisbane on Tuesday night, carrying 108 Australians and other tourists stranded by the closure of the French Pacific territory's international airport.\n\nMeanwhile, the New Zealand military flew 48 people into Auckland.\n\nFrance has said it expects to evacuate around 500 people on military aircraft - starting on Wednesday.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is on his way to the territory - which has seen its most serious unrest in decades - and will arrive on Thursday.\n\nHe'll be accompanied others including by the country's interior minister and armed forces minister to set up a dialogue mission.\n\nHis travel to the riot-hit island comes after more than a week of unrest there over his government's voting reform plans, which have been rejected by indigenous Kanaks.\n\nIndigenous leaders say the plans, which will allow more French residents to vote in local elections, will dilute the political influence of native people.\n\nAmong the 108 people on the Australia-assisted rescue flights were Mary Hatten and her family, who were on holiday in the usually idyllic destination.\n\n\"By [last] Tuesday morning... the place was just in a mess, which was very sad for the locals, for the tourist industry, and I suppose to some extent for our own personal enjoyment. We were pretty much confined to the hotel,\" Ms Hatten told the ABC.\n\n\"When we landed [in Brisbane] it was just like: 'Oh, thank God we're here!'\"\n\nOthers evacuated have a long connection to New Caledonia.\n\nGary Salmon, who lives on the Gold Coast in Queensland, said he had been working in the nickel mining industry in New Caledonia for 20 years.\n\n\"It's very unfortunate what's happening there at the moment, it's such a beautiful country,\" he said to the ABC.\n\n\"I'd hate to estimate the damage over there, it won't be millions, it'll be billions.\"\n\nMany Australians remain in New Caledonia - with around 300 having registered as being stuck in or close to the capital, Noumea.\n\n\"We continue to work with partners on further flights, prioritising passengers based on need,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a statement on social media.\n\nMeanwhile New Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters said the government was \"working with France and Australia on a further flight [on Wednesday] to bring another group of Kiwis in New Caledonia home via Brisbane, using French and New Zealand aircraft.\"\n\nEvacuation flights will continue \"until the reopening of La Tontouta International Airport\", the French High Commission in Noumea said on Wednesday.\n\nIn its daily update on the crisis, it said that 84 police officers and gendarmes had now been injured since the start of the disturbances, with more than 280 rioters arrested, including more than 20 on Tuesday.\n\nA state of emergency remains in place - which includes a night-time curfew and a ban on Instead, he will be flying to the archipelago 10 time zones away from Paris, east of Australia, that has been gripped by deadly armed clashes, looting, arson and other mayhem, with six people killed, including two gendarmes, in the past week.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island where indigenous people have long sought independence from France, and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of some parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said.\n\n\"The return to calm is starting to arrive. The situation isn't quite totally normalized, but the situation is improving. We are clear: Much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilized.\"\n\nA priority for French authorities since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noum\u00e9a's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of finally being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules touched down in Noum\u00e9a. The unrest has raised new questions about Mr Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late on Tuesday from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nMr Conroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Mr Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nMr Conroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists, so the primary plan is more French flights, but ... we do have contingency plans, and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Mr Conroy later told the ABC.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 The situation isn't quite totally normalised but the situation is improving.\n\n\"We are clear: much remains to be done before the return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nA priority for French authorities since the weekend has been clearing the highway to Noumea's international airport of barricades and the burned hulks of vehicles, raising the prospect for stranded tourists of finally being able to leave.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to begin bringing home stranded citizens.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia had received clearance from French authorities for two evacuation flights.\n\nHours later, a Royal Australian Air Force C-130 The business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nNew Zealand, French and Australian foreign ministers held a call on Monday evening, after New Zealand and Australia said they were waiting for clearance from French authorities to send defence aircraft to evacuate tourists.\n\nA meeting of France's defence council later agreed for arrangements to allow tourists to return home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"We want to acknowledge the support of relevant authorities, both in Paris and Noum\u00e9a, in facilitating this flight,\" he added. Further flights will be sent in coming days, he added.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a social media post on Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \"Australian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\".\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections, which local leaders fear will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission previously said.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it's fail,\" Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.", "source": {"uri": "thejakartapost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Jakarta Post"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8137920849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "06:01:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T06:01:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T06:00:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0521/1450317-new-caledonia/", "title": "First tourist rescue flight lands in New Caledonia", "body": "A military transport aircraft has landed in riot-hit New Caledonia to evacuate trapped tourists, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since 13 May, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said this morning.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60km road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak protesters.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\nOne of those guarding the roadblock, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there - we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he said.\n\nAnother masked man said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40% of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least ten years.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand", "type": "loc", nationalities were included due to reciprocal agreements with countries like Canada and Japan that help evacuate Australian citizens during times of crisis, Mr Conroy said.\n\nMore than 200 Australians remain trapped in New Caledonia and want to leave.\n\nThe French government is planning flights from Noumea to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"We obviously have plans developed and planes {"uri": "8139705935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:42:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:42:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:41:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/world-news/2024/05/22/australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-scores-of-citizens-from-new-caledonia/", "title": "Australia and New Zealand evacuate scores of citizens from New Caledonia", "body": "Six people have been killed during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in the French Pacific territory.\n\nThe Australian military has flown 115 passengers on two flights from the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a French government flight was expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers on Wednesday, an Australian government minister said.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nThe unrest erupted on May 13 as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late on Tuesday from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nMr Conroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Mr Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nMr Conroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists, so the primary plan is more French flights, but ... we do have contingency plans, and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Mr Conroy later told the ABC.\n\n\"A French plane is expected to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or this evening and we expect around 100 Australians to be on it,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland on Tuesday night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight would bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later on Wednesday, the statement said. The New Zealand military would fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg. Around 265 New Zealanders wanted to leave New Caledonia.\n\nThe road to New Caledonia's international airport remained closed on Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-364185037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:42:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:42:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:59:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/national-world/cnn-world/2024/05/21/french-president-emmanuel-macron-heads-to-violence-hit-new-caledonia/", "title": "French President Emmanuel Macron heads to violence-hit New Caledonia - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- French President Emmanuel Macron is on his way to New Caledonia, a government official has said, after a week of deadly unrest in the Pacific archipelago.\n\nMacron was leaving Paris on Tuesday night and will \"set up a mission\" in the French territory, government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot told a press conference, without giving further details.\n\nHe will be accompanied by Interior Minister G\u00e9rald Darmanin, Defense Minister S\u00e9bastien Lecornu, and Overseas Minister Marie Gu\u00e9venoux, Darmanin told the National Assembly.\n\nNew Caledonia has been roiled by riots sparked by electoral changes from the national government. The unrest has killed at least six people, and has left a trail of burned cars and looted shops, with road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nThe violence is the latest outburst of political tensions that have simmered for years and pitted the island's largely pro-independence indigenous Kanak communities - who have long chafed against rule by Paris - against French inhabitants opposed to breaking ties with their motherland.\n\nMacron's visit comes as Australia and New Zealand deploy government planes to evacuate their nationals from New Caledonia and as hundreds more French security personnel have been deployed to assist in the unrest.\n\nFrance's High Commission of New Caledonia said Tuesday the airport remains closed for commercial flights until May 25.\n\nThevenot said Tuesday that 1,000 more members of French security forces have arrived in New Caledonia to support the 1,700 personnel already on the island. Darmanin also told the French legislature the number of police and gendarmes in New Caledonia would soon reach 3,000.\n\nAlso speaking to France's National Assembly, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday \"the situation is starting to improve.\"\n\nProtests began May 13 involving mostly young people, in response to the tabling of a vote in the French parliament proposing changes to New Caledonia's constitution that would give greater voting rights to French residents living on the islands. On Tuesday, legislators voted overwhelmingly in favor of the change.\n\nThe proposed changes to the constitution add thousands of extra voters to New Caledonia's electoral rolls, which have not been updated since the late 1990s. Pro-independence groups say the changes are an attempt by France to consolidate its rule over the archipelago. Supporters of the change say voter rolls will better reflect the current population.\n\nLying in the South Pacific with Australia, Fiji and Vanuatu for neighbors, New Caledonia is a semiautonomous French territory -- one of a dozen scattered throughout the Pacific, Caribbean and Indian Ocean.\n\nColonial France took control of New Caledonia in 1853. White settlement followed and the indigenous Kanak people were longtime victims of harsh segregation policies. Many indigenous inhabitants continue to live with high rates of poverty and high unemployment to this day.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.aap.com.au/news/repatriation-flights-touch-down-from-new-caledonia/", "title": "Repatriation flights touch down from New Caledonia", "body": "Scores of relieved Australians have arrived home after escaping the anguish and turmoil of more than a week of deadly rioting in New Caledonia.\n\nRoyal Australian Air Force planes were sent to the French territory on Tuesday after the federal government was given clearance for two flights to bring back citizens.\n\nFadi Chemali, who was on the first plane to reach Australia, said those on board were filled with relief after days of failing to find a way off the island.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he told AAP shortly after landing in Brisbane on Tuesday night.\n\nMr Chemali had been holidaying with his wife and young daughter for a week before the riots broke out and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were, it has been fairly intense.\"\n\nMr Chemali said he first believed French authorities would help tourists off the island before it became clear Australia needed to step in.\n\nAt least six people have died in the territory and hundreds have been injured since violence broke out last Monday.\n\nFrench troops are trying to stem further unrest, with buildings razed, shops looted and roads barricaded.\n\nAbout 300 Australians in New Caledonia are registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs.\n\nA Hercules military plane reached Noumea earlier on Tuesday after leaving RAAF Base Amberley near Ipswich, according to public flight data.\n\nIt can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defence Department.\n\nForeign Minister Penny Wong said the government will continue to work with other countries on securing more flights.\n\n\"French authorities have advised they will conduct flights to enable the safe departure of foreign tourists from New Caledonia, commencing tomorrow,\" she wrote on social media platform X, adding Australia was ready to help.\n\nAustralia's Consul-General in New Caledonia, Annelise Young, posted on X her team had been working round the clock with teams in Canberra and Paris and closely with the French authorities to ensure safe passage for Australian tourists.\n\nSenator Wong spoke with her New Zealand and French counterparts on Monday to request access to the territory.\n\nNew rules changing who is allowed to participate in the nation's elections have been slammed by the Indigenous Kanak people, who fear their vote will be diluted by thousands of French nationals who have moved to the island.\n\nAbout 270 rioters have been arrested and a 12-hour curfew imposed from 6pm to 6am.\n\nFrance has sent more than 1000 security personnel, with hundreds more to join, in a bid to quell the unrest.\n\nThe reopening of the international airport for commercial flights will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAustralia has urged people to reconsider travel to New Caledonia.\n\nThose in the territory have been advised to limit their movement.", "source": {"uri": "aap.com.au", {"uri": "8138437175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/frances-macron-to-visit-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_bd5f0c67-1ac8-5ca0-aa2b-34f139756f65.html", "title": "France's Macron to visit riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will visit riot-hit New Caledonia, Paris said Tuesday, as tourists are evacuated from the Pacific territory that has suffered over a week of unrest.\n\nMacron \"will leave as soon as this evening,\" government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said, hoping to soothe tempers over his government's voting reform plans rejected by indigenous Kanaks.\n\nEarlier Tuesday an Australian Air Force transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from a small domestic airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea, as separatist roadblocks still hinder access to the international hub.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent an initial batch of planes to Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nA second C-130 was slated to land in Auckland, New Zealand around 1000 GMT, with Foreign Minister Winston Peters saying it would bring \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" and promising \"subsequent flights in coming days\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates Noumea's larger La Tontouta international airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire, while the CCI on Monday tallied 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from Noumea to La Tontouta airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nProminent French figures including former Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who followed the New Caledonia file closely while in office, have called for delay to the constitutional change.\n\n\"You can't make progress on the Caledonia file by issuing ultimatums,\" Valls said Sunday.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nWithdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\n\"Violence cannot replace the ballot box in a democracy,\" he added.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, as well as a ban on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb-tgb/as/db", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mathurin_derel@ktbs.com", "name": "Mathurin mess': Australians arrive home after evacuation from New Caledonia", "body": "More than 100 Australians and other tourists were airlifted to Brisbane amid deadly riots and unrest in the Pacific nation\n\nMore than 100 Australians and other tourists have landed in Brisbane from New Caledonia after the government arranged two repatriation flights due to the worsening security situation in the Pacific island nation.\n\nIn a statement on X, foreign minister Penny Wong said 108 Australians and others had arrived back in Australia on Tuesday night on the government assisted-departure flights after riots in the former French territory left six dead and a trail of looted shops, torched cars and road barricades.\n\nA New Zealand defence force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's high commission in New Caledonia said.\n\nAs she arrived in Brisbane, Australian tourist Mary Hatten said she had been largely confined to her hotel. \"The place was just in a mess,\" she told the ABC.\n\nChris Salmon, who works in the mining industry in New Caledonia, hugged his family and said he was relieved to have left the French island. \"It feels all pretty awful, pretty senseless,\" he said.\n\nThe airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nAround 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, who has been stranded in New Caledonia while on honeymoon with wife his Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nMore than 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's high commission said.\n\nFrance's president, Emmanuel Macron, set off for the Pacific country late on Tuesday, his office said. He will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak Caledonia", "body": "Repatriation flights touch down from New CaledoniaHolly HalesAAPWed, 22 May 2024 1:37AM\n\nScores of relieved Australians have arrived home after escaping the anguish and turmoil of more than a week of deadly rioting in New Caledonia.\n\nRoyal Australian Air Force planes were sent to the French territory on Tuesday after the federal government was given clearance for two flights to bring back citizens.\n\nFadi Chemali, who was on the first plane to reach Australia, said those on board were filled with relief after days of failing to find a way off the island.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he told AAP shortly after landing in Brisbane on Tuesday night.\n\nTheNightly\n\nGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nMr Chemali had been holidaying with his wife and young daughter for a week before the riots broke out and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were, it has been fairly intense.\"\n\nMr Chemali said he first believed French authorities would help tourists off the island before it became clear Australia needed to step in.\n\nAt least six people have died in the territory and hundreds have been injured since violence broke out last Monday.\n\nFrench troops are trying to stem further unrest, with buildings razed, shops looted and roads barricaded.\n\nAbout 300 Australians in New Caledonia are registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs.\n\nA Hercules military plane reached Noumea earlier on Tuesday after leaving RAAF Base Amberley near Ipswich, according to public flight data.\n\nIt can carry 124 passengers, according to the Defence Department.\n\nForeign Minister Penny Wong said the government will continue to work with other countries on securing more flights.\n\n\"French authorities have advised they will conduct flights to enable the safe departure of foreign tourists from New Caledonia, commencing tomorrow,\" she wrote on social media platform X, adding Australia was ready to help.\n\nAustralia's Consul-General in New Caledonia, Annelise Young, posted on X her team had been working round the clock with teams in Canberra and Paris and closely with the French authorities to ensure safe passage for Australian tourists.\n\nSenator Wong spoke with her New Zealand and French counterparts on Monday to request access to the territory.\n\nNew rules changing who is allowed to participate in the nation's elections have been slammed by the Indigenous Kanak people, who fear their vote will be diluted by thousands of French nationals who have moved to the island.\n\nAbout 270 rioters have been arrested and a 12-hour curfew imposed from 6pm to 6am.\n\nFrance has sent more than 1000 security personnel, with hundreds more to join, in a bid to quell the unrest.\n\nThe reopening of the international airport for commercial flights will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAustralia has urged people to reconsider travel to New Caledonia.\n\nThose in the territory have been advised to limit their movement.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": The unrest has killed at least six people, and has left a trail of burned cars and looted shops, with road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nThe violence is the latest outburst of political tensions that have simmered for years and pitted the island's largely pro-independence indigenous Kanak communities - who have long chafed against rule by Paris - against French inhabitants opposed to breaking ties with their motherland.\n\nMacron's visit comes as Australia and New Zealand deploy government planes to evacuate their nationals from New Caledonia and as hundreds more French security personnel have been deployed to assist in the unrest.\n\nFrance's High Commission of New Caledonia said Tuesday the airport remains closed for commercial flights until May 25.\n\nThevenot said Tuesday that 1,000 more members of French security forces have arrived in New Caledonia to support the 1,700 personnel already on the island. Darmanin also told the French legislature the number of police and gendarmes in New Caledonia would soon reach 3,000.\n\nAlso speaking to France's National Assembly, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday \"the situation is starting to improve.\"\n\nProtests began May 13 involving mostly young people, in response to the tabling of a vote in the French parliament proposing changes to New Caledonia's constitution that would give greater voting rights to French residents living on the islands. Instead, he will be flying to the archipelago 10 time zones away from Paris, east of Australia, that has been gripped by deadly armed clashes, looting and arson with six people killed, including two gendarmes, in the past week.\n\nParis last Wednesday declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island where indigenous people have long sought independence from France, and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of some parts of the capital, Noumea.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms Thevenot said.\n\n\"The return to calm is starting to arrive. According to AFP, over 3,000 tourists have been trapped in New Caledonia, including over 300 Australians and roughly 250 New Zealanders.\n\nNew Zealand Foreign Minister Winston Peters stated that a plane will be sent to New Caledonia to initiate evacuations. He added that the flight would carry approximately 50 passengers with the most pressing needs from Noumea to Auckland. It would be the first in a series of planned flights, Peters said.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" Peters stated.\n\nThe evacuations come at a time when New Caledonia's international airport remains closed as protestors continue to block roads refusing to put an end to their demonstrations until their demands are met.\n\nRioting erupted last week before legislators in Paris voted on a plan allowing French people who have resided in New Caledonia for ten years to vote in provincial elections, which some local leaders believe will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nProtests over the regulations became violent on Monday night, with firearms fired at security personnel, vehicles set ablaze, and shops looted in the worst unrest the French overseas territory has seen since the 1980s.\n\nFrance considered a law that would extend voting eligibility in local elections to French nationals who have resided in New Caledonia for more than ten years, a move critics believe will marginalize Indigenous people. {"uri": "2024-05-363419305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "13:26:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T13:26:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T13:20:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article288605732.html", "title": "Australia, New Zealand begin airlifts from New Caledonia; Macron heads to islands", "body": "May 21 (UPI) -- Australia and New Zealand dispatched military flights to the French territory of New Caledonia in the Pacific on Tuesday to evacuate its citizens and tourists amid unrest that has killed at least six people.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a post on X that officials were contacting registered Australians after receiving clearance for \"two government assisted-departure flights\" for more than 300 Australians and other tourists to escape the territory.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritized based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Wong said.\n\nWong urged Australians who want to leave to register on the foreign ministry's crisis portal and anyone in need of emergency consular assistance to call its Consular Emergency Center.\n\nThe first Royal Australian Air Force aircraft departed New Caledonia bound for Brisbane shortly before 6 p.m. Canberra time with around 100 Australians on board.\n\nThe first of a series of planned New Zealand government flights arrived safely at Auckland International Airport from Noumea late Tuesday local time with around 50 people on board.\n\nThe Royal New Zealand Air Force C-130 Hercules was dispatched to rescue those \"with the most pressing needs\" and fly them back to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said in a news release earlier.\n\nPassengers for subsequent flights being laid on in cooperation with Australia and France would be prioritized by consular staff.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days -- and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government. We want to acknowledge the support of relevant authorities, both in Paris and Noumea, in facilitating this flight,\" said Peters.\n\nHe added that the situation in New Caledonia remained \"dynamic\" and that officials were continuing to work with French counterparts and other partners, Australia in particular, \"to understand what is needed to ensure the safety of our people there.\"\n\nNew Zealanders are urged to update their SafeTravel details to allow officials to be in touch with further advice while those requiring immediate assistance should contact the 24/7 Consular Emergency line.\n\nThe evacuations came as France announced President Emmanuel Macron would fly to Caledonia on Tuesday night to \"set up a mission\" a week after declaring a state of emergency in the islands after violence flared over proposed voting reforms opposed by indigenous Kanak people.\n\nNo further details on Macron's visit were provided.\n\nPro-independence Indigenous groups are angry about plans to permit more French residents to participate in elections that they say water down the votes of native people.\n\nRelations between the French administration and indigenous people took a turn for worse in 2021 when Paris refused to postpone an independence referendum at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic in the isolated archipelago, prompting Kanaks to boycott the poll.\n\nNew Zealanders coming off the Royal New Zealand Air Force flight reported the situation was worst in the north of the capital, Noumea, with looting and dozens of barricades on the road to the airport.\n\n\"We can hear the gunfire, we can hear the explosions, we can smell the smoke,\" Nat Jones told the New Zealand Herald in a phone call ahead of the flight.\n\n\"I'm just a bit anxious because now is the scary bit. {"uri": "8138437363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:26:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:26:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:24:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/frances-macron-to-visit-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_3eebc9fc-0ca2-51ff-82ad-fe756d35427f.html", "title": "France's Macron to visit riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will visit riot-hit New Caledonia, Paris said Tuesday, as tourists are evacuated from the Pacific territory that has suffered over a week of unrest.\n\nMacron \"will leave as soon as this evening,\" government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said, hoping to soothe tempers over his government's voting reform plans rejected by indigenous Kanaks.\n\nEarlier Tuesday an Australian Air Force transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from a small domestic airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea, as separatist roadblocks still hinder access to the international hub.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent an initial batch of planes to Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nA second C-130 was slated to land in Auckland, New Zealand around 1000 GMT, with Foreign Minister Winston Peters saying it would bring \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" and promising \"subsequent flights in coming days\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates Noumea's larger La Tontouta international airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire, while the CCI on Monday tallied 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from Noumea to La Tontouta airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\nMore from this section Sean 'Diddy' Combs apologizes after video shows him assaulting partner Forever fad: Rubik says his cube 'reminds us why we have hands' 'Incognito Market' founder arrested in New York - Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nProminent French figures including former Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who followed the New Caledonia file closely while in office, have called for delay to the constitutional change.\n\n\"You can't make progress on the Caledonia file by issuing ultimatums,\" Valls said Sunday.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nWithdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\n\"Violence cannot replace the ballot box in a democracy,\" he added.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, as well as a ban on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb-tgb/as/db", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8138807953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "15:10:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T15:10:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T15:08:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/macron-heads-to-riot-hit-new-caledonia-as-australia,-nz-evacuate-tourists/78190236", "title": "Macron heads to riot-hit New Caledonia as Australia, NZ evacuate tourists", "body": "SYDNEY/PARIS (Reuters) -French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, killing six.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand were evacuating tourists from the island as the violence left a trail of destruction with looted shops, torched cars and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food.\n\nSome 108 Australians and other tourists landed in Brisbane on two government flights, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on X. A defence force plane landed in Auckland with some 50 people on board, the New Zealand Herald reported.\n\nMore flights were expected in coming days to evacuate some 500 French and foreign tourists in total, France's High Commission in New Caledonia said.\n\nThe airport, shut since the start of the riots, remained closed for commercial flights.\n\nThe protests were sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over constitutional reform approved in Paris that would change who is allowed to take part in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nMacron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, aides said.\n\nMacron \"will discuss with all the forces in New Caledonia\", French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said. \"The objective is to ... prepare and anticipate reconstruction.\"\n\n\"The president is also going there to re-establish dialogue,\" Attal said.\n\nDIALOGUE\n\nInitial reaction showed renewing dialogue will not be an easy task, all the more so as pro-independence leaders blame the riots on Macron pushing through the electoral reform despite local opposition.\n\n\"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, wrote on X about news of Macron's visit.\n\nFrance annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No. 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one in five residents live under the poverty threshold.\n\nThe island lies some 20,000 km (12,430 miles) away from mainland France, and some 1,500 km (930 miles) east of Australia.\n\nThe opposition in Paris, former French prime ministers, and leaders of other Pacific islands have also said Macron should not go ahead with the electoral reform, which parliament in Paris adopted last Tuesday.\n\nVanuatu Foreign Minister Matai Seremaiah urged France to \"do the right thing, to resolve all outstanding decolonisation issues\" and seriously engage with Kanak leaders.\n\nEVACUATIONS\n\nAround 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nQueueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were on patrol and another 600 would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here,\" said Viro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks. He said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s and people were scared.\n\nThe situation on the ground was improving but much more needed to be done, French government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said.\n\n(Reporting by Kirsty Needham, Lucy Craymer and Jill Gralow in Sydney, Tassilo Hummel, Ingrid Melander, Augustin Turpin in Paris; writing by Ingrid Melander and Kirsty Needham; {"uri": "2024-05-363365598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:41:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:41:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T10:28:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/frances-macron-to-visit-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_b7647846-45a8-5fb9-a337-66ff7bcb1b4d.html", "title": "France's Macron to visit riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron will visit riot-hit New Caledonia, Paris said Tuesday, as tourists are evacuated from the Pacific territory that has suffered over a week of unrest.\n\nMacron \"will leave as soon as this evening,\" government spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said, hoping to soothe tempers over his government's voting reform plans rejected by indigenous Kanaks.\n\nEarlier Tuesday an Australian Air Force transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from a small domestic airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea, as separatist roadblocks still hinder access to the international hub.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent an initial batch of planes to Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nA second C-130 was slated to land in Auckland, New Zealand around 1000 GMT, with Foreign Minister Winston Peters saying it would bring \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" and promising \"subsequent flights in coming days\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates Noumea's larger La Tontouta international airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire, while the CCI on Monday tallied 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from Noumea to La Tontouta airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nProminent French figures including former Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who followed the New Caledonia file closely while in office, have called for delay to the constitutional change.\n\n\"You can't make progress on the Caledonia file by issuing ultimatums,\" Valls said Sunday.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nWithdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\n\"Violence cannot replace the ballot box in a democracy,\" he added.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, as well as a ban on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb-tgb/as/db\n\nMore from this section\n\nScottie Scheffler's Louisville court date postponed after arrest during PGA Championship Montana's attorney general said he recruited token primary opponent to increase campaign fundraising New sales workshop 'Extreme Business Growth' in Las Vegas", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8138453698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:56:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:56:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:34:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13442481/Macron-heads-New-Caledonia-Australia-New-Zealand-send-evacuation-flights.html", "title": "Macron heads to New Caledonia as Australia, New Zealand send...", "body": "By Kirsty Needham and Ingrid Melander\n\nSYDNEY/PARIS, May 21 (Reuters) - French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, leaving six dead.\n\nThe riots over electoral reform have left a trail of destruction with shops looted, cars burnt and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. The island's business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nSpeaking after a cabinet meeting, French government spokesman Prisca Thevenot said Macron would travel to \"set up a mission,\" without saying what it could entail.\n\nSome politicians have called for veteran politicians to be named as mediators, but Thevenot did not say if this was what Macron had in mind.\n\n\"Our priority is the return to calm and order,\" Thevenot said, noting the situation on the ground was improving but more needed to be done.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand have already begun evacuating nationals from New Caledonia.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nThe New Zealand Herald reported that a defence force plane had landed in Auckland with some 50 citizens evacuated from New Caledonia. Further flights were expected in the coming days.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said clearance had been received for two Australian government assisted-departure flights on Tuesday for tourists wanting to leave.\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia said the airport remained closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nMORE POLICE\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nQueueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were at work, and another 600 personnel would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThe commission asked French residents who normally live outside New Caledonia to register their details for support to return home.\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it fails,\" Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.\n\n(Reporting by Kirsty Needham, Lucy Craymer and Jill Gralow in Sydney, Tassilo Hummel, Augustin Turpin, Nicolas Delame, Ingrid Melander in Paris; Editing by Michael Perry and Christina Fincher)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": While the international airport remains closed to commercial traffic, Australia and New Zealand began evacuating nationals on government planes.\n\n\"A return to calm continues on the whole territory,\" wrote the French state representative in New Caledonia, Louis Le Franc, in a statement published Tuesday, announcing the deployment of additional security forces.\n\nSix people have been killed in violence sparked by protesters angry about a constitutional reform that would change who can participate in local elections, which pro-Independence leaders say will dilute the indigenous Kanak voice.\n\nRioting and looting have shuttered businesses, and road barricades have restricted access to food and medical care.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron noted \"progress\" towards re-establishing law and order, after a defence council Monday night, where he decided to send the army to protect public buildings.\n\nStranded tourists\n\nAustralia and New Zealand announced the first evacuation flights for tourists blocked by the unrest, as the main international airport is closed to commercial traffic at least until Thursday.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \"Australian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\".\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force plane has picked up the \"first tranche\" of passengers, according to Foreign Minister Winston Peters, who said further flights would be sent in coming days.\n\nMore than 3,000 people thought to have been stranded in New Caledonia.\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia asked French residents who normally live outside New Caledonia to register their details for support to return home.\n\nStalemate on constitutional reform\n\nFollowing the defense council, France decided to continue the state of emergency and extend the night-time curfew in place along with a ban on gatherings and the use of TikTok.\n\nThe government has asked New Caledonians to continue discussion on the constitutional reform, but loyalists say they will not negotiate until there is a return to order on the territory.\n\nThey also refuse to consider suspending the reform, as demanded by the pro-Independence parties that have been involved in the protests.\n\nWithdrawing the reform would justify \"the troublemakers, looters and rioters\", New Caledonian MP Nicolas Metzdorf, a anti-independence member of Macron's Renaissance party, said at a press conference in Noumea.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr",
