{"uri": "8139776425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:36:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:36:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T06:35:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/australia-and-new-zealand-evacuate-citizens-from-french-territory-amid-major-unrest-6386048-May2024/", "title": "Australia and New Zealand evacuate citizens from French territory amid major unrest", "body": "Six people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured.\n\nAUSTRALIA AND NEW Zealand are evacuating their citizens from the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia amid major unrest that has seen six people killed.\n\nThe Australian military has flown 115 passengers out on two flights from and a French government flight is expected to evacuate another 100 stranded passengers today.\n\nSix people have been killed, including two police officers, and hundreds have been injured during recent armed clashes, looting and arson in New Caledonia.\n\nThe deadliest unrest in four decades has been blamed on French plans to give voting rights to thousands of non-Indigenous residents. Indigenous Kanaks, who suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination under French rule and have long sought independence, fear the move will marginalise their votes.\n\nFrench authorities said the violence, which on 13 erupted May, has now eased since 1,050 troops, tactical police and national security reinforcements from Paris were deployed, including to \"highly sensitive\" areas.\n\nNevertheless, two primary schools and 300 cars in a dealership were torched in the territory's capital Noumea overnight, according to the local mayor's office.\n\nPolice have arrested more than 280 \"rioters\" in the unrest. Local prosecutors say around 400 shops and businesses have been damaged.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to land tomorrow in New Caledonia, where the unrest has raised new questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMany Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, oppose the plan to extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nKanak separatists, some masked and wielding homemade catapults, are manning multiple makeshift roadblocks, including on the main route to the international airport.\n\nEvacuations\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late yesterday from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nConroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers but he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force C-130 Hercules flew 48 passengers \"with the most pressing needs\" from Noumea to the New Zealand city of Auckland last night, the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said in a statement.\n\nA French-operated flight will bring stranded New Zealanders home via Brisbane later today, according to the statement. The New Zealand military will fly the Brisbane-Auckland leg.\n\nAround 265 New Zealanders want to leave New Caledonia.", "source": {"uri": "thejournal.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8137960494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "06:30:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T06:30:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T06:30:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/first-tourist-rescue-flight-lands-in-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_3eebc9fc-0ca2-51ff-82ad-fe756d35427f.html", "title": "First tourist rescue flight lands in riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "Smoke rises in the distance as a slogan in support of the indigenous Kanaks is seen on a bridge in Noumea, Caledonia\n\nA military transport aircraft landed in riot-hit New Caledonia to evacuate trapped tourists Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\n- Anger over vote reform - More from this section Schauffele makes the putt of his life for first major win DWP says bank account monitoring test found 60,000 benefit claimants were breaching rules East Patchogue teen files lawsuit blaming Brookhaven Town following cancer diagnosis\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb/cwl", {"uri": "8137875270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "05:21:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T05:21:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T05:21:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/australia-new-zealand-to-begin-evacuating-nationals-from-violence-wracked-new-caledonia-/7620523.html", "title": "Australia, New Zealand to begin evacuating nationals from violence-wracked New Caledonia", "body": "Australia and New Zealand are sending planes to New Caledonia to evacuate their citizens from the French Pacific territory that has been plagued by deadly violence for a week.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong posted on social media platform X that Canberra has been cleared by France for \"two government assisted flights\" to evacuate Australians and other tourists from New Caledonia Tuesday. Wong added that passengers are being prioritized according to need, and that the government will \"continue to work on further flights.\"\n\nNew Zealand Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said the government there is sending a plane to the island's capital, Noumea, to evacuate 50 of its nationals. Peters acknowledged that New Zealanders in New Caledonia \"have faced a challenging few days\" and that bringing them home \"has been an urgent priority\" for Wellington.\n\nAt least six people have been killed and hundreds more wounded since violence broke out last Monday over a bill under debate in the French parliament that would allow French-born residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to vote in local elections.\n\nLeaders of the island's pro-independence movement say the measure would dilute the voting power of the indigenous Kanak people, who have suffered under decades of discrimination.\n\nFrance's National Assembly approved the measure last week by a vote of 351-153. The bill still must be approved in a special session of both houses of parliament next month.\n\nScores of homes and businesses have been looted and burned in Noumea, prompting authorities to impose a dusk-to-dawn curfew and a ban on public gatherings. The violence has also prompted the closure of schools and businesses, as well as the island's airport. France has deployed more than 1,000 security personnel to help end the unrest, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday.\n\nAt least 270 people have been arrested.\n\nFrance agreed in 1998 to grant New Caledonia more political power and autonomy and to hold three referendums over the island's status. {"uri": "8138589654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:55:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:55:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:54:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-21/first-australian-repatriation-flight-lands-from-new-caledonia/103875830", "title": "First repatriation flights from riot-stricken New Caledonia arrives in Australia", "body": "The first Australians evacuated from riot-stricken New Caledonia have arrived back in the country but not everyone is safely home.\n\nAt least 300 Australian travellers have been stuck in or near the capital of Noumea since violent protests erupted last Monday, with some saying they have been unable to access essential medications or food.\n\nAfter several days of pressing the French government, the Federal Government received permission to send two military transport planes to pick up the first of the evacuees.\n\nThe father and son live on the Gold Coast and have worked in the nickel mining industry in New Caledonia for 20 years.\n\nGary Salmon told the ABC he hasn't seen anything like the current unrest.\n\n\"It's very unfortunate what's happening there at the moment, it's such a beautiful country,\" he said.\n\n\"I'd hate to estimate the damage over there, it won't be millions, it'll be billions.\"\n\nChris said he and his father were grateful the Australian government responded so quickly.\n\n\"Everyone was just so relieved to have that Australian support ... when Canberra kicked into gear with DFAT (Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) and they got their comms going they really did a good job as well, so really happy,\" he said.\n\nMary Hatten and her family were trying to have a holiday when the riots erupted.\n\nShe said the Australian government should have done more to warn travelers of the potential unrest.\n\n\"By Tuesday morning quite frankly the place was just in a mess, which was very sad for the locals, for the tourist industry, and I suppose to some extent for our own personal enjoyment, we were pretty much confined to the hotel,\" Ms Hatten said.\n\n\"We had a lot of discussions with local business operators and also a couple of people that we met who were expats, working there ... for four or five years and they sort of said 'it's been on the cards, things have been brewing'.\n\n\"I'm sort of thinking to myself, well, maybe the travel warning should be a lot greater.\"\n\nA similar flight carrying about 50 New Zealand citizens landed in Auckland on Tuesday night.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have contacted Australians in New Caledonia saying that French authorities will conduct further evacuation flights from the country on Wednesday local time.\n\n\"Pending further updates from French authorities, we will contact you with more details on their flight arrangements,\" the communication said.\n\nDFAT said flights could come at short notice and people needed to be preapred to leave.\n\n\"The Australian Government also stands ready to assist with further flights should French authorities grant approval.\"\n\nDFAT has also told Australians outside the capital that safe passage back to Noumea would be facilitated by French authoritie in coming days.\n\nIt said it was seeking further guidance on the arrangements.\n\nThose still waiting for a way out were frustrated.\n\nAustralian Benen Huntley had been honeymooning with his wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he told Reuters in a telephone interview.\n\nQueueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nLocal authorities said nearly 300 people had been arrested since the violence began last week.\n\nAs some Australians began arriving home, French President Emmanuel Macron was preparing to depart for New Caledonia.\n\nGovernment spokeswoman Prisca Thevenot said on Tuesday that Mr Macron \"will leave as soon as this evening\".\n\nThe announcement came after a Cabinet meeting in which Mr Macron announced he had decided to travel there himself.\n\nMs Thevenot said Mr Macron was travelling to New Caledonia to \"set up a mission\".\n\nSome politicians have called for veteran politicians to be named as mediators between opposing sides but Ms Thevenot did not say if that is what the French president had in mind.\n\nShe gave no details about how long Mr Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Ms Thevenot said.\n\nMr Macron had previously been scheduled to be in Normandy in northern France on Wednesday.\n\nHis surprise visit comes after violent riots left six people dead and hundreds of others injured.\n\nNew Caledonia, with a population of about 270,000, has been rocked by unrest sparked by French plans to impose new rules that would give tens of thousands of non-Indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nPro-independence groups say any such move would dilute the indigenous Kanak vote.\n\nFrance has sent 1,000 armed police, troops, and national security reinforcements to its overseas territory.\n\nA state of emergency, overnight curfew and a ban on TikTok has done little to quell the unrest.", "source": {"uri": We continue to pursue approvals.\"\n\nhttps://x.com/SenatorWong/status/1791951250365546794\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said about 300 Australians are currently registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), and said the government was on hand to deliver assistance.\n\n\"The Australian government is closely monitoring events in New Caledonia, and there are reports they're running out of food and commercial flights are stopped, commercial flights stopped a couple of days ago,\" he told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"We are looking into how we can provide assistance to {"uri": "2024-05-363583864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "15:52:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T15:52:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T13:53:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/macron-flying-caledonia-bid-end-135326321.html", "title": "Macron flying to New Caledonia in bid to end violent insurrection", "body": "Emmanuel Macron will fly to New Caledonia in an attempt to end the violent insurrection that has left six people dead and thousands of tourists stranded.\n\nThe French president \"will go there tonight\", according to a spokesman, adding that a \"return to calm is starting to arrive\" in the Pacific territory.\n\nMr Macron's visit comes as an Australian Air Force transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from a small domestic airport in New Caledonia's capital Noumea, as separatist roadblocks continued to hinder access to the main international airport - which is closed to commercial flights until at least Saturday.\n\nMore than 3,000 people are estimated to have been stranded by a week of unrest that has shuttered the Pacific archipelago's main international airport.\n\nAustralia has estimated at least 300 of its nationals have registered for rescue.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian foreign minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force plane has also been dispatched to pick up about \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\", according to foreign minister Winston Peters.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, as well as a ban on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nThe French government last week sent 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of some parts of Noumea.\n\nMr Macron will launch a special \"mission\" aimed at reducing boiling tensions over a voting reform rejected by indigenous Kanaks, who make up 41 per cent of the archipelago's 270,000-strong population.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nPro-independence Kanaks say the change is a form of colonisation by stealth. Those who support it point out that New Caledonia has now rejected independence three times in successive referendums, the latest in 2021, and that 20 per cent of the population are unable to vote despite paying taxes and contributing to the local economy.\n\nMr Macron has pledged to validate the contested electoral reform \"before the end of June\" by senators and deputies during a special congress but \"the executive is continuing ... to build a political solution for the territory\", said a spokesman.\n\nProminent French figures including former prime minister Manuel Valls, who followed the New Caledonia dossier closely while in office, have called for delay to the constitutional change.\n\n\"You can't make progress on the Caledonia file by issuing ultimatums,\" Mr Valls said on Sunday.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through. Withdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\n\"Violence cannot replace the ballot box in a democracy,\" he added.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s. But almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8138477746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:49:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:49:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:49:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/macron-heads-to-new-caledonia-as-australia-new-zealand-send-evacuation-flights/article_e40757f5-d3b7-58a0-b5bb-898576e69ea5.html", "title": "Macron heads to New Caledonia as Australia, New Zealand send evacuation flights", "body": "By Kirsty Needham and Ingrid Melander\n\nSYDNEY/PARIS (Reuters) -French President Emmanuel Macron will travel to the Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday, a government spokesperson said, just over a week after riots erupted in the French overseas territory, leaving six dead.\n\nThe riots over electoral reform have left a trail of destruction with shops looted, cars burnt and road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. The island's business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nSpeaking after a cabinet meeting, French government spokesman Prisca Thevenot said Macron would travel to \"set up a mission,\" without saying what it could entail.\n\nSome politicians have called for veteran politicians to be named as mediators, but Thevenot did not say if this was what Macron had in mind.\n\n\"Our priority is the return to calm and order,\" Thevenot said, noting the situation on the ground was improving but more needed to be done.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand have already begun evacuating nationals from New Caledonia.\n\nAround 3,200 people are waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia after commercial flights were cancelled last week due to the unrest, the local government has said.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\nThe New Zealand Herald reported that a defence force plane had landed in Auckland with some 50 citizens evacuated from New Caledonia. Further flights were expected in the coming days.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said clearance had been received for two Australian government assisted-departure flights on Tuesday for tourists wanting to leave.\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia said the airport remained closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nMORE POLICE\n\nAustralian officials said passengers were being prioritised based on need. Those left behind were frustrated, said Australian Benen Huntley, honeymooning with wife Emily.\n\n\"My wife is quite upset, we just want to get home,\" he said in a telephone interview.\n\n\"We opened our hotel door this morning and you could just see an enormous billow of smoke coming off a building in the distance.\"\n\nQueueing to buy bread, the Adelaide couple had seen dozens of gendarmes guarding a petrol station.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were at work, and another 600 personnel would be added, France's High Commission said.\n\nThe commission asked French residents who normally live outside New Caledonia to register their details for support to return home.\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections. Local leaders fear the change will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it fails,\" Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.\n\n(Reporting by Kirsty Needham, Lucy Craymer and Jill Gralow in Sydney, Tassilo Hummel, Augustin Turpin, Nicolas Delame, Ingrid Melander in Paris; Editing by Michael Perry and Christina Fincher)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb/cwl\n\nMore from this section\n\nMontana's attorney general said he recruited token primary opponent to increase campaign fundraising Scientology Network's 'Voices for Humanity' Brings Hope Back to Paradise With David Lopez Meet a Scientologist Gets Fired up With including two gendarmes - and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nFor decades, tensions have flared between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonisers and colonists who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe latest unrest erupted on 13 May as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nOpponents fear the measure will benefit pro-French politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nDestruction in Noum\u00e9a\n\nLast Wednesday, French authorities declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Noum\u00e9a.\n\n\"Faced with the outbreak of violence, the priority is the return of order to allow dialogue to resume in New Caledonia,\" Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, said. \"We are clear: Much remains to be done before a return to normal. The government is fully mobilised.\"\n\nShe gave no details about how long Macron will stay or who he will meet.\n\nBut the French president will see first hand the destruction that has turned parts of Noum\u00e9a into no-go zones, with buildings torched, shops pillaged and barricades erected both by pro-independence supporters - some armed - and people banding together to protect livelihoods and homes.\n\nWith police given emergency powers and a 6pm to 6am curfew in effect, the authorities say security forces are starting to contain unrest.\n\nThey announced further 22 arrests on Tuesday, {"uri": "8136116253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-20", "time": "04:53:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-20T04:53:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-20T04:52:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/may/20/new-caledonia-protests-evacuation-flights-australian-nz-tourists-noumea-stranded-state-of-emergency", "title": "Evacuation flights unable to reach tourists stranded in New Caledonia amid unrest", "body": "Hundreds of Australian and New Zealand travellers are stuck in the French Pacific territory where protests and violence are preventing access to the airport\n\nHundreds of Australian and New Zealand tourists stranded in New Caledonia amid deadly unrest are anxiously waiting on French authorities to allow air travel out of the territory, as their governments stand by to bring them home.\n\nFrench security forces are working to retake control of the highway to the international airport in New Caledonia, shuttered because of violent unrest in the French Pacific territory.\n\nFrance's top official in the territory, Louis Le Franc, said on Sunday evening a police operation to regain control of the road to the airport would take several days. Gendarmes had dismantled 76 roadblocks.\n\nBut pro-independence forces on Monday vowed to maintain roadblocks that have paralysed parts of the territory.\n\nThe airport, with routes to Australia, Singapore, New Zealand and other destinations, closed on Tuesday as protests against voting reforms opposed by pro-independence supporters degenerated into widespread violence, leaving a vast trail of destruction. Six people have been killed and hundreds injured.\n\nA reopening of the Noum\u00e9a-La Tontouta airport could allow stranded tourists to escape from the island where armed clashes, arson and looting has prompted France to impose a state of emergency.\n\nRoughly 3,000 tourists are thought to be marooned in New Caledonia, according to AFP, including more than 300 Australians and nearly 250 New Zealanders.\n\nAustralia's prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said the situation in New Caledonia was \"deeply concerning\".\n\nAfter a night when there was fire and looting, Albanese told ABC radio on Monday that Australia had been seeking approval from French authorities for two days to send an evacuation flight to New Caledonia to pick up tourists stranded in hotels.\n\n\"We continue to pursue approvals because the Australian defence force is ready to fly when it's permitted to do so,\" Albanese said.\n\nThe foreign ministers of Australia and New Zealand said they were seeking French permission to fly out their nationals.\n\n\"French authorities advise the situation on the ground is preventing flights. We continue to pursue approvals,\" the Australian minister, Penny Wong, posted on X.\n\nThe New Zealand minister, Winston Peters, said New Zealand authorities had completed preparations for defence force aircraft to bring home nationals while commercial services were grounded.\n\n\"We are ready to fly, and await approval from French authorities as to when our flights are safe to proceed,\" Peters posted on X.\n\n\"Ever since the security situation in New Caledonia deteriorated earlier this week, the safety of New Zealanders there has been an urgent priority for us.\"\n\nTourists have described sheltering in hotels and growing concerns over food supplies, while residents have spoken of their desperate attempts to acquire food and fuel.\n\nNew Zealander Barbara Graham, who is in the capital researching towards her PhD, told news outlet Newshub she could see \"fires burning out of control [and] black smoke billowing out of the city\" from her accommodation.\n\nMultiple shops had been ransacked, she said.\n\n\"The shops that are open, that I've seen, are getting really bare. Shops have been looted and burnt out.\"\n\nAustralian Tonia Scholes spoke to the Project program on Sunday, and said Noumea \"was like a war zone\".\n\n\"There's burnt cars, there's barricades, there's remnants of fires, there's people standing on street corners drinking hard liquor and having what almost seems like a party,\" she said.\n\nShe said local residents in the neighbourhood where she was staying with friends had taken security into their own hands.\n\n\"They have all banded together to protect what is theirs and they have 24-hour watches, they walk the streets with big torches. That's actually our neighbours protecting us, which is just amazing that they've embraced us in their neighbourhood, a bunch of Australian girls here for a week and they're just like 'don't worry we've got your back'.\"\n\nBut Scholes said getting solid information from the Australian government about evacuation options had been difficult.\n\n\"We're just hoping and waiting for a phone call to say we've got some way of getting you out.\"\n\nBrisbane woman Sophie Jones Bradshaw flew to New Caledonia - to where she had travelled for more than 20 years - for work on 11 May, just before the outbreak of rioting. She was now separated from her family, with no idea when they would be reunited.\n\n\"It's getting really hard to see my son every day on the camera,\" Jones Bradshaw told AAP.\n\n\"I'm crying because he wants me to go home - I'm telling him 'oh just one more sleep, one more sleep', but I don't know.\"\n\nJones Bradshaw said the Caledonian capital was \"desolation, it's chaos - it's frightening\". \"It feels like a no man's land.\"\n\nShe said half of Noumea has been burnt, with homes and businesses razed across the city.\n\n\"You have to go further and further out to find a shop that hasn't been burned or is not closed.\n\n\"In the middle of all that, you can still hear explosions every now and then. I feel exhausted and scared like any Caledonian.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ben_doherty@theguardian.com", "name": "Ben {"uri": "2024-05-363424934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "13:31:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T13:31:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T13:21:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/new-caledonia-where-unrest-french-territory-3066416", "title": "Where New Caledonia is and why there's unrest in the French territory", "body": "Emmanuel Macron is heading to the Pacific overseas territory after riots claimed the lives of six people and forced hundred to evacuate\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is heading to the Pacific islands of New Caledonia after days of riots have left six dead, hundreds injured and forced tourists to evacuate.\n\nUnrest began in New Caledonia, a French overseas territory, last week after electoral changes were voted through by the French government in Paris.\n\nFrance declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency last Wednesday and sent more than 1,000 gendarmes and police to the area, another 600 personnel are on their way to deal with the violence.\n\nNow military aircraft from Australia and New Zealand have flown to the capital Noumea to airlift stranded foreign nationals and tourists on the islands.\n\nThe streets are littered with burnt out vehicles and businesses, while shops have been looted and the main airport closed to commercial flights as demonstrators have set up blockades on the roads.\n\nNew Caledonia is a group of islands between Australia and New Zealand in the Pacific ocean, west of Fiji and south of Vanuatu, with a population of around 270,000.\n\nIt is made up of the main island, known as Grande Terre, the Loyalty Islands and the Chesterfield Islands, the Belep archipelago, the Isle of Pines and a few remote islets.\n\nBritish explorer James Cook was the first European to discover the islands in 1774, naming it New Caledonia because the north-east of the main island reminded him of Scotland.\n\nIn 1853, Napolean III took possession of the islands and it became a French penal colony.\n\nThen in 1946 it was declared a French overseas territory, and French citizenship was granted to all New Caledonians, regardless of ethnicity, from 1953.\n\nBetween 1976 and 1988, there was a period of unrest known as \"the Events\" as the French government clashed with the indigenous Kanak people's independence movement.\n\nStability was resumed with the Matignon Agreements in 1988, and the Noumea Accord in 1998 lay the foundations for a 20-year transition transferring more power to the local government.\n\nThe latest uprising, which began on 13 May, was sparked by anger among the Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France, which would change who is allowed to participate in elections.\n\nLocal leaders fear the changes will dilute the Kanak vote as the new amendment allows those who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years to get a vote.\n\nPreviously, European arrivals from France post-1998 were excluded from the vote.\n\nOpponents claim the measure will benefit pro-France politicians in New Caledonia and further marginalise Kanaks, who once suffered from strict segregation policies and widespread discrimination.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" he said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks.\n\n\"We need strong actions [from the government] to calm the situation ... this is a political, not a security issue,\" said Dominique Fochi, secretary general of the pro-independence Caledonian Union.\n\nFrench Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.\n\nWhile French government spokesman Prisca Thevenot said Mr Macron was travelling to the islands to \"set up a mission\" and the \"priority is New Caledonia", "body": "About 100 more Australians stranded in New Caledonia following deadly riots are set to be repatriated, meaning more than half the people who want to leave the French territory will have gotten home.\n\nA French plane will arrive in Brisbane on Wednesday after 84 Australians and 24 other nationals were repatriated to the Queensland capital on Tuesday.\n\nThere are about 500 Australians in New Caledonia and some 300 in total had registered their interest in coming home with the Department of Foreign Affairs, Pacific Minister Pat Conroy said.\n\n\"That number may move slightly but we think approximately 100 Australians will be on that flight,\" he told ABC TV on Wednesday.\n\nAustralia would continue to work with the French government on further flights, Mr Conroy said.\n\n\"The primary plan is more French flights but as I've indicated publicly, we do have contingency plans and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that,\" he said.\n\nThose on board the first two flights were filled with relief after days of failing to find a way off the island, said Fadi Chemali who was on the first plane to reach Australia.\n\n\"Everyone clapped once we landed, we were all just so happy,\" he told AAP shortly after landing in Brisbane.\n\nMr Chemali had been holidaying with his wife and daughter for a week before rioting erupted and spent eight days scrambling to find a way home.\n\n\"I didn't see any of the violence up close but we heard a lot, including gunshots from where we were, it has been fairly intense.\"\n\nAt least six people have died in the territory and hundreds have been injured since violence broke out last Monday.\n\nFrench troops are trying to stem further unrest, with buildings razed, shops looted and roads barricaded.\n\nAustralia's Consul-General in New Caledonia, Annelise Young, posted on X that her team had been working round the clock with officials in Canberra and Paris and closely with French authorities to ensure safe passage for Australian tourists.\n\nNew rules changing who is allowed to participate in the nation's elections have been slammed by the Indigenous Kanaks, who fear their vote will be diluted by thousands of French nationals who have moved to the island.\n\nAbout 270 rioters have been arrested and a 12-hour curfew imposed from 6pm to 6am.\n\nFrance has sent over 1000 security personnel, with hundreds more to join, in a bid to quell the unrest.\n\nThe reopening of the international airport for commercial flights will be reassessed on Thursday.\n\nAustralia has We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nTROUBLE IN THE TERRITORY Smoke rises in the distance as a burnt vehicle and roadblock barricades are seen on a road near the Montravel area of Noumea, capital of France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, on May 21, 2024. AFP PHOTO\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic.\"\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCatapults\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-Indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left at least six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said on Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said over the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometer (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock on Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\nAnger over vote reform\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people.\"\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there: we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n'Madness'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire.\"\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a nighttime curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is The unrest has raised new questions about Mr Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nAustralian Pacific minister Pat Conroy said 84 of the passengers who were flown on two Royal Australian Airforce C-130 Hercules late on Tuesday from the capital Noumea to the Australian east coast city of Brisbane were Australian citizens.\n\nMr Conroy did not say what nationalities were among the remaining 31 passengers. But he said Australia had reciprocal arrangements with Canada and Japan to help their citizens in crises.\n\nMore than 200 other Australians were registered with Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs to leave the South Pacific territory, where a 12-day state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We've prioritised the elderly, the pregnant and the most vulnerable,\" Mr Conroy told Nine Network television.\n\n\"We'll continue to work with the French government to make sure we get every Australian out of New Caledonia who does want to leave,\" Mr Conroy added.\n\nMr Conroy said he had been advised France was planning more flights to Brisbane on Wednesday.\n\n\"The French have indicated they intend to continue repatriating foreign nationals, particularly tourists, so the primary plan is more French flights, but ... we do have contingency plans, and we do have planes on standby should there be an issue with that course of action,\" Mr Conroy later told the ABC.\n\n\"A French {"uri": "8137945869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "06:19:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T06:19:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T06:19:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/first-tourist-rescue-flight-lands-in-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/", "title": "First tourist rescue flight lands in riot-scarred New Caledonia | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "A military transport aircraft landed in riot-hit New Caledonia to evacuate trapped tourists Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb/cwl\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-362921078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "06:20:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T06:20:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T05:29:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.nbcrightnow.com/national/first-tourist-rescue-flight-lands-in-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_e2959a32-74be-548f-9a76-5c395f99e847.html", "title": "First tourist rescue flight lands in riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "A military transport aircraft landed in riot-hit New Caledonia to evacuate trapped tourists Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb/cwl\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8138324109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "10:19:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T10:19:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T10:19:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/first-tourists-evacuated-from-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_bd5f0c67-1ac8-5ca0-aa2b-34f139756f65.html", "title": "First tourists evacuated from riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "A military transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from riot-hit New Caledonia Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates the airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire.\n\nThe CCI on Monday reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans of TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be {"uri": "8137840242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "04:53:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T04:53:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T04:52:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/australasia/article/3263451/australia-new-zealand-scramble-evacuate-tourists-riot-hit-new-caledonia", "title": "Australia, New Zealand scramble to evacuate tourists from riot-hit New Caledonia", "body": "New Caledonia\u2019s main airport remains closed to commercial flights, stranding thousands amid a week of deadly riots\n\nSix people have been killed and the unrest has left a trail of burnt-out cars and shops, with road barricades restricting access to medicine and food\n\nAustralia and New Zealand said they will send government planes to New Caledonia on Tuesday to evacuate nationals from the French territory which has experienced a week of deadly riots, sparked by electoral changes by the French government in Paris.\n\nFrance\u2019s High Commission in New Caledonia said on Tuesday the airport remains closed for commercial flights, and it will deploy the military to protect public buildings.\n\nThere were around 3,200 people waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia as commercial flights were cancelled due to the unrest that broke out last week, the local government has said.\n\nOver 1,000 gendarmes and police from France were at work, and another 600 personnel would be added in coming hours, France\u2019s High Commission said.\n\nRoads in Noumea are being cleared, with bulldozers removing burnt out car carcasses and debris, it added.\n\nSix people have been killed and the unrest has left a trail of burnt businesses and cars and looted shops, with road barricades restricting access to medicine and food. The business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nNew Zealand, French and Australian foreign ministers held a call on Monday evening, after New Zealand and Australia said they were waiting for clearance from French authorities to send defence aircraft to evacuate tourists.\n\nA meeting of France\u2019s defence council later agreed for arrangements to allow tourists to return home.\n\n\u201cNew Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days \u2013 and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\u201d New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\u201cWe want to acknowledge the support of relevant authorities, both in Paris and Noum\u00e9a, in facilitating this flight,\u201d he added. Further flights will be sent in coming days, he added.\n\nAustralia\u2019s Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a social media post on Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \u201cAustralian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\u201d.\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections, which local leaders fear will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\u201cWe are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\u201d Xulue said in a video interview.\n\nThree of six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France\u2019s High Commission previously said.\n\n\u201cThe French government doesn\u2019t know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it\u2019s fail,\u201d Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before {"uri": "8138064933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "07:43:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T07:43:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T07:42:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/21/france-to-deploy-more-troops-to-troubled-pacific-territory-of-new-caledonia", "title": "France to deploy more troops to troubled Pacific territory of New Caledonia", "body": "Noumea's international airport remains closed as Australia and New Zealand say they will evacuate tourists on military aircraft.\n\nHundreds more security personnel will join the 1,500 reinforcements already on the ground in New Caledonia after the worst unrest in the French Pacific territory in more than 30 years.\n\nThe High Commission of New Caledonia, which represents the French state in the territory, said on Tuesday that 600 personnel would be deployed in the coming hours to join those already sent from France.\n\n\"The return to calm continues throughout the territory,\" it said in a statement, but added that the airport in the capital, Noumea, would remain closed to commercial flights, with the situation to be reviewed on Thursday.\n\nThe government has said about 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia when flights were cancelled last week when violence broke out over French plans to amend voting laws to allow more recent arrivals to vote in provincial elections.\n\nSix people were killed after makeshift blockades were set up on Noumea's streets, cars and businesses set on fire and shops looted. The high commission said efforts were under way to clear the remaining barriers and remove the burned-out vehicles and other debris.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand, meanwhile, sent their first military planes to New Caledonia to evacuate their nationals.\n\nAn Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft landed at Noumea's Magenta airport, which usually handles domestic traffic, on Tuesday afternoon, the AFP news agency reported.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand's Foreign Minister Winston Peters, meanwhile, said the first military aircraft would repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland. He said more flights were scheduled for the coming days.\n\nThe civil disturbances are the worst in the territory of some 270,000 people since the 1980s and reflect concerns among the Indigenous Kanak community, who make up about 40 percent of the population, that changes to the electoral system will dilute their vote and political influence.\n\nThe voting system for provincial elections was established in the 1998 Noumea Accord, a result of the previous unrest, and excluded later European arrivals from France. Under the new constitutional amendment, those who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years will get a vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanak amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told the Reuters news agency in a video interview.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanak and were shot by armed civilians. There have also been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission said previously.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had dismantled 76 barricades set up along the 60km (40-mile) road from Noumea to the international airport, but AFP reported some had been rebuilt.\n\nOne was being manned by a group of masked Kanak people, some of whom were carrying home-made catapults.\n\nA masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley told AFP that the proposed voting reform meant \"the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there - we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he said.", from the indigenous Kanak population who have long sought independence from Paris.\n\nSpeaking this Tuesday, government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot announced, \"[Macron] will go there tonight,\" following a cabinet meeting where the president said he had decided to make the more than 33,000-kilometere round trip himself to the archipelago east of Australia.\n\nIn just over a week, at least six people have been killed - including two gendarmes - and hundreds of others injured in New Caledonia amid armed clashes, looting and arson, raising questions about Macron's handling of France's colonial legacy.\n\nFor decades, tensions have flared between indigenous Kanaks who seek independence for the archipelago of 270,000 people, and descendants of colonisers and colonists who want to remain part of France.\n\nThe latest unrest erupted on 13 May as the French legislature in Paris debated amending the French Constitution to make changes to New Caledonia voter lists.\n\nLast Wednesday, French authorities declared a 12-day minimum state of emergency on the island and rushed in 1,000 reinforcements to bolster security forces that lost control of parts of the capital, Than 300 Australians Await Evacuation As Airport Remains Shut", "body": "More than 300 Australians were awaiting evacuation in the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia, as security forces were deployed to regain control of the highway to the Noum\u00e9a-La Tontouta international airport, which was shut down after violent unrest erupted a week ago.\n\nFrench official, Louis Le Franc, on Sunday, stated that a police operation planned to take control of the highway connecting the Noum\u00e9a Airport would take several days, even as the pro-independence forces in Caledonia vowed to continue the roadblocks that have paralyzed territory, The Guardian reported.\n\nAustralia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said they have been waiting for clearance from French authorities to send flights to New Caledonia so that the tourists stranded in hotels could be evacuated.\n\n\"We continue to pursue approvals because the Australian defense force is ready to fly when it's permitted to do so,\" he said.\n\nThe foreign ministers of Australia and New Zealand too said they were seeking French permission to fly out their nationals.\n\n\"French authorities advise the situation on the ground is preventing flights,\" the Australian minister, Penny Wong, posted on X. \"We continue to pursue approvals.\"\n\nWong said that she and New Zealand's foreign minister, Winston Peters, had spoken with their French counterpart, St\u00e9phane S\u00e9journ\u00e9, \"to convey our condolences, express our gratitude for French efforts to restore calm, and reiterate our request for access.\"\n\nPeters said New Zealand was ready to fly defense aircraft to bring home nationals, as commercial services have been grounded. Around 250 New Zealanders are reportedly stranded in Caledonia.\n\nQantas Airways said they have been in contact with Noumea Airport authorities since the shut down. \"We're in close contact with DFAT [The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade] and Noumea Airport authorities and preparing to respond quickly to help get people to their destinations when it reopens. {"uri": "8139536073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:02:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:02:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:01:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2945985-macrons-arrival-in-new-caledonia-amid-worst-riots-in-40-years", "title": "Macron's Arrival in New Caledonia Amid Worst Riots in 40 Years | Law-Order", "body": "Amid severe riots in New Caledonia, French President Emmanuel Macron's upcoming visit aims to address the chaos. Over 1,000 security reinforcements have been deployed, with barricades being cleared and arrests made. Pro-independence groups seek electoral reform, fearing dilution of indigenous Kanak votes.\n\nProtesters and a thousand French police reinforcements were playing a \"game of cat and mouse\" in New Caledonia, ahead of the arrival of France's President Emmanuel Macron after the worst riots in 40 years in the French territory, pro-independence groups said on Wednesday.\n\nFrance's High Commission said Macron would be accompanied by ministers for defence and interior for Thursday's talks, and some 100 members of the GIGN or elite tactical response group were deployed in New Caledonia. More than 1,000 security reinforcements from France were on the ground, some 90 barricades had been cleared from roads, and the night had been calmer despite two fires in Noumea, the high commission said on Wednesday. Some 20 arrests were made yesterday, with 280 rioters arrested in the past week.\n\nJimmy Naouna, from the Front de Liberation Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) of New Caledonia, said the pro-independence political party had called for protesters to remove road blocks, which are restricting movement and supply of food in the capital Noumea, yet they continue to appear overnight. \"The police forces go around clearing these barricades but the youth right after that, they put them up again, so its almost a cat and mouse game. We will see what happens when Macron gets here,\" he told Reuters in an interview.\n\nFLNKS, the party of the New Caledonia government's president Louis Mapou, want Paris to scrap an electoral reform that sparked riots a week ago that have killed six. Some leaders fear the change will dilute the vote of indigenous Kanak, who make up 40% of the population. \"We are expecting if he travels to Kanaky he will make some strong announcement that he is withdrawing this electoral bill, but if he is just coming here as a provocation that might just turn bad,\" Naouna said, using the island's indigenous name.\n\nMacron will meet elected officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island, his aides said. The island is more than 16,000 km (10,000 miles) from mainland France, and some 1,500 km (930 miles) east of Australia.\n\nOver a hundred foreign tourists were evacuated on Australian and New Zealand government chartered flights on Tuesday, as New Caledonia's airport remains closed to commercial flights. The U.S. State Department said one U.S. citizen was among those evacuated to Brisbane. Australia's Minister for the Pacific Pat Conroy said 84 Australians were evacuated, and 200 more Australians who are seeking to leave remain in New Caledonia.\n\nThe French government is organising Wednesday's evacuation flights to Australia, he said. Australian diplomats are \"working very hard to make sure as many Australians as possible are on those flights\", he added. France annexed New Caledonia in 1853 and gave the colony the status of overseas territory in 1946. New Caledonia is the world's No. 3 nickel miner but the sector is in crisis and one-in-five residents live below the poverty threshold.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is
