{"uri": "8138212364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "09:15:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T09:15:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T09:15:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.suchtv.pk/world/item/126503-france-to-deploy-more-troops-to-troubled-pacific-territory-of-new-caledonia.html", "title": "France to deploy more troops to troubled Pacific territory of New Caledonia - SUCH TV", "body": "Hundreds more security personnel will join the 1,500 reinforcements already on the ground in New Caledonia after the worst unrest in the French Pacific territory in more than 30 years.\n\nThe High Commission of New Caledonia, which represents the French state in the territory, said on Tuesday that 600 personnel would be deployed in the coming hours to join those already sent from France.\n\n\"The return to calm continues throughout the territory,\" it said in a statement, but added that the airport in the capital, Noumea, would remain closed to commercial flights, with the situation to be reviewed on Thursday.\n\nThe government has said about 3,200 people were waiting to leave or enter New Caledonia when flights were cancelled last week when violence broke out over French plans to amend voting laws to allow more recent arrivals to vote in provincial elections.\n\nSix people were killed after makeshift blockades were set up on Noumea's streets, cars and businesses set on fire and shops looted. The high commission said efforts were under way to clear the remaining barriers and remove the burned-out vehicles and other debris.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand, meanwhile, sent their first military planes to New Caledonia to evacuate their nationals.\n\nAn Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft landed at Noumea's Magenta airport, which usually handles domestic traffic, on Tuesday afternoon, the AFP news agency reported.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand's Foreign Minister Winston Peters, meanwhile, said the first military aircraft would repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland. He said more flights were scheduled for the coming days.\n\nThe civil disturbances are the worst in the territory of some 270,000 people since the 1980s and reflect concerns among the Indigenous Kanak community, who make up about 40 percent of the population, that changes to the electoral system will dilute their vote and political influence.\n\nThe voting system for provincial elections was established in the 1998 Noumea Accord, a result of the previous unrest, and excluded later European arrivals from France. Under the new constitutional amendment, those who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years will get a vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanak amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told the Reuters news agency in a video interview.\n\nThree of the six people killed in the unrest were young Kanak and were shot by armed civilians. There have also been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission said previously.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had dismantled 76 barricades set up along the 60km (40-mile) road from Noumea to the international airport, but AFP reported some had been rebuilt.\n\nOne was being manned by a group of masked Kanak people, some of whom were carrying home-made catapults.\n\nA masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley told AFP that the proposed voting reform meant \"the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there - we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he said.", We have received communication that French authorities would be coordinating the evacuation of all tourists that remain in New Caledonia,\" she said.\n\n\"We don't know when we will be able to get home.\n\n\"There are thousands of tourists from all over the world and if we are now being included as part of that group stranded here, it could take ages for us to get home.\"\n\nPlesa said she had received little communication from Australian officials.\n\n\"We are still stuck here and in as much danger today as yesterday,\" she said.\n\n\"We just want to know when we'll get our opportunity to come home.\n\n\"We have been told to stay put within our hotels, because we could get that call at any time.\n\n\"It's just another day in limbo. population accounts for around 40 per cent of New Caledonia's 270,000 total inhabitants, and many have called for independence from France.\n\nThree referendums on the topic have been held since 2018, with the pro-independence vote falling short on each occasion - although it boycotted the most recent poll in 2021.\n\nA state of emergency in response to the unrest was declared last week, and France {"uri": "2024-05-363241589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:02:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:02:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T09:35:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/first-tourists-evacuated-from-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_b7647846-45a8-5fb9-a337-66ff7bcb1b4d.html", "title": "First tourists evacuated from riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "A military transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from riot-hit New Caledonia Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates the airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire.\n\nThe CCI on Monday reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans of TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb-tgb/as/yad\n\nMore from this section\n\nTugboats escort ship that caused deadly Baltimore bridge collapse back to port Scientology Network's {"uri": "8138329586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "10:23:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T10:23:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T10:22:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/first-tourists-evacuated-from-riot-scarred-new-caledonia/article_3eebc9fc-0ca2-51ff-82ad-fe756d35427f.html", "title": "First tourists evacuated from riot-scarred New Caledonia", "body": "A military transport aircraft evacuated trapped tourists from riot-hit New Caledonia Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nThe first transport with evacuees landed in Brisbane in eastern Australia around 7:00 pm (0900 GMT) Tuesday.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nCharles Roger, director of New Caledonia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) which operates the airport, told AFP there would be no commercial flights there until Saturday morning.\n\n- Catapults -\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nThe unrest has left six people dead, including two police, and hundreds injured.\n\nLocal prosecutors said Tuesday that around 400 shops and businesses had been damaged, many of them by fire.\n\nThe CCI on Monday reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nThe French authorities in New Caledonia said police had so far arrested nearly 270 \"rioters\".\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nMore from this section Slideshow: Highlights from the PGA Championship final round in Louisville Klopp hails 'superpower' fans in emotional Liverpool farewell 22 Kids and Counting's Radford family celebrate surprise baby news: 'Can't wait to meet you'\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport.\n\n- Anger over vote reform -\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name, Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\n- 'Madness' -\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name, Sylvie.\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans of TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/arb-tgb/as/yad", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, {"uri": "8138008425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "07:06:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T07:06:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T07:05:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/first-tourist-rescue-flight-lands-in-riot-sca-1827066.html", "title": "First Tourist Rescue Flight Lands In Riot-scarred New Caledonia - UrduPoint", "body": "Noumea, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 21st May, 2024) A military transport aircraft landed in riot-hit New Caledonia to evacuate trapped tourists Tuesday, the first rescue flight since looting, arson and deadly gunfire enveloped the French Pacific territory eight days ago.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand are sending an initial batch of planes to New Caledonia's domestic Noumea Magenta airport, where AFP correspondents saw the first Australian C-130 Hercules aircraft land and several coaches waiting.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need. We continue to work on further flights,\" Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said on social media, announcing two initial flights.\n\nNew Zealand is sending one military plane to repatriate \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" to Auckland, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said, describing the situation in New Caledonia as \"dynamic\".\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester said he and his wife Tiffany were \"ecstatic\" to hear evacuation flights had begun after being stuck in a barricaded resort for a week.\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since May 13, when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nTwenty-one supermarkets have been able to reopen and gradually restock, the French high commission said Tuesday.\n\nFrench forces were slowly restoring calm across the territory, clearing burned-out vehicles from roads, and deploying troops to protect public buildings, authorities said.\n\nFrench officials said at the weekend that security forces had destroyed 76 roadblocks along the critical 60-kilometre (40-mile) road from the capital Noumea to La Tontouta International Airport.\n\nBut AFP journalists said many had quickly been rebuilt by Kanak militants.\n\nKanaks with scarfs over their faces, some armed with homemade catapults, were still manning a roadblock Tuesday on the road to the international airport, which is closed to commercial flights until at least Thursday.\n\nOne of several militants on the roadblock, a masked 25-year-old with sunglasses who gave only his first name Stanley, said the proposed voting reform \"means the elimination of the Kanak people\".\n\n\"That's what they don't understand over there -- we are already in the minority in our own home,\" he told AFP.\n\nAnother masked man, a 34-year-old who also divulged only his first name, Simon, said they were letting drivers pass through the roadblock, and some people were giving them bread and water.\n\n\"It's calm, the regulars already know us on the barricades,\" he said.\n\nIndigenous Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population, say the latest voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nBut more recent arrivals to the islands say they are being deprived of their right to take part in local elections.\n\nThe new law would extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nIn the Noumea beachside suburb of Magenta, AFP journalists saw abandoned roadblocks and locals clearing up the streets.\n\n\"I am so happy to see this and for the madness to end,\" said one tearful resident who gave only her first name Sylvie.\n\nThe New Caledonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has reported \"catastrophic\" economic damage from the unrest, with 150 businesses \"looted and set on fire\".\n\nFrance is considering extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, the sale of alcohol, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": {"uri": "8138479090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "11:51:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T11:51:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T11:50:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.newdelhitimes.com/australia-new-zealand-begin-evacuating-nationals-from-violence-wracked-new-caledonia/", "title": "Australia, New Zealand begin evacuating nationals from violence-wracked New Caledonia - New Delhi Times - India's Only International Newspaper - Empowering Global Vision, Empathizing with India", "body": "The first plane sent to evacuate stranded tourists from New Caledonia landed Tuesday at the capital Noumea.\n\nAn Australian military transport plane landed at the city's international airport to begin evacuating 300 Australian tourists who have been unable to leave since riots broke out in the French Pacific territory a week ago.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong posted on the social media platform X late Monday that Canberra has been cleared by France for \"two government assisted flights\" to evacuate Australians and other tourists from the archipelago. Wong added that passengers are being prioritized according to need, and that the government will \"continue to work on further flights.\"\n\nNew Zealand Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters said the government there is sending a plane to the island's capital, Noumea, to evacuate 50 of its nationals. Peters acknowledged that New Zealanders in New Caledonia \"have faced a challenging few days\" and that bringing them home \"has been an urgent priority\" for Wellington.\n\nAt least six people have been killed and hundreds more wounded since violence broke out last Monday over a bill under debate in the French parliament that would allow French-born residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years to vote in local elections.\n\nLeaders of the island's pro-independence movement say the measure would dilute the voting power of the indigenous Kanak people, who have suffered under decades of discrimination.\n\nFrance's National Assembly approved the measure last week by a vote of 351-153. The bill still must be approved in a special session of both houses of parliament next month.\n\nScores of homes and businesses have been looted and burned in Noumea, prompting authorities to impose a dusk-to-dawn curfew and a ban on public gatherings. The violence has also prompted the closure of schools and businesses, as well as the island's airport, which left thousands of tourists unable to leave.\n\nGroups of Kanak protesters have set up roadblocks leading in and out of Noumea which has prevented deliveries of food and medicine to citizens and tourists trapped in their homes and resorts.\n\nFrance has deployed more than 1,000 security personnel to help end the unrest, with hundreds more due to arrive Tuesday.\n\nAt least 270 people have been arrested.\n\nFrance agreed in 1998 to grant New Caledonia more political power and autonomy and to hold three referendums over the island's status. Voters have rejected independence in all three referendums.\n\nCredit : Voice of America (VOA), Photo Credit : Associated Press (AP)", "source": {"uri": "newdelhitimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8138879114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "15:55:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T15:55:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T15:55:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/french-president-emmanuel-macron-visit-144230717.html", "title": "French President Emmanuel Macron to visit troubled New Caledonia", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron is set to travel to the French overseas territory of New Caledonia, which has been rocked by serious unrest.\n\nA French government spokeswoman said Macron will leave late on Tuesday for the Pacific archipelago, which lies 1,500 kilometres east of Australia.\n\nFrance has deployed 2,700 police officers and some military units to New Caledonia in the wake of riots which have killed six people and seen over 200 detained.\n\nA state of emergency is also in effect in the territory, although the situation has improved in recent days, the spokeswoman said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Australia and New Zealand dispatched aeroplanes to bring stranded citizens home from the violence-stricken region.\n\nThe protests emerged in response to proposed electoral reforms which would give French nationals the right to vote in provincial elections after ten years of residency in the territory.\n\nThe indigenous Kanak population of New Caledonia, which has long campaigned for independence, accused Paris of pushing ahead with the controversial reform without considering strong opposition among the majority of the territory's residents.\n\nThe archipelago gained extensive autonomy through the Noum\u00e9a Agreement of 1998. Paris is currently trying to conclude a new agreement with political leaders in the territory, which is strategically located in the southern Pacific Ocean.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8138722667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "14:13:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T14:13:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T14:13:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/524709df-e976-40b4-9476-3c1feab26430", "title": "Emmanuel Macron rushes to riot-hit French territory of New Caledonia", "body": "President Emmanuel Macron is to make an unexpected visit to France's riot-torn Pacific territory of New Caledonia to try to restart talks with local leaders and resolve a political crisis sparked by a controversial electoral reform.\n\nGovernment spokesperson Prisca Thevenot said Macron would depart for New Caledonia later on Tuesday to \"set up a mission\" there, but gave no further details of his aims or how long he would stay in the archipelago 1,500km east of Australia.\n\nMacron's trip follows deadly unrest in the territory, which he considers of strategic importance to France and which has vast reserves of nickel. Concerns about disruption to nickel supplies sent prices of the mineral, a crucial element in batteries and steelmaking, surging last week.\n\nSix people, including two police officers, have died in the riots that have led to the closure of schools, businesses and the main airport in the archipelago, which is home to a pro-independence movement led by members of the indigenous Kanak population.\n\nFrance declared a state of emergency in New Caledonia on May 15 and dispatched hundreds of extra police to the territory after the state's highest official there, Louis Le Franc, warned it was \"headed to civil war\".\n\nWhile the unrest has begun to calm, Australia evacuated more than 100 of its citizens from New Caledonia on Tuesday and New Zealand said it would fly home 50 people. France is planning further evacuation flights although the airport remains closed to commercial traffic.\n\n\"The president is going to New Caledonia in the spirit of responsibility that is his as the head of state\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009on this topic of high importance,\" Thevenot said at a press conference.\n\nThe unrest began when the government pushed ahead with electoral reform after several years of failed negotiations for an overall accord to reconcile New Caledonia's pro- and anti-independence camps.\n\nFrance has proposed expanding the right to vote in New Caledonian provincial elections to all citizens who have lived there for more than a decade. The change is opposed by much of the Kanak population who fear it would dilute their political influence in favour of the non-indigenous population that began to arrive during the colonial period.\n\nIf finalised, the French constitutional amendment would override the Noum\u00e9a Accord of 1998, which brought political stability to New Caledonia in part by restricting the voting franchise to Kanaks and citizens who lived in the territory before the agreement.\n\nMacron signalled last week that he could abandon the reform if local leaders made their own broader deal, but he has not officially withdrawn a plan to hold a congress in June to finalise the constitutional change.\n\nThe Kanaks have become a minority in the territory, accounting for about 40 per cent of the population. They suffer from higher unemployment and relatively low median salaries.\n\nAs part of a so-called de-colonialisation process, three referendums have been held since 2018 in which residents voted against independence from France, although the most recent one in 2021 was boycotted by pro-independence parties.\n\nThose votes preserved the status quo that gives New Caledonia significant autonomy and self-governing powers, and prompted Macron to declare the question of independence resolved.\n\nThe unrest is a setback for Macron, who on a trip to New Caledonia last year highlighted the strategic importance to France of the presence the territory gives its navy in the Pacific and its valuable nickel reserves. France sees its overseas territories in the Pacific and Indian Oceans as key to its efforts to counter China's economic and military influence.\n\nNew Caledonia's nickel sector has been plunged into crisis because of competition from lower-cost producers such as Indonesia. Several mining companies, including Glencore, have said they will pull out, in a blow to the French finance ministry's efforts to put together a bailout package.\n\nMacron's approach of pushing electoral reform as a tactic to try to catalyse agreement among supporters and opponents of independence had backfired, said Beno\u00eet Tr\u00e9pied, an anthropologist who specialises in New Caledonia.\n\n\"Touching the issue of the voting base without an overall accord and broad compromise amounts to picking up a hatchet,\" he told television channel France Info, suggesting it was a provocation to the Kanak population. \"Everyone has said and repeated that for years.\"", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Financial Times News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8139686710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:27:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:27:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:26:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/schools-cars-burn-in-new-caledonia-ahead-of-macron-visit/article_bd5f0c67-1ac8-5ca0-aa2b-34f139756f65.html", "title": "Schools, cars burn in New Caledonia ahead of Macron visit", "body": "Deputies of France's National Assembly stand for a moment of silence in tribute to the dead in riot-hit New Caledonia\n\nArsonists torched schools and hundreds of cars overnight in New Caledonia, officials said Wednesday, as President Emmanuel Macron embarked on a surprise visit aiming to end nine days of deadly riots on the French Pacific archipelago.\n\nMacron left Paris on Tuesday on a flight to the troubled territory, a popular holiday destination where roads are now littered with charred vehicles, and scores of shops, schools and other buildings are in cinders.\n\nClashes have left six people dead and hundreds injured since unrest erupted May 13 on the Pacific islands, home to 270,000 people.\n\nFrench authorities said the violence had eased since 1,050 troops, tactical police and national security reinforcements from Paris were deployed, including to \"highly sensitive\" areas.\n\nNevertheless, two primary schools and 300 cars in a dealership were torched in the territory's capital Noumea during the night, the mayor's office told AFP.\n\nThe deadliest unrest in four decades has been blamed on French plans to give voting rights to thousands of non-indigenous residents, which Indigenous Kanaks say will dilute their votes.\n\nPolice have arrested more than 280 \"rioters\" since the troubles began, the French authorities said.\n\n- Trapped tourists flee -\n\nTourists trapped in the territory have begun to flee.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent an initial batch of military planes to Noumea's small domestic Magenta airport on Tuesday, repatriating \"about 100 people\", according to French authorities on the island.\n\n\"When we landed, it was just like 'Oh, thank God we're here!'\" said Mary Hatten, who had spent a week holed up in a Noumea hotel, after touching down in Brisbane.\n\nFurther flights will be organised until the main La Tontouta International Airport reopens to commercial flights, French officials said.\n\nThe airport operator says commercial flights should resume on Saturday morning.\n\nMacron aims to \"listen to, talk and hold discussions with New Caledonian elected officials\" in an attempt to restore order, an official close to the president told AFP in Paris.\n\nHe wants to \"give answers to the many legitimate questions Caledonians are asking, both on the reconstruction side and the political side\", the official said.\n\nOne Kanak manning an unofficial roadblock north of the capital Noumea said Macron needed to understand Indigenous opposition to the vote reform.\n\n\"I don't know why our fate is being discussed by people who don't even live here,\" said the 52-year-old, who gave only his first name Mike.\n\n\"We are the people of the country, not you or the others. No, it's us,\" he told AFP.\n\nThe voice of local Kanaks \"is not being listened to, not being heard\", he said.\n\n- Barricades -\n\nFrench security forces have removed more than 90 roadblocks, authorities said.\n\nBut Kanak separatists, some masked and wielding homemade catapults, are still manning makeshift roadblocks including on the main route to the international airport, AFP correspondents said.\n\nArmed locals, of French and other origins, have set up their own neighbourhood barricades.\n\nLocal prosecutors say around 400 shops and businesses have been damaged.\n\nKanaks make up about 40 percent of the population.\n\nMany of them oppose the plan to extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nWithdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\nParis has for now held off extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, alcohol sales, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be {"uri": "8139397508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "00:03:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T00:03:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T00:02:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3263541/new-caledonia-riots-inequalities-lack-indigenous-voice-expose-failures-french-democratic-system", "title": "New Caledonia riots spotlight French 'failures' of democracy in South Pacific", "body": "\u2018Foreign interference\u2019 narrative, a bid to deflect France\u2019s responsibility for the crisis and insult to the Kanak people\u2019s long struggle for independence, analysts note\n\nCountries such as Australia should step up to address injustice of indigenous peoples, stop viewing the Pacific as vulnerable to \u2018foreign actors\u2019 like China, they add\n\nAs Australian and New Zealand planes begin evacuating citizens from the embattled Pacific island of New Caledonia on Tuesday after a week of riots, France will continue to come under pressure over its refusal to decolonise the territory, analysts say.\n\nViolent protests broke out in the island territory northeast of Australia last week after Paris extended voting rights to French people who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years or more, thus potentially diluting the indigenous Kanak people\u2019s efforts to win independence.\n\nFrance declared a state of emergency for the territory and has deployed armed forces to the island to quell the unrest that had led to blocked roads, a closed airport, six deaths, and stranded Australians, New Zealanders and other nationals.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron confirmed he would depart for the territory on Tuesday night.\n\nTensions between New Caledonia and its colonial master France have spanned decades, but they have reached a tipping point, according to Patrick Kaiku, a political-science teaching fellow at the University of Papua New Guinea.\n\n\u201cViolence is not new in New Caledonia, and even if the riots are to subside, the fear is that they can easily shift to small-scale revolts and passive resistance, especially in the North Province,\u201d Kaiku said, adding that the new laws would consolidate the voting power of France loyalists.\n\n\u201cGiven the tone of loyalists and French politicians, pro-independence groups will not back down. I don\u2019t see an end to this latest crisis.\u201d\n\nAmid the China\u2013United States rivalry that has also been playing out in the Pacific as Western nations seek to \u201cwin back\u201d island nations growing closer to China and other countries, foreign states such as Azerbaijan have also been dragged into the fiasco.\n\nLast week, French Interior Minister G\u00e9rald Darmanin accused Azerbaijan of stirring tensions in New Caledonia after the emergence of Azerbaijani flags alongside Kanak symbols in the protests. Azerbaijan, nearly 14,000km away from New Caledonia, denied allegations of foreign interference.\n\nAt the same time, Paris shut down TikTok on the island amid a state of emergency and curfews, raising questions about the suppression of freedom of speech. It did not offer a reason for the block.\n\nAll of these, however, were unnecessary \u201cnoise\u201d to drown out the legitimate concerns of Kanaks in their dealings with Paris, Kaiku said.\n\n\u201cEvoking the spectre of foreign interests and influence in the New Caledonia riots is a convenient ploy to sidestep the simmering tensions that have been building up since the 1998 Noum\u00e9a Accord and the demands for an electoral roll that is representative of the voters in the New Caledonian electorate,\u201d he said.\n\nThe latest voting changes proposed by Paris had gone against the Noum\u00e9a Accord, which allowed equal recognition of the interests of indigenous Kanaks and descendants of French settlers.\n\nThey also added insult to injury over a rushed third referendum for independence under the accord in 2021 when many indigenous New Caledonians were unable to vote because of the pandemic.\n\nOn Monday, an alliance of non-governmental organisations in the Pacific region called on the United Nations to send a neutral mission to \u201coversee and mediate dialogue between all parties to the Noum\u00e9a Accord\u201d.\n\nThe UN has continued to list New Caledonia as a non-self-governing territory yet to exercise its right to self-determination.\n\nThe alliance also sought UN support for the \u201cfailures of the French government as a neutral administrator of the territory\u2019s decolonisation process\u201d.\n\nClaiming that \u201cforeign interference\u201d was behind the turmoil in New Caledonia not only attempted to deflect responsibility from France for the crisis but was also an insult to the Kanak people\u2019s long struggle for independence, former University of Canberra New Caledonia researcher Alaine Chanter said in an analysis on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cIt is enabled by a Western narrative that sees the Pacific as a kind of political \u2018terra nullius\u2019 vulnerable to malign \u2018foreign actors\u2019 like China, Russia and now Azerbaijan,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThe US, Australia and, yes, France, argue that their aim is to counter these threats, to keep the Pacific \u2018family\u2019 democratic and intact. This discourse of political absence is infantilising, patronising, and deeply racist.\u201d\n\nThe riots ultimately stemmed from inequalities felt by the indigenous Kanak people under colonial rule, and it was time to question its legitimacy if inequalities were allowed to persist, said Nicole George, a Peace and Conflict Studies academic from the University of Queensland.\n\nIn an analysis for The Conversation on Monday, George said surrounding nations in the Pacific such as Australia should step up to address the injustice.\n\n\u201cThe scale of the rioting and devastation in Noum\u00e9a demonstrate, yet again, the failures of France to properly address the feelings of discontent among the Kanak population and the profound inequalities that exist in New Caledonia,\u201d said George, who was among the Australians stranded in New Caledonia.\n\nAnd yet, Canberra\u2019s latest cooperation with Paris in the \u201cAustralia-France Roadmap\u201d to support academic and professional engagement on security and defence in relation to policymaking in the Indo-Pacific was about China rather than French colonialism, Nic Maclellan, a veteran Pacific researcher, said in a Development Policy Centre analysis last week.\n\n\u201cRepeated lectures about \u2018democracy\u2019 from French politicians carry little sway in a colonial context, which is \u2013 by its very nature \u2013 anti-democratic,\u201d he said.\n\nA new \u201cAustralia-France Centre of Excellence for the Indo-Pacific\u201d under that same road map was \u201clooking increasingly difficult for Australia to justify\u201d, La Trobe University international relations researcher Kate Clayton said on X.\n\nAs for whether the crisis could make way for new diplomatic relations between China and New Caledonia, Kaiku said it was unlikely as the territory was not a sovereign state for now.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": The business chamber said 150 companies had been looted and burnt.\n\nNew Zealand, French and Australian foreign ministers held a call on Monday evening, after New Zealand and Australia said they were waiting for clearance from French authorities to send defence aircraft to evacuate tourists.\n\nA meeting of France's defence council later agreed for arrangements to allow tourists to return home.\n\n\"New Zealanders in New Caledonia have faced a challenging few days - and bringing them home has been an urgent priority for the government,\" New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters said.\n\n\"We want to acknowledge the support of relevant authorities, both in Paris and Noum\u00e9a, in facilitating this flight,\" he added. Further flights will be sent in coming days, he added.\n\nAustralia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong said in a social media post on Tuesday that clearance had been received for two \"Australian government assisted-departure flights today for Australian and other tourists to depart New Caledonia\".\n\nProtests erupted last week, sparked by anger among indigenous Kanak people over a constitutional amendment approved in France that would change who is allowed to participate in elections, which local leaders fear will dilute the Kanak vote.\n\nViro Xulue, part of a community group providing social assistance to other Kanaks amid the crisis, said it felt like a return to the civil war of the 1980s, and people were scared.\n\n\"We are really scared about the police, the French soldiers, and we are scared about the anti-Kanak militia terrorist group,\" Xulue told Reuters in a video interview.\n\nThree of six people killed in the unrest were young Kanaks shot by armed civilians, and there have been confrontations between Kanak protesters and armed self-defence groups or civilian militias formed to protect themselves, France's High Commission previously said.\n\n\"The French Government doesn't know how to control people here. They send more than 2,000 military to control, but it's fail,\" Xulue said.\n\nPro-independence political parties say they want the French government to withdraw the electoral reform before they restart talks, while France said re-establishing order was a precondition to dialogue.\n\n(Reporting by Kirsty Needham and Lucy Craymer; Editing by Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", We continue to pursue approvals,\" Wang added.\n\nApproximately 300 Australians stranded in New Caledonia have registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) and have been advised {"uri": "8139118853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "19:01:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T19:01:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T19:00:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.flightglobal.com/fixed-wing/australia-and-new-zealand-launch-military-evacuation-flights-from-new-caledonia/158383.article", "title": "Australia and New Zealand launch military evacuation flights from ...", "body": "The Australian military has launched evacuation flights to repatriate civilians stranded in New Caledonia amid civil unrest.\n\nRoyal Australian Air Force (RAAF) transports evacuated more than 100 tourists from Australia and elsewhere on 21 May, according to Canberra. Photos released by the RAAF show armed military personnel helping holiday-attired visitors in the island's capital Noumea board a Lockheed Martin C-130J cargo aircraft with tail number A97-450.\n\nFlight tracking data shows a C-130 bearing that registration arrived in Noumea at 15:14 local time on 21 May. Less than 2h later, at 16:48, the same craft departed Noumea Magenta airport for Brisbane.\n\nA separate C-130 from the Royal New Zealand Air Force was also dispatched to retrieve some 50 citizens from that country.\n\nThe overseas French territory erupted into violence and unrest on 13 May over a law passed in Paris that would expand voting rights for non-indigenous residents of the South Pacific island.\n\nAt least six people have since been reported dead, with more than 1,000 French gendarmes deployed to restore order.\n\nLocal authorities say commercial flight cancellations have stranded an estimated 3,200 people in New Caledonia, although some of those were from flights attempting to enter the territory.\n\nABC reports that more than 300 Australian visitors have been stranded in the capital Noumea since rioting began. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) launched two evacuation flights as part of Canberra's assisted departure response, the department says.\n\n\"Defence conducted a number of ADF flights to assist with the repatriation of Australian nationals, permanent visa holders and approved foreign nationals wishing to return to Australia from New Caledonia,\" the ADF says, noting the flights were requested by Australia's diplomatic service.\n\nFrench authorities are reportedly coordinating additional flights, including for individuals located outside the Noumea region. {"uri": "8139756762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:21:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:21:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T06:20:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-22/australians-stranded-new-caledonia-evacuation-flights/103872706", "title": "'What a mess this place is': Australians stranded in New Caledonia desperate to get home", "body": "Stranded Australian tourists in riot-stricken New Caledonia are still unsure when they will be evacuated, despite French authorities offering seats on departure flights to some travellers.\n\nThe Australian government evacuated 84 Australians and 24 foreign nationals from New Caledonia's capital Noumea yesterday on military transport planes.\n\nA French government assisted flight is expected to carry around 100 Australians to Brisbane later today.\n\nSome Australians the ABC spoke to said they had been notified of French government flights, but it was not clear what time they would depart.\n\nTylah Carre, an Australian tourist in Noumea, said he received a text from French authorities saying they would \"conduct flights for [their] safe departure\".\n\n\"But we don't know if we have six hours or just an hour, like yesterday when people were told there's a bus downstairs,\" Mr Carre said.\n\n\"Many are staying in their rooms in case they get the call.\"\n\nJanine Banks, another Australian tourist, said she was frustrated with the communication from the Australian government.\n\nShe said she hadn't received any information from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade until about 9pm last night and relied on WhatsApp for updates from other tourists.\n\n\"We were told Monday night to be ready for evacuation on Tuesday, so we packed and waited by the phone all day.\"\n\nShe then heard no updates during the day.\n\nMs Banks had initially booked a trip to Vanuatu but her flight plans changed when Air Vanuatu went bust.\n\nQueensland academic Nicole George was teaching in Noumea when rioting erupted last week.\n\nShe was hoping to be one of the more than 100 Australian residents who were repatriated on the two ADF flights overnight.\n\nPacific Minister Pat Conroy said the French government was \"currently planning flights to Brisbane today, using their resources\".\n\n\"So the primary plan is more French flights,\" he said.\n\n\"But we do have contingency plans and we do have planes on stand-by should there be an issue with that course of action.\"\n\nHe added a French plane was due to leave for Brisbane this afternoon or evening and evacuate about 100 Australians.\n\n\"So bringing it to around 184 Australians roughly, brought home over the last day or two.\"\n\nVictorian doctor Max Winchester and wife Tiffany are also stranded and said their first attempt at a kid-free holiday had gone terribly wrong.\n\nThe pair, from Woodend, had been holidaying when the political unrest began and were unable to get seats on the first evacuation flights.\n\n\"We're being told we're going to be evacuated by the French and we just don't feel comfortable with that,\" Dr Winchester said.\n\n\"It was my attempt at our first child-free romantic holiday.\"\n\nDr Winchester said he and his wife had run out of their medication and were unable to go to the nearest town because of fires, looting and vandalism.\n\nYesterday's defence force flights departed from new Caledonia's domestic airport, but Australian tourists told the ABC they were unsure if barricades still blocked the road to New Caledonia's international airport further north.\n\nFrom his hotel window, Mr Carre couldn't see any fires but heard local news of a factory ablaze in Noumea's industrial zone.\n\n\"It feels like it has de-escalated, but it's uneasy,\" he said.\n\nSome shops had stock, but most shelves were still empty.\n\nNew Caledonia's business chamber reported 150 companies had been looted and burned.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is on his way to New Caledonia in a move which could also complicate further evacuation flights.\n\nAides to Mr Macron said he would meet with officials and local representatives on Thursday for a day of talks focused on politics and on the reconstruction of the island.\n\nThe unrest in New Caledonia, with a population of about 270,000, was sparked by French plans to impose new rules that would give tens of thousands of non-Indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nPro-independence groups say any such move would dilute the Indigenous Kanak vote.\n\nMs George said she was worried Mr Macron's visit would further inflame tensions and make it difficult to continue evacuations.\n\n\"We don't think a group of tourists from Australia are really high priority at the moment.\n\n\"We are concerned if the violence kicks off [again] in the next couple of days.\"\n\nShe said there was a lot of uncertainty among the remaining Australians.\n\n\"We are trying to band together, we have a WhatsApp group here, we're trying to support each other.\"", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, {"uri": "8139681269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:22:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:22:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:21:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/schools-cars-burn-in-new-caledonia-ahead-of-macron-visit/article_3eebc9fc-0ca2-51ff-82ad-fe756d35427f.html", "title": "Schools, cars burn in New Caledonia ahead of Macron visit", "body": "Deputies of France's National Assembly stand for a moment of silence in tribute to the dead in riot-hit New Caledonia\n\nArsonists torched schools and hundreds of cars overnight in New Caledonia, officials said Wednesday, as President Emmanuel Macron embarked on a surprise visit aiming to end nine days of deadly riots on the French Pacific archipelago.\n\nMacron left Paris on Tuesday on a flight to the troubled territory, a popular holiday destination where roads are now littered with charred vehicles, and scores of shops, schools and other buildings are in cinders.\n\nClashes have left six people dead and hundreds injured since unrest erupted May 13 on the Pacific islands, home to 270,000 people.\n\nFrench authorities said the violence had eased since 1,050 troops, tactical police and national security reinforcements from Paris were deployed, including to \"highly sensitive\" areas.\n\nNevertheless, two primary schools and 300 cars in a dealership were torched in the territory's capital Noumea during the night, the mayor's office told AFP.\n\nThe deadliest unrest in four decades has been blamed on French plans to give voting rights to thousands of non-indigenous residents, which Indigenous Kanaks say will dilute their votes.\n\nPolice have arrested more than 280 \"rioters\" since the troubles began, the French authorities said.\n\n- Trapped tourists flee -\n\nTourists trapped in the territory have begun to flee.\n\nAustralia and New Zealand sent an initial batch of military planes to Noumea's small domestic Magenta airport on Tuesday, repatriating \"about 100 people\", according to French authorities on the island.\n\n\"When we landed, it was just like 'Oh, thank God we're here!'\" said Mary Hatten, who had spent a week holed up in a Noumea hotel, after touching down in Brisbane.\n\nFurther flights will be organised until the main La Tontouta International Airport reopens to commercial flights, French officials said.\n\nThe airport operator says commercial flights should resume on Saturday morning.\n\nMacron aims to \"listen to, talk and hold discussions with New Caledonian elected officials\" in an attempt to restore order, an official close to the president told AFP in Paris.\n\nHe wants to \"give answers to the many legitimate questions Caledonians are asking, both on the reconstruction side and the political side\", the official said.\n\nOne Kanak manning an unofficial roadblock north of the capital Noumea said Macron needed to understand Indigenous opposition to the vote reform.\n\nMore from this section Cannabis Edibles Are Triggering Poisonings Among Older Users Tracking Exercise by Steps or Minutes? Study Finds Either Method Boosts Health 'I'm grateful': Sask. birders wowed by rarely spotted scarlet tanager\n\n\"I don't know why our fate is being discussed by people who don't even live here,\" said the 52-year-old, who gave only his first name Mike.\n\n\"We are the people of the country, not you or the others. No, it's us,\" he told AFP.\n\nThe voice of local Kanaks \"is not being listened to, not being heard\", he said.\n\n- Barricades -\n\nFrench security forces have removed more than 90 roadblocks, authorities said.\n\nBut Kanak separatists, some masked and wielding homemade catapults, are still manning makeshift roadblocks including on the main route to the international airport, AFP correspondents said.\n\nArmed locals, of French and other origins, have set up their own neighbourhood barricades.\n\nLocal prosecutors say around 400 shops and businesses have been damaged.\n\nKanaks make up about 40 percent of the population.\n\nMany of them oppose the plan to extend voting rights to those who have lived in the territory for at least 10 years.\n\nBut anti-independence representatives want it pushed through.\n\nWithdrawing \"would prove the wreckers, the looters and the rioters right,\" said Nicolas Metzdorf, a New Caledonia MP for Macron's Renaissance party.\n\nParis has for now held off extending a 12-day state of emergency, which has led to a night-time curfew, house arrests of suspected ringleaders, and bans on TikTok, alcohol sales, carrying weapons and gatherings.\n\nNew Caledonia has been a French territory since the mid-1800s.\n\nBut almost two centuries on, opinion is split roughly along ethnic lines over whether the islands should be part of France, autonomous or independent.\n\nburs-djw/cwl", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mathurin_derel@reformer.com", {"uri": "8139581858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:49:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:49:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:49:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.afr.com/world/pacific/what-s-really-behind-the-riots-in-new-caledonia-20240522-p5jfp3", "title": "What's really behind the riots in New Caledonia?", "body": "Set in the warm waters of the south-west Pacific, some 1500 kilometres east of Australia, New Caledonia is home to 270,000 people, including 41 per cent Melanesian Kanaks and 24 per cent of European origin, mostly French.\n\nThe archipelago was given its name by British explorer Captain James Cook in 1774. It was annexed by France in 1853 and used as a penal colony until shortly before the turn of the 20th century.\n\nNew Caledonia, one of five island territories spanning the Indo-Pacific held by France, is central to Emmanuel Macron's plan to increase French influence in the Pacific.\n\nThe world's No. 3 nickel producer, New Caledonia lies at the heart of a geopolitically complex maritime region, where China and the United States are jostling for power and influence in security and trade. Without naming China, Macron has previously said France's drive to expand its influence in the Pacific was to ensure a \"rules-based development\".\n\nAfter France's colonisation in the 19th century, New Caledonia officially became a French overseas territory in 1946. Starting in the 1970s, in the wake of a nickel boom that drew outsiders, tensions rose on the island, with various conflicts between Paris and Kanak independence movements.\n\nA 1998 Noumea Accord helped end the conflict by outlining a path to gradual autonomy and restricting voting to the indigenous Kanak and migrants living in New Caledonia before 1998. The accord allowed for three referendums to determine the future of the country. In all three, independence was rejected.\n\n\"Tonight, France is more beautiful because New Caledonia has decided to stay part of it,\" Macron said after the result of the most recent vote in 2021. Nonetheless, the 2021 poll was boycotted by pro-independence parties due to the coronavirus pandemic, and there remains lingering scepticism over the legitimacy of the result.\n\nUnder the terms of the Noumea Accord, voting in provincial elections was restricted to people who had resided in New Caledonia before 1998, and their children. The measure was aimed at giving greater representation to the Kanaks, who had become a minority population.\n\nParis has come to view the arrangement as undemocratic and lawmakers approved a constitutional amendment to open up the electorate to include people who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years.\n\nMacron has said he will delay rubber-stamping it into law, and invite representatives of the territory's population to Paris for talks to reach a negotiated settlement. However, he said a new agreement must be reached by June, or he will sign it into law.", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-363959273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "00:56:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T00:56:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T00:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/really-torn-caledonia-turmoil-forces-003304898.html", "title": "'We're really torn': New Caledonia turmoil forces French nationals to sail to safety in Australia", "body": "New Caledonia was only ever supposed to be a stopover, a pause on a family sailing trip around the world. \"But we discovered,\" a French national, Xavier Decramer, says from his boat in the Noum\u00e9a marina, \"a very nice place to stay and to live. The infrastructure was amazing as far as the roads, the libraries, the schools ... and also a very peaceful place.\n\n\"It's small, people are kind to each other ... say hi to everyone ... It was a very courteous place, and, and we really enjoyed that.\"\n\nAnd so, it became home to Decramer, his wife, Maeva Zebrowski, who was born in New Caledonia, and their three young children. Their children enrolled in schools and the family found community in Noum\u00e9a.\n\nBut the turmoil that has erupted into violence this month has ended their New Caledonian homecoming. After less than a year, the family will, in coming days, pack their boat with the supplies that can be sourced and sail for Brisbane, Australia - 770 nautical miles, or about six days of sailing.\n\n\"It's clearly with a heavy heart that we're going to be leaving this place,\" Decramer says.\n\n\"Bearing in mind my wife was born here, we wanted to settle here. It's difficult. We're really torn between the need to put our family in safety ... and the feeling that we are leaving people behind here - people who cannot leave.\"\n\nWith Noum\u00e9a's international airport closed for commercial flights, leaving isn't an option for many people. Some governments have launched repatriation flights to take their nationals out of New Caledonia.\n\nDecramer says the decision to depart has been hardest on their three children, \"who've made friends in school, who will not be able to go back ... to say goodbye to the friends they are going to leave\".\n\nRelated: New Caledonia unrest: Australia and New Zealand sending evacuation flights for stranded tourists\n\nThe latest unrest in New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory of 270,000 people, erupted over French plans to unfreeze electoral rolls for provincial elections - changes that would give tens of thousands of non-Indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nUnder the terms of the Noum\u00e9a accord, voting in provincial elections was restricted to people who had resided in New Caledonia before 1998 and their children. The measure was aimed at giving greater representation to the Indigenous Kanak population.\n\nThe Kanak people make up about 40% of New Caledonia's population and Kanak groups argue the new voting rules would dilute their vote.\n\nMore than a week of rioting, looting and arson has left six people dead, including two gendarmes, and hundreds injured. France has sent more than 1,000 security forces to its overseas territory and the president, Emmanuel Macron, told a meeting of his defence and security council there was \"clear progress in re-establishing order\".\n\nBut pro-independence, largely Kanak activists vowed they would not retreat from their protests and reports from Noum\u00e9a say some roadblocks taken down by security forces were being rebuilt by pro-independence forces.\n\nDecramer says the political disquiet was always present, made visible in protests and occasional unrest.\n\n\"The demonstrations that were happening in the past few months - yes, they were big, but they were peaceful and they were a part of normal life for people living here for a long time. They tell you, 'Well, it's been ups and downs for 40 years: you're new, you don't understand, it's OK.'\n\n\"Sadly, we've seen even the locals have been surprised by the speed and the severity of the uprising.\"\n\nBut despite the political fractures erupting into violence this month, \"there's been great solidarity between the different people\".\n\n\"There is a local news radio, NC La Premi\u00e8re, which is doing a fantastic job. They have ... an open-air show with everybody calling in for information or questions ... The people are helping each other.\n\n\"You have the people giving codes so that some people who are far in the islands can recharge their phones. You have people going out to get medicine for elderly people who are stuck in their apartments, live information on which roads are safe or not, which stores open or not.\"\n\nRelated: A week of unrest in New Caledonia - in pictures\n\nAt the height of the violence, Decramer and his family left Noum\u00e9a for a nearby island in the lagoon off the capital.\n\n\"We were 12 nautical miles out and we could still hear some of the detonations from ... the city at night. You could still smell the burnt plastic from whatever was burning at the time. Even far into the lagoon ... you could still feel the turmoil there.\"\n\nDecramer says the deaths during the violence have been a tragedy for New Caledonia. But neighbourhood patrols have been \"a blessing\", he says. His youngest child's school has been patrolled by class parents at night to keep it from being attacked.\n\nAnd Decramer remains positive about New Caledonia's future, which he hopes will recognise Kanak Indigenity, as well as the archipelago's multiculturalism.\n\n\"I hope that their path towards independence will be a peaceful one, not like the one today.\n\n\"As far as the future of New Caledonia is concerned, I think a greater autonomy or actual independence is the long-term future of this place. But for it to be a peaceful movement ... it has to be inclusive.\"", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [{"uri": Noum\u00e9a International Airport closed for protection and limited access, with barricades and burnt-out vehicles causing chaos on the way to the airport and restricted access. New Zealand and Australia are preparing for deployment to repatriate tourists operating from Noum\u00e9a Magenta Aircess. SIMPLEFLYING VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nMilitary aircraft from Australia, France, and New Zealand have been busy repatriating stranded tourists in New Caledonia home after widespread riots broke out across Noum\u00e9a following political tension. Violence broke out in the nation's capital following a debate from Paris that proposed constitutional changes that favored France's continued governance of the South Pacific territory.\n\nNoum\u00e9a International Airport, La Tontouta (NOU), was barricaded for protection and to limit access. At the same time, the nearly hour-long journey between Noum\u00e9a and the airport was littered with barricades, burnt-out vehicles, and rioters, which led to the airport being closed by French authorities and tourists stranded.\n\nIn recent days, the Royal New Zealand Defence Force and Royal Australian Defence Force have prepared for deployment to New Caledonia while awaiting authority from the French government to operate to Noum\u00e9a to repatriate stranded tourists home. Due to the limited access to La Tontouta, approval was given to operate from Noum\u00e9a Magenta Airport (GEA), a domestic airport two miles from the city center.\n\nDiscover more aviation news for Australia and Oceania here.\n\nReturning travelers home\n\nNew Zealand's Royal Defence Force operated its first repatriation flight on Tuesday evening, bringing 50 stranded travelers home onboard its Hercules C-130H. The New Zealand Government is now working with French authorities to transport the remaining 200 affected homes in one go, a request that would require a more significant international airport, La Tontouta, to open and permit the operation of larger commercial aircraft. The Australian government has also operated a Hercules to New Caledonia, transporting affected Australians to Brisbane, the closest international port.\n\nFrench authorities are set to reassess the opening of La Tontouta on Thursday. However, it remains unclear if this would see commercial services resume. Aircalin, the flag carrier of New Caledonia, has suspended its international operations, with its offices remaining closed. According to the carrier's website, the airline has been permitted to operate one repatriation flight from Nadi (NAN), Fiji, to New Caledonia on May 22nd to repatriate stranded residents home. However, data from Flightradar24 shows this flight was canceled.\n\nGet the latest aviation news straight to your inbox: Sign up for our newsletters today.\n\nMore flights expected\n\nFrance's High Commission in New Caledonia has advised that it expects many more repatriation flights to take place in the coming days to transport 500 stranded French and other foreign tourists. The French president, Emmanuel Macron, is expected to touch down in the Pacific tomorrow in a bid to cool tensions between the indigenous Kanak and French people.\n\nRelated Violent Protests Lead To 2 {"uri": "8138580570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:50:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:50:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:49:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.spacedaily.com/reports/French_marines_patrol_New_Caledonia_after_deadly_riots_999.html", "title": "French marines patrol New Caledonia after deadly riots", "body": "Military and police \"reinforcements will control areas that have got out of our hands in recent days,\" said French high commissioner Louis Le Franc, the highest-ranking state official in New Caledonia.\n\nAnger over France's plan to impose new voting rules has spiralled into the deadliest violence in four decades in the archipelago of 270,000 people, which lies between Australia and Fiji -- 17,000 kilometres (10,600 miles) from Paris.\n\nFrench Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Thursday that about 1,000 extra security forces were being sent to New Caledonia -- adding to the 1,700 already present.\n\nThey began landing Thursday at the French army-controlled La Tontouta International Airport and could be seen moving through the capital Noumea in red berets, toting rifles, gas masks and riot shields.\n\nFrance's EFS blood supply agency said that supplies of blood were being sent over to deal with the \"critical\" situation.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron cancelled a video conference with local leaders Thursday for lack of willing participants, but began contacting pro- and anti-independence officials individually on Friday, his office said.\n\nUsing state of emergency powers, security forces had imposed \"a calmer and more peaceful situation\" around Noumea for the first time since the unrest broke out on Monday, the high commission said early Friday.\n\nBut there were fires at a school and two companies, it added.\n\n- Smouldering buildings -\n\nOn Friday morning, AFP journalists saw flames and smoke pouring from a shopping centre, smouldering buildings, dozens of burned-out cars and residents dragging the remnants of vehicles off the roads.\n\nHundreds of people lined up outside shops for desperately needed food and supplies, although authorities have promised to bring in essential goods.\n\nLe Franc described areas \"where there are several hundred rioters waiting for just one thing: contact with the security forces\".\n\nTen independence activists accused of organising violence have been placed under house arrest, according to authorities.\n\nTwo gendarmes have been killed: one shot in the head and a second shot in friendly fire, officials said.\n\nThree other people -- all indigenous Kanaks -- have also been killed: a 17-year-old and two men aged 20 and 36.\n\nOne suspect in an unspecified homicide handed himself in and a second has been arrested on suspicion of killing two Kanaks.\n\nFrance has accused Azerbaijan of \"interference\" in the politics of its Pacific territory, but Baku has rejected the claims.\n\nOn Friday, a French government agency, Viginum, said it detected a \"massive and coordinated\" online campaign pushing claims that French police had shot pro-independence demonstrators in New Caledonia. The government pointed to the involvement of \"Azerbaijani actors\" in the campaign.\n\n- Barricades and burning tyres -\n\nThe violence is the worst seen in New Caledonia since unrest involving independence radicals rocked the French overseas territory in the 1980s.\n\nNew Caledonia has on three occasions rejected independence in referendums, but the cause retains strong support among the Kanak people, whose ancestors have lived on the islands for thousands of years.\n\nColonised by France from the second half of the 19th century, it has special status with some local powers transferred from Paris.\n\nFrench lawmakers this week pushed forward plans to allow people who moved to New Caledonia at least 10 years ago to vote in the territory's elections.\n\nPro-independence forces say that would dilute the vote of Kanaks, who make up about 40 percent of the population.\n\nGroups of Kanaks have set up roadblocks around the main island, waving the territory's flag, burning tyres and blocking or slowing traffic.\n\nOther mostly non-indigenous residents, some armed, piled up garden chairs, crates and other belongings in neighbourhood barricades.\n\n- TikTok challenge -\n\nA local business group estimated the damage, concentrated around Noumea, at 200 million euros ($217 million).\n\nFrench Justice Minister Eric Dupond-Moretti has called on prosecutors to \"take the strongest possible action against the perpetrators of the violence\" and also indicated he was considering transferring the \"criminals\" to mainland France.\n\nThe Noumea public prosecutor's office opened an investigation targeting \"the instigators\" of the riots.\n\nParis has accused a group known as CCAT, which gathers the most radical separatists, of being behind the riots.\n\nOn Friday CCAT issued a statement calling for \"a time of calm to break the spiral of violence\".\n\nParis has closed the airport to commercial flights, shuttered schools, imposed a night-time curfew and banned gatherings, carrying weapons and the sale of alcohol.\n\nThe government has also blocked social network TikTok, saying it was being used by protesters.", "source": {"uri": "spacedaily.com", The French authorities have sent hundreds of police officers into New Caledonia, enforced a curfew and banned TikTok, but they have struggled to restore calm in the territory.\n\nSome local leaders expressed doubts that Mr. Macron, who is scheduled to arrive on Thursday, could defuse the tensions. \"Here comes the fireman after he set the fire!\" Jimmy Naouna, a spokesman for FLNKS, an alliance of pro-independence parties, wrote on social media.\n\nMany in the Kanak community have accused Mr. Macron and France of reneging on an agreement that had put New Caledonia on a possible path to independence. Mr. Macron has refused calls to withdraw the amendment.\n\nHis trip will be the first visit to the territory, where about 270,000 people live, by a senior French leader since violence broke out last Monday. "Stranded Australians in New Caledonia amid riots return home safelyAisling BrennanNCA NewsWireTue, 21 May 2024 5:59PM\n\nAustralians stranded in New Caledonia as tensions escalate in the French-controlled South Pacific territory have touched down on home soil after being rescued by the Defence Force.\n\nForeign Affairs minister Penny Wong confirmed on Tuesday morning clearance had been granted for two Australian government assisted-departure flights to leave New Caledonia bound for Brisbane.\n\nAt least one repatriation flight safely landed shortly after 7pm on Tuesday at Brisbane International Airport.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nThe second flight is expected to depart Noumea at 7.22pm and is due to arrive into Brisbane by 11pm.\n\nThe flights would be carrying \"Australians and other tourists\" departing New Caledonia in the wake of the violent riots, which were sparked as plans to change voting rules are underway.\n\nThe government's evacuation plan was the result of the island country's international airport being closed and roads being blockaded by authorities as the riots continue.\n\nAt least six people have been killed during the protests and many others injured.\n\n\"(Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) is contacting registered Australians,\" Ms Wong said on X, formally known as Twitter.\n\n\"Passengers are being prioritised based on need.\n\n\"We continue to work on further flights.\"\n\nThere are 300 Australians currently registered with the DFAT who want to leave the island, located about 1200km off Australia's east coast.\n\nIt's understood Qantas will provide connections to returning citizens not based in Brisbane.\n\nAny Australians in New Caledonia who wish to be evacuated and haven't already registered should contact DFAT's crisis centre.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said the flights were an important step and ensuring Australians were safe amid the violent riots.\n\n\"The wellbeing of Australians in New Caledonia is a priority,\" Mr Albanese said on X.\n\nThe uncertainty on the island
