{"uri": "8138550738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "12:36:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T12:36:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T12:32:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13442721/Thank-God--First-New-Caledonia-evacuation-flight-arrives-Australia.html", "title": "'Thank God!': First New Caledonia evacuation flight arrives in...", "body": "Chris Salmon embraces his wife Marney after arriving in Brisbane from New Caledonia on May 21, 2024\n\nA plane full of elated and relieved Australian tourists who had been trapped in New Caledonia during a week of rioting and looting touched down in Brisbane late Tuesday.\n\nTheir Royal Australian Air Force C130 Hercules was the first evacuation flight to leave the French Pacific territory since unrest began on May 13.\n\n\"When we landed, it was just like 'Oh, thank God we're here!'\" said Mary Hatten, who had spent the last week holed up in a Noumea hotel as opponents of French rule took to the streets.\n\nNew Caledonia's main international airport remains closed to commercial aircraft, stranding thousands of tourists like Hatten who flocked to the South Pacific isle looking for a slice of paradise.\n\nThey instead found themselves barricaded inside hotels with dwindling food supplies, as forces sent from Paris tried to quell protests, riots and looting fuelled by opposition to French rule.\n\nHatten said about 50-60 passengers were onboard the first flight including many children and pregnant women fleeing violence that has killed six and injured hundreds.\n\nThe Pacific territory of 270,000 people has been in turmoil since last week when violence erupted over French plans to impose new voting rules that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nHatten and her partner Phil arrived at Noumea Airport the day the unrest began. From the get-go, she told AFP, it was clear all was not well.\n\nOn the drive to the city \"it looked very sketchy\" she said. Scores of Indigenous Kanak protestors \"lined the road, waving flags, burning tyres. It felt very uncomfortable\".\n\nA Royal Australian Air Force C-130 Hercules aircraft evacuating people at Noumea-Magenta Airport in New Caledonia\n\nShe spent the week watching the smoke rise over Noumea as successive commercial flights home were cancelled and police began staying at the hotel.\n\n\"It's a holiday that we didn't expect,\" she said. \"We just decided that, you know, if we could get a repatriation flight with the Royal Australian Air Force, we would take it.\"\n\nFinally, she got a call from Australian consular staff early Tuesday morning and was told to pack her bags and be ready to leave on 30 minutes' notice.\n\nA group of would-be travellers assembled in the hotel lobby before being loaded into half a dozen coaches and taken under police and military escort to the city's Magenta airport, which usually serves domestic routes.\n\nOn the route out she saw the same plumes of \"thick black smoke\" coming from burning tyres.\n\nPassengers waited in an airport hangar and were fed before taking themselves, their beach bags and their families onto the military transporter.\n\n- 'Most pressing needs' -\n\nBurnt vehicles in the Magenta district of Noumea in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, on May 21, 2024\n\nFor days, the Australian and New Zealand militaries have been on standby waiting for French authorities to give the all-clear for relief flights to begin.\n\nFrench troops said they had cleared dozens of make-shift separatist roadblocks from the international airport to the city, but militants and protestors remain lined along some of the route.\n\nFinally on Tuesday two Australian military planes and one from New Zealand dashed across the Coral and Tasman Seas to collect passengers from Noumea's more domestic accessible airport.\n\nMore than 3,000 travellers are estimated to have been stranded by the unrest.\n\nIt is not known how many of those are tourists on holiday in New Caledonia and how many are Caledonians stuck overseas.\n\n(L-R) Erko Isanovic, Nichole Hatten, Wei Liak, Phil Hatten, and Mary Hatten are seen after disembarking a flight arriving from Noumea at Brisbane International Airport in Brisbane It was not immediately clear how many would be on Tuesday's flights in total.\n\nThe New Zealand Defence Force plane was expected to carry about \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\", were injured after violence erupted in the French Pacific territory last week.\n\nAs a result, the La Tontouta International Airport is closed until further notice, making it difficult for the government to help Australians.\n\nResponding to reports the consulate in Noumea had closed and Australians on the ground were organising help among themselves, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese defended his government.\n\n\"Australia's response over a period of time ... is, I think, amongst, certainly equal to, anywhere in the world,\" the prime minister told ABC radio on Tuesday.\n\n\"At the moment, the airport is closed so, the planes can't get in, but Air Force have been on stand-by for the last 48 hours and they remain ready to provide that assistance to evacuate Australians who its advice and urged Australians to reconsider travel plans to New Caledonia.\n\n\"Political demonstrations and protests are occurring and may turn more violent at short notice,\" its website says.\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Penny Wong said she and her New Zealand counterpart Winston Peters had spoken with French Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne to convey condolences, request access to the territory and \"express our gratitude for French efforts to restore calm\".\n\nConsul-General of France in Sydney Martin Juillard said the consulate was working in close co-ordination with French associations to help New Caledonian families who are not able to go back home.\n\n\"This is a joint effort, where we work together, try not to overlap and make sure that all basic humanitarian needs to contact the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.\n\nFearful Australians stuck on the island have likened the deteriorating situation to a war zone and there are concerns food supplies could run {"uri": "2024-05-363232912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "10:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T10:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T10:46:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/france-hails-progress-appeasing-protest-104626735.html", "title": "France hails 'progress' on appeasing protest-hit New Caledonia", "body": "An uneasy calm has returned to New Caledonia after the deployment of hundreds of French security forces to shut down violent protests on the Pacific island territory sparked by opposition to a controversial Constitutional reform. While the international airport remains closed to commercial traffic, Australia and New Zealand began evacuating nationals on government planes.\n\n\"A return to calm continues on the whole territory,\" wrote the French state representative in New Caledonia, Louis Le Franc, in a statement published Tuesday, announcing the deployment of additional security forces.\n\nSix people have been killed in violence sparked by protesters angry about a constitutional reform that would change who can participate in local elections, which pro-Independence leaders say will dilute the indigenous Kanak voice.\n\nRioting and looting have shuttered businesses, and road barricades have restricted access to food and medical care.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron noted \"progress\" towards re-establishing law and order, after a defence council Monday night, where he decided to send the army to protect public buildings.\n\nStranded tourists\n\nAustralia and New Zealand announced the first evacuation flights for tourists blocked by the unrest, as the main international airport is closed to commercial traffic at least until Thursday.\n\nMore than 3,000 people thought to have been stranded in New Caledonia.\n\nThey also refuse to consider suspending the reform, as demanded by the pro-Independence parties that have been involved in the protests.\n\n(with newswires)", "source": {"uri": "8139546300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:12:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:12:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:11:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://globalvoices.org/2024/05/22/unrest-in-new-caledonia-the-kanak-peoples-destiny-should-not-be-decided-in-europe/", "title": "Unrest in New Caledonia: 'The Kanak people's destiny should not be decided in Europe'", "body": "Violence erupted in New Caledonia in response to the constitutional bill amendment proposed in France's National Assembly. Screenshot from YouTube video of Al Jazeera English, fair use.\n\nProtests turned into riots in New Caledonia as pro-independence youth activists clashed with the police in response to a proposed constitutional reform in the French National Assembly which would allow residents who have lived there for 10 years to vote in local elections. Activists say the move further dilutes Indigenous peoples' power on the island and will ensure New Caledonia remains an \"overseas territory\" of France.\n\nNew Caledonia is a South Pacific territory that was colonized by France in 1853. Despite longstanding independence demands by local Indigenous groups, it remains a French territory. It has been on the United Nations' list for decolonization since 1986. The landmark Noumea Peace Accord in 1998 instituted a three-part independence referendum to determine the political future of New Caledonia.\n\nThe first referendum took place in November 2018 while the second vote was held in October 2020. Both results delivered only a small margin in favor of France which reflected a solid constituency pushing for the self-determination of the Indigenous Kanak population. The third referendum in December 2021 was controversial because the Paris government decided to continue with it despite appeals from the Kanak community to postpone the voting during the pandemic. As expected, it delivered an overwhelming victory for France because pro-independence groups boycotted the referendum. The voter turnout was also less than 50 percent.\n\nInstead of addressing the concern of Pacific groups about the credibility of the third referendum, France pushed forward with a constitutional bill that would \"unfreeze\" New Caledonia's electoral roll. This means residents who arrived or settled in the territory over the past decade will be eligible to vote. This would further dilute the voting representation of the Kanak people who make up 42 percent of the 270,000 population.\n\nViolence erupted in New Caledonia while France's National Assembly was deliberating the amendment bill on May 13. Almost 5,000 people were involved in the riots that also led to looting and burning of properties. A state of emergency was declared in the territory and France deployed troops to restore order. Some apps like TikTok were banned which raised concern about the suppression of free speech. As violence continued for several days, Pacific groups called for peace as they expressed solidarity with the Kanak community.\n\nCharlot Salwai Tabimasmas, chairman of the Melanesian Spearhead Group and Prime Minister of Vanuatu, attributed the crisis to the indifference of French leaders.\n\nThese events could have been avoided if the French Government had listened and not proceeded to bulldoze the Constitutional Bill aimed at unfreezing the electoral roll, modifying the citizen's electorate, and changing the distribution of seats in Congress.\n\nBut he also warned that \"the indiscriminate destruction of property will affect New Caledonia's economy in a very big way and that will have a debilitating cascading effect on the welfare and lives of all New Caledonians, including the Kanaks.\"\n\nHe is proposing the establishment of a \"dialogue and mediation mission to be led by a mutually agreed high-personality\" to resolve the crisis. This is also the recommendation of the Pacific Islands Forum which stated that it \"stands ready to facilitate and provide a supported and neutral space for all parties to come together in the spirit of the Pacific Way.\"\n\nReverend James Shri Bhagwan, General Secretary of the Pacific Conference of Churches, reminded French leaders about the supposed \"impartial role\" of the French state in the decolonization process. He also underscored the historic roots of the crisis.\n\nIt cannot be ignored that eruption of violence is the manifestation of the pain, trauma and frustration of a community who have consistently had their indigenous and political rights undermined, by a French government whose rhetoric of being a \"Pacific nation\" is exposed by its actions.\n\nPastor Var Kaemo, president of the Protestant Church in Kanaky New Caledonia, lamented the violent turn of events. \"We must not be accomplices to these volcanic eruptions that spread disaster and misery in the land of our ancestors. The island closest to paradise has become the island closest to hell.\"\n\nNew Caledonia is the world's third-largest producer of nickel -- a crucial component in the EV energy transition -- and jobs in the nickel-mining industry make up 25 percent of employment opportunities. The price of nickel has spiked since the unrest began last week.\n\nNicole George, associate professor in Peace and Conflict Studies at the University of Queensland, interviewed women leaders who pointed out the active role of frustrated young people who were protesting wealth disparities and lack of meaningful opportunities in the territory. \"These fuel resentment and the profound racial inequalities that deprive Kanak youths of opportunity and contribute to their alienation,\" she wrote.\n\nThis is the same analysis made by Victor Gogny, president of the S\u00e9nat coutumier, the Kanak Customary Senate, an advisory body to Congress and government made up of 16 Indigenous chiefs.\n\nThe statement issued by the Pacific Regional Non-Governmental Organisations on April 30, two weeks before the debate in the French assembly which triggered the unrest, reflected the sentiments of the Indigenous Kanak community.\n\nThe evil of colonialism can continue unchecked in this manner, and in this 21st Century is not only an insult to the Pacific Region but to the international system.\n\nThe Pacific is not distracted by French false narratives. The Kanak, as people, are the rightful inhabitants of what is present day New Caledonia still under enduring French colonial rule.\n\nThe Kanak people and New Caledonias destiny should not be decided in Europe, they are Pacific people who are rightfully asking for their freedom.\n\nAs of Tuesday, May 21, French President Emmanuel Macron plans to make a surprise visit to the island state to attempt to quell the protest.", "source": {"uri": "globalvoices.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global Voices"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanak_people", "type": {"uri": "8134810480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-19", "time": "05:15:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-19T05:15:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-19T05:14:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/defence-on-standby-to-rescue-australians-trapped-in-new-caledonia-5652932", "title": "Defence on Standby to Rescue Australians Trapped in New Caledonia", "body": "Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong says the defence force is 'ready to fly' once local authorities advise it is safe to use the airport.\n\nAs soon as French authorities advise the airport in Noum\u00e9a is safe, Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel will be deployed to New Caledonia to help evacuate the estimated 300 Australians trapped there by over a week of violence, Foreign Minister Penny Wong has said.\n\nSix people -- all believed to be locals -- have been killed so far in the French-ruled Pacific Island territory during rioting that was sparked by French government plans to reform the territory's elections, reducing the likelihood of a future majority in favour of independence.\n\nThe latest fatality was a person killed in an exchange of fire at one of the many impromptu barricades blocking roads on the island.\n\nA state of emergency has been declared, and a curfew has been imposed. Reports have said that both hotels housing foreigners and locals were running out of food, and all commercial flights in and out have been stopped.\n\nWhile the six deaths announced by authorities are directly attributable to the violence, there are fears that it may be even higher due to people being unable to access medical help due to the deteriorating situation, worsened by roadblocks in the city, or too afraid to venture outside to find it.\n\nThierry de Greslan, a representative from the hospital in Noum\u00e9a, estimated that three or four people \"may have died due to lack of access to medical care.\"\n\nHe added that around 50 dialysis patients had been unable to receive their treatments. The number of visits to emergency rooms dropped significantly, up to 80 percent.\n\n\"We are having great difficulty bringing our patients and health care workers in. Teams have been working since Monday and are exhausted,\" he said. \"We are in an urban guerrilla situation with nightly gunshot wounds.\"\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said the Australian government is \"closely monitoring\" events.\n\n\"Commercial flights stopped a couple of days ago. We are looking at in what way we can provide assistance to Australians who are currently in New Caledonia,\" he said.\n\nSenator Wong said the government is working with French authorities to expedite the evacuation of any Australians who wish to leave.\n\n\"The Australian Defence Force is ready to fly, pending commercial flights resuming,\" she said. \"French authorities advise the situation on the ground is preventing flights. We continue to pursue approvals.\"\n\nAustralians stuck in New Caledonia amid the unrest say they're desperate to get home as supermarket shelves are bare.\n\nBrisbane woman Sophie Jones Bradshaw told AAP she was exhausted and scared as she waited to see whether she could return to Australia ahead of her son's fourth birthday in several days.\n\nShe said she had slept fully dressed for the past five nights with her passport, phone, and laptop in a bag ready to go at any moment.\n\n\"I'm really hoping that [the airport] will open on the 22nd and I'll be maintained on my flight, which I doubt,\" she said. \"But I'm really hoping and it's hard not to know.\"\n\nAnother Australian trapped by the fighting told Reuters that they were rationing food as they waited for a way out.\n\nJoanne Elias, has been in the territory since May 10 and is trapped at a local resort with with her husband and four children.\n\n\"The kids are definitely hungry because we don't really have much option of what we can feed them. We don't know how long we're going to be here for,\" she said.\n\nMeanwhile the mayor of Noum\u00e9a has described New Caledonia as being \"under siege.\"\n\nSonia Lagarde said that while overnight violence has eased due to a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew, \"we are far from a return to normal.\"\n\n\"The situation is not improving,\" she said. \"Quite the contrary, despite all the appeals for calm ... The damage is incredible ... {"uri": "8135858761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-19", "time": "23:28:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-19T23:28:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-19T23:27:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://au.news.yahoo.com/aussies-stranded-in-new-caledonia-detail-terrifying-ordeal-amid-mass-riots-231412397.html", "title": "Aussies stranded in New Caledonia detail 'terrifying' ordeal amid mass riots", "body": "An Australian woman stranded in New Caledonia amid growing unrest and riots has taken aim at the government over what she described as a \"lack of communication\", describing scenes on the ground as \"absolutely terrifying\".\n\nSix people have died following the French government's decision to allow people who have lived on the South Pacific island for at least 10 years to vote in provincial elections. The indigenous Kanak people, and pro-independence groups are protesting the electoral reform, with concerns it will dilute their vote.\n\nAussies stranded on the French-ruled territory say they are rationing food as they wait for a way out of the troubled island, with no flights currently being allowed in or out. They are among 3200 people who are stuck waiting to leave or enter.\n\nTonia Scholes described the neighbourhood in which her Airbnb is located, approximately 5 kilometres from the capital Noumea, as \"like a war zone\".\n\n\"There's burnt cars, there's barricades, there's remnants of fires, there's people standing on street corners drinking hard liquor and having what almost seems like a party,\" she said on The Project on Sunday night.\n\n\"Buildings that we used as landmarks to find out Airbnb have been burnt to the ground,\" she added.\n\nScholes said she has no idea when she and her travel companions will be able to return back to Australia, with the group being told very little by the federal government.\n\n\"It's absolutely terrifying. You think that we're a little bit protected in Australia -- that the government's got our backs,\" she said. \"But there has been a lack of communication with information getting through to Australia as to how bad it is here.\n\n\"Friends of mine are just like 'Oh just get on to Smart Traveller' or 'just get onto the embassy'. The embassy's been closed here since we got here...We called the consulate, they sounded surprised that we were calling them. We don't call Canberra at three in the morning for fun.\n\n\"We found that they had our email address wrong. We found that there had been virtually no contact. We found that they had somebody else's surname wrong. This stuff matters, this is our lives and we want to come home. We don't know what's happening, we've got bags packed with our essentials. we're just hoping and waiting for a phone call.\"\n\nWhile Scholes praised those around her for helping to keep her and her friends out of harm's way, she admitted that she feared for her safety. \"So we are under curfew from 6pm to 6am every night and the night is peppered with gunshots and pops and bangs and helicopters and we've seen fighter jets and this is just surreal,\" she said.\n\n\"It's definitely not what I thought I was coming for.\"\n\nAnother Aussie stranded, Joanne Elias, said she was told to fill up a bathtub with water in case it ran dry. \"The kids are definitely hungry because we don't really have much option of what we can feed them,\" Joanne Elias said on Saturday from a resort in the capital Noumea, where her family has been holed up.\n\n\"You can tell they are running out of food,\" she told Reuters, referring to the resort where they are staying. Elias, who arrived in the country on May 10 with her husband and four children, said she had been told to fill a bathtub in case water ran out, as food stocks dwindled.\n\n\"We don't know how long we're going to be here for,\" she said.\n\nOn Sunday, Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the government was working with French authorities to give assistance to Australians stranded in the South Pacific islands. Commercial flights are currently not operating from Noum\u00e9a's La Tontouta International Airport, and a state of emergency has been declared. A nationwide curfew between 6pm and 6am is also in place.\n\n\"We are working to support Australians in New Caledonia,\" Wong said on X.\n\n\"The Australian Defence Force is ready to fly, pending commercial flights resuming. French authorities advise the situation on the ground is preventing flights. We continue to pursue approvals.\"\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said about 300 Australians are currently registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), and said the government was on hand to deliver assistance.\n\n\"The Australian government is closely monitoring events in New Caledonia, and there are reports they're running out of food and commercial flights are stopped, commercial flights stopped a couple of days ago,\" he told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"We are looking into how we can provide assistance to Australians who are currently in New Caledonia.\"\n\nSmart Traveller has warned Aussies to reconsider travel to New Caledonia over fears protests and political demonstrations \"may turn more violent at short notice\".\n\nTourists have been urged to \"exercise a high degree of caution,\" and are urged to avoid the island's capital of Noum\u00e9a due to political unrest, and the likelihood of travel disruptions and limited essential France declared a state of emergency there on 15 May.\n\n\"The president is mobilised on the subject, as he has been since 2017,\" Prisca Thevenot told the press after the Council of Ministers met on Tuesday. She did not specify how long Macron would stay in New Caledonia or the nature of the 'mission', which will be unveiled in the coming days.\n\nMacron will be joined by Minister of Interior G\u00e9rald Darmanin, Minister of Defense S\u00e9bastien Lecornu and Minister Delegate for Overseas Affairs, Marie Gu\u00e9venoux.\n\nShe added that Prime Minister Gabriel Attal will \"also have the opportunity to go there, not immediately but in the coming weeks\".\n\nMore than 400 shops and businesses have been 'destroyed or damaged' since the start of the riots in reaction to a constitutional reform decried by the pro-independence movement a week ago, Noumea public prosecutor Yves Dupas said on Tuesday.\n\nAccording to the government, the return of 'order and security' is a prerequisite for any resumption of negotiations.\n\nMacron's visit 'is an opportunity for dialogue that must be seized', non-independence MP Philippe Dunoyer, a member of Macron's Renaissance party, told AFP. The second Renaissance MP for New Caledonia, Nicolas Metzdorf, said he opposed any postponement or withdrawal of the constitutional reform that had sparked off the violence.\n\nMore than 2,700 gendarmes, police officers, and military personnel are deployed in New Caledonia, and additional numbers are expected. Four civilians - including at least three indigenous Kanak residents - have been killed in riots along with two police officers. Dozens more have been injured and more than 200 people arrested so far.\n\nUnder the planned reform, all citizens who have been resident in the archipelago for ten years would be included in the New Caledonia electorate, which should result in a loss of electoral weight for the Kanaks.\n\nAccording to Macron, the reform should be validated 'before the end of June' by a Congress of senators and deputies, but the opponents are calling for the text to be postponed.\n\nOn Sunday (19 May), the presidents of R\u00e9union island, Guadeloupe, Martinique, and French Guiana - all French overseas Government spokesperson Prisca Thevenot announced the trip. \"He will go there tonight,\" she said on Tuesday.\n\nThe previously unannounced trip required a shake-up of Macron's schedule. He had previously planned a trip on Wednesday to Normandy in northern France Instead, he will be heading to the archipelago 10 time zones away from Paris, east of Australia, that has been gripped by deadly armed clashes, looting, arson and other mayhem.\n\nA state of emergency was declared by Paris last week and 1,000 reinforcements rushed in to bolster security forces that lost control of some {"uri": "8137723670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "02:55:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T02:55:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T02:54:31Z", "dataType": "news", Zealand to dispatch three planes to New Caledonia to rescue stranded tourists", "body": "Australia and New Zealand announced three planes will be sent to the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia on Tuesday to rescue hundreds of tourists who have been barricaded in hotels during a week of deadly unrest.\n\nIn Wellington, Foreign Minister Winston Peters said New Zealand was dispatching a plane immediately after receiving long-delayed landing permission from French authorities.\n\nNew Caledonia's main Tontouta International Airport usually brings in a steady stream of tourists looking for a relaxing break in paradise.\n\nBut for the past week, it has received military planes laden with heavily armed French security forces trying to put down violent protests against Paris rule.\n\nPeters said the first New Zealand aircraft would bring \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\" back to Auckland.\n\nIt would, he said, be the \"first in a series of proposed flights to begin bringing New Zealanders home\".\n\nShortly after the announcement, his counterpart Penny Wong said Australia had received permission to send two planes.\n\nMore than 3,000 people are estimated to have been stranded by a week of unrest that has shuttered the Pacific archipelago's main international airport.\n\nMany of them are Australian and New Zealand tourists stuck in resorts and hotels with dwindling supplies of food.\n\nAustralian tourist Maxwell Winchester and his wife Tiffany have been barricaded at a resort between Noumea and the airport for more than a week.\n\nHe told AFP on Tuesday that they were \"ecstatic\" at the prospect of impending rescue.\n\n\"We realise we probably won't get on these flights, because those who have higher needs will get on them, but we at least know we have a way out in the next few days,\" he said.\n\nTourists have told AFP of food shortages, gunfire, and reports of arson and looting near resorts, leaving them fearful for their safety.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8139465158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "01:30:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T01:30:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T01:29:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2024/05/22/yzbd-m22.html", "title": "New Caledonia unrest continues amid massive French security operation", "body": "facebook icon\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is flying to New Caledonia today in a direct attempt to shut down riots and unrest that have enveloped the colony for the past eight days.\n\nMacron said the main objective was to \"install\" a \"dialogue mission\" to resume political talks with all stakeholders and find a \"political solution\" to the crisis. Macron's spokesperson Prisca Th\u00e9venot said a \"return to order\" was a preliminary condition for any talks.\n\nThe French Pacific territory has entered a second week of unrest despite the imposition of an emergency decree by Macron last Wednesday. Rioting, largely by indigenous Kanak youth, has devastated the island's capital, Noum\u00e9a. By Friday five people, three young Kanaks and two gendarmes, had been killed.\n\nThe rioting erupted as the French National Assembly pushed through a constitutional amendment to allow French residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years since 1998 the right to vote in provincial elections and for the 54-member Congress. The move is opposed by pro-independence leaders who claim it will dilute the vote of indigenous Kanaks, who make up over 40 percent of the population.\n\nThe protests, involving thousands of Kanaks, have been met with fierce repression from the French state and been confronted with armed pro-France vigilante groups. So far 230 people have been arrested. The 12-day state of emergency gives authorities extensive powers to ban gatherings, impose travel bans, and conduct house arrests and searches.\n\nA contingent of 1,000 French police and army reinforcements arrived on Friday, bringing armed security personnel to 2,700, including riot and crowd control squads.\n\nOver the weekend, the media reported an \"uneasy calm\" had settled over Noum\u00e9a's suburbs, where scenes of violence, arson and confrontation had continued throughout Friday. Despite the military-police crackdown, however, enforcement agencies still had not regained control of the capital's central districts, with fires and other damage occurring overnight Saturday.\n\nFrance's High Commissioner Louis Le Franc claimed: \"With massive reinforcement, we will soon be able to regain control of these areas.\" But Noum\u00e9a's mayor, Sonia Lagarde, said while overnight violence had eased due to a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew, \"we are far from a return to normal.\" \"The situation is not improving -- quite the contrary -- despite all the appeals for calm,\" she said, adding that Noum\u00e9a was \"under siege.\"\n\nThe unrest has spread to rural areas. On Saturday, a sixth death was reported after a man was killed near the town of Kaala-Gomen, about 355 kms north of the capital, in an exchange of gunfire at one of many barricades blocking roads on the island. Le Franc said security forces would stage \"harassment\" raids to reclaim other parts of the territory held by pro-independence groups.\n\nA major armed police operation was mounted Sunday to regain control of the main roads in and around Noum\u00e9a. Le Franc warned: \"Republican order will be re-established whatever the cost.\" More than 600 gendarmes used tanks to clear protesters and roadblocks from the road connecting Noum\u00e9a with Tontouta International Airport, which remains closed for commercial flights until further notice.\n\nOn Monday Macron claimed that there was \"clear progress in the restoration of order,\" while authorizing the military deployed to bolster police protecting public buildings in Noum\u00e9a. Islands Business correspondent Nic Maclellan reported scattered attacks were still occurring around the capital, including on shops and businesses. Roadblocks were also maintained by pro-independence forces into the Northern Province.\n\nAustralian and New Zealand governments yesterday began dispatching military aircraft to evacuate their citizens after French authorities authorised the flights to land at the domestic airport. According to Maclellan, the foreign ministers of Australia and NZ had earlier contacted their French counterpart to \"press action\" over delays.\n\nFrance remains determined to tighten its grip on the colony. As the US and its allies prepare for war against China, French imperialism is seeking to play a role in the militarisation of the Pacific. New Caledonia hosts a major French military base and holds nearly a quarter of the world's reserves of nickel, essential in the manufacture of stainless steel and in the arms industry.\n\nFrench Prime Minister Gabriel Attal has been chairing daily meetings of an \"inter-ministerial crisis cell\" involving Overseas Minister G\u00e9rald Darmanin, his deputy Marie Gu\u00e9venoux, Army Minister S\u00e9bastien Lecornu and Justice Minister Eric Dupont-Moretti. On Friday, Attal met leaders of the parliamentary parties to discuss whether to extend the state of emergency beyond 12 days, which would require the approval of both the lower house National Assembly and the Senate.\n\nTwo pro-France parties, Les Loyalistes and Rassemblement, told a press conference on Tuesday that to withdraw the constitutional amendment would amount to \"condoning the rioters and looters' actions.\" \"Terrorism, violence must not win (...) We're asking the French State to restore law and order,\" local pro-France politician Virginie Ruffenach declared.\n\nPro-independence figures led by the Front de Lib\u00e9ration Nationale Kanak et Socialiste (FLNKS) have been calling for the measure to be scrapped and that a French \"dialogue mission\" -- similar to the delegations sent by Paris before the signing of the 1998 Noum\u00e9a Accord -- headed by a \"high, recognised and independent official\" should come and negotiate a compromise.\n\nThe alliance of five pro-independence parties that make up the FLNKS represent an indigenous elite that has a vested interest in maintaining the existing voting arrangements, while posing no real alternative to the imperialist-dominated establishment.\n\nNew Caledonia's President Louis Mapou -- a Kanak politician from the National Union for Independence, part of the FLNKS -- bluntly condemned the actions of the rioters, saying \"anger cannot justify harming or destroying public property, production tools, all of which this country has taken decades to build.\"\n\nThe explosive rioting has exposed the vast class chasm between Kanak workers and youth in particular and the colony's wealthy layers. Maclellan posted on X/Twitter that the young people \"burned symbols of wealth and targeted large shopping centres and businesses. They live in urban areas and face daily difficulties. With their families, they are in poverty. They don't have a job.\"\n\nAndre Qaeze from Noumea's Radio Djiido similarly told RNZ Pacific that Kanak youth \"don't have any training, they go out from school with no job... The rich become richer and the poor become poorer, and they say no, we have to change this economic model of sharing. I think this is the main problem.\"\n\nAmid an escalating economic crisis, with the vital nickel industry in turmoil and people reeling from escalating living costs, the official parties representing both pro-independence and rival anti-independence forces stand on the side of the business elite, opposing any meaningful measures to end poverty and social inequality.\n\nAcross the region, meanwhile, there is growing outrage over France's repression. The Melanesian Spearhead Group, formed in 1986 by Papua New Guinea, Fiji, Vanuatu and Solomon Islands to back decolonisation, blamed France for the riots and demanded it drop the electoral reform.\n\nAn alliance of over two dozen Pacific non-government organisations also condemned France for what they say is a \"betrayal\" of New Caledonia's Kanak population. The Pacific Regional Non-Government Organisations (PRNGOs) condemned \"the Macron government for its poorly hidden agenda of prolonging colonial control over the territory.\"\n\nThe outgoing chair of the 18-member Pacific Islands Forum and Cook Islands Prime Minister Mark Brown said \"greater autonomy\" for the indigenous Kanak population is needed. Noting that many Forum members are former colonies, Brown said Pacific peoples value \"sovereignty\" and the protests were in response to that.\n\nThe reality is that none of the impoverished Pacific Island countries are fully independent: all of them rely heavily on aid from the imperialist powers and their governments are subject to routine interference from Australia, New Zealand, the US and France. Some analysts are concerned, however, that France's police repression could undermine the propaganda about an alliance of \"democracies\" seeking to push back against \"autocratic\" Chinese influence in the region.\n\nReuters reported that one commentator for the Sydney-based Lowy Institute, Oliver Nobetau, declared that the \"heavy-handed\" response to the protests by France would backfire in the region, where decolonisation was \"expected.\" \"France is trying to re-emerge as a Pacific partner and this will evidently not help that image,\" he warned.\n\nRead moreMacron declares state of emergency in New Caledonia as riots erupt over voting change17 May 2024Protests erupt in New Caledonia as France amends colony's electoral system19 April 2024Macron visits Pacific to bolster France's position amid escalating strategic tensions31 July 2023Contact usRelated TopicsFind out more about these topics:New CaledoniaAsia and the PacificFranceMelanesia", "source": {"uri": "wsws.org", {"uri": "2024-05-364139052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:50:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:50:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:50:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://pacific.scoop.co.nz/2024/05/new-caledonia-unrest-continues-amid-massive-french-security-operation/", "title": "Pacific.scoop.co.nz \" New Caledonia Unrest Continues Amid Massive French Security Operation", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron is flying to New Caledonia today in a direct attempt to shut down riots and unrest that have enveloped the colony for the past eight days. Macron said the main objective was to install a dialogue mission to resume ...\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is flying to New Caledonia today in a direct attempt to shut down riots and unrest that have enveloped the colony for the past eight days.\n\nMacron said the main objective was to \"install\" a \"dialogue mission\" to resume political talks with all stakeholders and find a \"political solution\" to the crisis. Macron's spokesperson Prisca Th\u00e9venot said a \"return to order\" was a preliminary condition for any talks.\n\nThe French Pacific territory has entered a second week of unrest despite the imposition of an emergency decree by Macron last Wednesday. Rioting, largely by indigenous Kanak youth, has devastated the island's capital, Noum\u00e9a. By Friday five people, three young Kanaks and two gendarmes, had been killed.\n\nThe rioting erupted as the French National Assembly pushed through a constitutional amendment to allow French residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years since 1998 the right to vote in provincial elections and for the 54-member Congress. The move is opposed by pro-independence leaders who claim it will dilute the vote of indigenous Kanaks, who make up over 40 percent of the population.\n\nThe protests, involving thousands of Kanaks, have been met with fierce repression from the French state and been confronted with armed pro-France vigilante groups. So far 230 people have been arrested. The 12-day state of emergency gives authorities extensive powers to ban gatherings, impose travel bans, and conduct house arrests and searches.\n\nA contingent of 1,000 French police and army reinforcements arrived on Friday, bringing armed security personnel to 2,700, including riot and crowd control squads.\n\nOver the weekend, the media reported an \"uneasy calm\" had settled over Noum\u00e9a's suburbs, where scenes of violence, arson and confrontation had continued throughout Friday. Despite the military-police crackdown, however, enforcement agencies still had not regained control of the capital's central districts, with fires and other damage occurring overnight Saturday.\n\nFrance's High Commissioner Louis Le Franc claimed: \"With massive reinforcement, we will soon be able to regain control of these areas.\" But Noum\u00e9a's mayor, Sonia Lagarde, said while overnight violence had eased due to a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew, \"we are far from a return to normal.\" \"The situation is not improving -- quite the contrary -- despite all the appeals for calm,\" she said, adding that Noum\u00e9a was \"under siege.\"", "source": {"uri": "pacific.scoop.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Scoop"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8139425144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "00:40:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T00:40:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T00:37:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/may/22/were-really-torn-new-caledonia-turmoil-forces-french-nationals-to-sail-to-safety-in-australia", "title": "'We're really torn': New Caledonia turmoil forces French nationals to sail to safety in Australia", "body": "Xavier Decramer and his family made a home in Noum\u00e9a, but the eruption of violence has prompted them to leave 'with a heavy heart'\n\nNew Caledonia was only ever supposed to be a stopover, a pause on a family sailing trip around the world. \"But we discovered,\" French national Xavier Decramer says from his boat in the Noum\u00e9a marina, \"a very nice place to stay and to live. The infrastructure was amazing as far as the roads, the libraries, the schools ... and also a very peaceful place.\n\n\"It's small, people are kind to each other ... say hi to everyone ... It was a very courteous place, and, and we really enjoyed that.\"\n\nAnd so, it became home to Decramer, his wife, Maeva Zebrowski, who was born in New Caledonia, and their three young children. Their children enrolled in schools and the family found community in Noum\u00e9a.\n\nBut the turmoil that has erupted into violence this month has ended their New Caledonian homecoming. After less than a year, the family will, in coming days, pack their boat with the supplies that can be sourced and sail for Brisbane, Australia - 770 nautical miles, or about six days sailing.\n\n\"It's clearly with a heavy heart that we're going to be leaving this place,\" Decramer says.\n\n\"Bearing in mind, my wife was born here, we wanted to settle here. It's difficult. We're really torn between the need to put our family in safety ... and the feeling that we are leaving people behind here, people who cannot leave.\"\n\nWith Noum\u00e9a's international airport closed for commercial flights, leaving isn't an option for many people. Some governments have launched repatriation flights to take their nationals out of New Caledonia.\n\nDecramer says the decision to depart has been hardest on their three children, \"who've made friends in school, who will not be able to go back ... to say goodbye to the friends they are going to leave\".\n\nThe latest unrest in New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory of 270,000 people, erupted over French plans to unfreeze electoral rolls for provincial elections - changes that would give tens of thousands of non-indigenous residents voting rights.\n\nUnder the terms of the Noum\u00e9a Accord, voting in provincial elections was restricted to people who had resided in New Caledonia prior to 1998 and their children. The measure was aimed at giving greater representation to the indigenous Kanak population.\n\nThe Kanak people make up about 40% of New Caledonia's population and Kanak groups argue the new voting regulations would dilute their vote.\n\nMore than a week of rioting, looting and arson has left six people dead, including two gendarmes, and hundreds injured. France has sent more than 1,000 security forces to its overseas territory and the president, Emmanuel Macron, told a meeting of his defence and security council there was \"clear progress in re-establishing order\".\n\nBut pro-independence, largely Kanak activists vowed they would not retreat from their protests and reports from Noum\u00e9a say some roadblocks taken down by security forces were being rebuilt by pro-independence forces.\n\nDecramer says the political disquiet was always present, made visible in protests and occasional unrest.\n\n\"The demonstrations that were happening in the past few months, yes, they were big, but they were peaceful and they were a part of normal life for people living here for a long time. They tell you, 'well, it's been ups and downs for 40 years: you're new, you don't understand, it's OK'.\n\n\"Sadly, we've seen even the locals have been surprised by the speed and the severity of the uprising.\"\n\nBut despite the political fractures erupting into violence this month, \"there's been great solidarity between the different people\".\n\n\"There is a local news radio, NC La Premi\u00e8re, which is doing a fantastic job. They have ... an open-air show with everybody calling in for information or questions ... The people are helping each other.\n\n\"You have the people giving codes so that some people who are far in the islands can recharge their phones. You have people going out to get medicine for elderly people who are stuck in their apartments, live information on which roads are safe or not, which stores open or not.\"\n\nAt the height of the violence, Decramer and his family left Noum\u00e9a for a nearby island in the lagoon off the capital.\n\n\"We were 12 nautical miles out and we could still hear some of the detonations from ... the city at night. You could still smell the burnt plastic from whatever was burning at the time. Even far into the lagoon ... you could still feel the turmoil there.\"\n\nDecramer says the deaths during the violence have been a tragedy for New Caledonia. But neighbourhood patrols have been \"a blessing\", he says. His youngest child's school has been patrolled by class parents at night to keep it from being attacked.\n\nAnd Decramer remains positive for New Caledonia's future, which he hopes will recognise Kanak indigenity, as well as the country's current multiculturalism.\n\n\"I hope that their path towards independence will be a peaceful one, not like the one today.\n\n\"As far as the future of New Caledonia is concerned, I think a greater autonomy or actual independence is the long-term future of this place. But for it to be a peaceful movement ... it has to be inclusive.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": came from Macron's spokesperson Prisca Th\u00e9venot, who also said \"return to order was the preliminary condition to any talks.\"\n\n\"It has been announced by the President, during the Cabinet meeting, that he will travel there this evening (Paris time)\", Th\u00e9venot said.\n\nIt has not been revealed as yet who were the members of the mission.\n\nThere had been calls from across the political spectrum, both in mainland France and in New Caledonia (including from capital Noum\u00e9a Mayor Sonia Lagarde) over the past few days, for such a \"dialogue mission\".\n\nThe calls also involved Macron withdrawing a controversial Constitutional Amendment that would \"unfreeze\" New Caledonia's conditions of eligibility and allow some 25,000 French citizens to vote at local provincial elections.\n\nThe amendment has been endorsed by France in both houses of Parliament, but it remains to be ratified by the Congress, a joint sitting of both these Houses.\n\nMacron's initial plan was to convene this Congress sometime by the end of June.\n\nMacron's announcement was widely welcomed, but at least two pro-France parties, Les Loyalistes and Rassemblement, told a press conference earlier Tuesday that to withdraw the text amounted to \"condoning the rioters and looters' actions.\"\n\n\"Terrorism, violence must not win (...) remains closed to the public and all commercial international flights have now been cancelled until Saturday.\n\nIn several Noum\u00e9a neighbourhoods, burning, and looting of businesses was still {"uri": "2024-05-361229571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-19", "time": "14:39:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-19T14:39:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-19T10:54:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-updates/incidents/aussies-paradise-trip-to-new-caledonia-takes-horror-turn/news-story/6b2b9ee7d745701974f7493a22a455b6", "title": "Aussie stranded on island breaks down", "body": "It was meant to be a dream trip, however an Australian woman has revealed how her trip to a holiday paradise has turned into a disaster.\n\nTonia Scholes is one of around 300 Australians, and among 3000 international tourists in total, who are stranded in New Calendonia due to violent riots that have left six dead in the French-ruled territory.\n\nIt comes following the French government's decision to let people who have lived on the South Pacific island for at least 10 years vote in provincial elections.\n\nTonia is located approximately 5 kilometres from the capital Noumea, and appeared on The Project on Sunday night to talk about her experience being stranded on the island.\n\n\"We were having a lovely dinner with girlfriends, we started to hear some little pops in the distance and we were like 'fireworks'!,\" she said.\n\n\"Not fireworks. The next morning there were several plumes of smoke and the air quality was not very good and the first indication we had was our hostess from the Airbnb messaged me and was like 'Are you OK'?\"\n\nTonia said she responded to her hostess confirming that she was okay, oblivious to the unfolding danger, to which the hostess informed her that she could not leave.\n\n\"That was the end of the holiday as such and when it became more like a lockdown. So we are under curfew from 6pm to 6am every night and the night is peppered with gunshots and pops and bangs and helicopters and we've seen fighter jets and this is just surreal.\n\n\"It's definitely not what I thought I was coming for.\"\n\nProject host Sarah Harris said: \"It sounds absolutely terrifying\".\n\nTo which Tonia responded by telling her about her horrifying experience of going to the grocery shop.\n\n\"It was like a war zone,\" she said. \"There's burnt cars, there's barricades, there's remnants of fires, there's people standing on street corners drinking hard liquor and having what almost seems like a party ...\n\n\"Buildings that we used as ladmarks to find out Airbnb have been burnt to the ground.\"\n\nWhen asked by Project co-host Hamish Macdonald if she fears for her safety, Tonia said \"a little bit\".\n\nHowever, she also praised those around her for helping to keep the tourists safe.\n\n\"People from home are saying you know 'I hope you're safe' and it's like we hope we are, we are actually in a French neighbour and they are amazing.\n\n\"They have all banded together to protect what is theirs and they have 24 hour watches, they walk the streets with big torches, that's actually our neighbours protecting us which is just amazing that they've embraced us in their neighbourhood, a bunch of Australian girls here for a week and they're just like 'don't worry we've got your back'.\"\n\nTonia said it has been difficult to find help to organise evactuation of the island.\n\n\"It is absolutely terrifying. You think we're a little bit protected in Australia and the governement's got our backs and what we've found is that's not really the case. There has been a lack of communication with information getting through to Australia as to how bad it is here.\"\n\nShe said the embassy is closed in New Caledonia and can't help them, the consulate \"sounded surprised\" that they were calling them and they had their email address wrong and claimed there had been no contact.\n\n\"We don't call Canberra at 3am for fun .... This stuff matters, this is our lives. We want to come home and we just don't know what's happening, we've got little go bags packed with our essentials and we're just hoping and waiting for a phone call to say we've got somehow of getting you out.\"\n\nOn Sunday, Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the government was working with French authorities to give assistance to Australians stranded in the South Pacific islands.\n\nCommercial flights are currently not operating from Noum\u00e9a's La Tontouta International Airport, and a state of emergency has been declared.\n\n\"We are working to support Australians in New Caledonia,\" Ms Wong said in a post made on X.\n\n\"The Australian Defence Force is ready to fly, pending commercial flights resuming.\n\n\"French authorities advise the situation on the ground is preventing flights. We continue to pursue approvals.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said about 300 Australians are currently registered with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), and the government was ready to deliver assistance.\n\n\"The Australian government is closely monitoring events in New Caledonia, and there are reports they're running out of food and commercial flights are stopped, commercial flights stopped a couple of days ago,\" he said on Sunday.\n\n\"We are looking into how we can provide assistance to Australians who are currently in New Caledonia.\"\n\nAustralians have been urged by Smart Traveller to reconsider travel to New Caledonia over fears protests and political demonstrations \"may turn more violent at short notice\".", {"uri": "8137833810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "04:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T04:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T04:45:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.digitaljournal.com/world/new-caledonia-tourists-ecstatic-as-rescue-planes-arrive/article", "title": "New Caledonia tourists 'ecstatic' as rescue planes arrive", "body": "Smoke rises in the distance as roadblocks are seen near the Montravel area of Noumea, capital of France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia - Copyright AFP Theo Rouby\n\nTourists trapped by rioting, looting and separatist roadblocks in crisis-wracked New Caledonia expressed joy that they may soon be rescued after the first military evacuation flights landed on Tuesday.\n\nFor the last week, Australian tourist Maxwell Winchester and his wife Tiffany have been barricaded into a normally idyllic hill resort outside the capital Noumea.\n\nAs gunfire rattled down the valley and smoke spewed from nearby towns, they faced a fearful wait for help as supplies of food slowly dwindled.\n\n\"Every night, we had to sleep with one eye open,\" Winchester told AFP. \"Every noise, we were worried that they were coming in to loot us.\"\n\nFor days, they monitored the latest news -- which brought alarming reports of six dead and hundreds injured -- while struggling to get help from Australian consular staff.\n\nWinchester received word around lunchtime Tuesday that Australia was finally sending two military evacuation planes.\n\n\"We are ecstatic,\" he said, even though the couple believe they may not be among the first evacuees.\n\nMore than 3,000 people are estimated to have been stranded by a week of unrest that has shuttered the Pacific archipelago's main international airport.\n\nIt is not known how many of those are tourists on holiday and how many are Caledonians stuck outside the islands.\n\nBut Australia has estimated at least 300 of its nationals have registered for rescue.\n\nFor those hundreds, the sight of a Royal Australian Air Force C130 Hercules landing at the city's Magenta airport on Tuesday will have brought overwhelming relief.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force plane is also in the air, dispatched to pick up about \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\", according to Foreign Minister Winston Peters.\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said.\n\nWinchester was sanguine about not being part of the first evacuees.\n\n\"We realise we probably won't get on these flights because those who have higher needs will get on them,\" he said.\n\n\"But we at least know we have a way out in the next few days.\"\n\nStill, for some, there will be an uneasy wait.\n\nAustralian tourists Meg Soutar and Caroline Tully were on a girls' trip to the remote west coast of New Caledonia.\n\nThey were unable to get to the airport for the evacuation flights on Tuesday, as their route would pass through some of the areas worst affected by the unrest.\n\nFor now, the women are staying put and hope they can get home to Brisbane soon. They have had very limited information or assistance from officials.\n\n\"We literally stay by the phone and WIFI to see what is going on,\" Soutar told AFP. \"We feel very isolated, we are not in a resort, it's just us.\"\n\n\"It's been nine days since the conflict started and we are no closer to getting home,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "digitaljournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8139637114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:43:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:43:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:42:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK2405/S00768/new-caledonia-unrest-continues-amid-massive-french-security-operation.htm", "title": "New Caledonia Unrest Continues Amid Massive French Security Operation", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron is flying to New Caledonia today in a direct attempt to shut down riots and unrest that have enveloped the colony for the past eight days.\n\nMacron said the main objective was to \"install\" a \"dialogue mission\" to resume political talks with all stakeholders and find a \"political solution\" to the crisis. Macron's spokesperson Prisca Th\u00e9venot said a \"return to order\" was a preliminary condition for any talks.\n\nThe French Pacific territory has entered a second week of unrest despite the imposition of an emergency decree by Macron last Wednesday. Rioting, largely by indigenous Kanak youth, has devastated the island's capital, Noum\u00e9a. By Friday five people, three young Kanaks and two gendarmes, had been killed.\n\nThe rioting erupted as the French National Assembly pushed through a constitutional amendment to allow French residents who have lived in New Caledonia for 10 years since 1998 the right to vote in provincial elections and for the 54-member Congress. The move is opposed by pro-independence leaders who claim it will dilute the vote of indigenous Kanaks, who make up over 40 percent of the population.\n\nThe protests, involving thousands of Kanaks, have been met with fierce repression from the French state and been confronted with armed pro-France vigilante groups. So far 230 people have been arrested. The 12-day state of emergency gives authorities extensive powers to ban gatherings, impose travel bans, and conduct house arrests and searches.\n\nA contingent of 1,000 French police and army reinforcements arrived on Friday, bringing armed security personnel to 2,700, including riot and crowd control squads.\n\nOver the weekend, the media reported an \"uneasy calm\" had settled over Noum\u00e9a's suburbs, where scenes of violence, arson and confrontation had continued throughout Friday. Despite the military-police crackdown, however, enforcement agencies still had not regained control of the capital's central districts, with fires and other damage occurring overnight Saturday.\n\nFrance's High Commissioner Louis Le Franc claimed: \"With massive reinforcement, we will soon be able to regain control of these areas.\" But Noum\u00e9a's mayor, Sonia Lagarde, said while overnight violence had eased due to a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew, \"we are far from a return to normal.\" \"The situation is not improving -- quite the contrary -- despite all the appeals for {"uri": "8139301476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-21", "time": "22:03:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-21T22:03:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T22:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://www.gzeromedia.com/news/watching/macron-s-high-stakes-visit-to-riot-torn-new-caledonia", "title": "Macron's high-stakes visit to riot-torn New Caledonia", "body": "France's President Emmanuel Macron shakes hands with crew members before boarding his Presidential plane to travel to the Pacific archipelago of New Caledonia in an attempt to resolve a political crisis, at the Orly airport, a suburb of Paris on May 21, 2024.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, the French Pacific territory gripped by deadly unrest among young people from the Indigenous Kanak community. The violence has renewed discussions about France's colonial past, which have largely focused on Africa until now.\n\nBackground: Riots began after France's parliament approved constitutional changes to give local voting rights to French citizens who had lived in the archipelago for at least 10 years. This would dilute the voting rights of the Indigenous population, which has voted three times for independence from France in recent years.\n\nMacron is facing a lose-lose situation. If he postpones the constitutional change - it's set to be ratified at the end of May - he will look like he is caving to violence. If he does nothing, he risks the insurrection continuing to dominate the French news cycle, rather than France's recent economic upturn, ahead of the upcoming European Parliamentary elections. But with Macron's party 15 points behind Marie Le Pen's, he was already expected to face a humiliating defeat when voters head to the polls on June 9.\n\nAs Macron makes the two-day journey in hopes of finding a \"comprehensive security agreement,\" troops are working to rein in the violence ahead of his arrival. Their priority is clearing the highway to the international airport of barricades and burned vehicles, which are currently slowing tourists from leaving and medical and food supplies from arriving.", "sim": 0.3725490272045135, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/new-caledonia-tourists-ecstatic-as-rescue-planes-arrive/article_28751416-d8c8-57d9-831b-e7c8e7cfcf3e.html", "title": "New Caledonia tourists 'ecstatic' as rescue planes arrive", "body": "Tourists trapped by rioting, looting and separatist roadblocks in crisis-wracked New Caledonia expressed joy that they may soon be rescued after the first military evacuation flights landed on Tuesday.\n\nFor the last week, Australian tourist Maxwell Winchester and his wife Tiffany have been barricaded into a normally idyllic hill resort outside the capital Noumea.\n\nAs gunfire rattled down the valley and smoke spewed from nearby towns, they faced a fearful wait for help as supplies of food slowly dwindled.\n\n\"Every night, we had to sleep with one eye open,\" Winchester told AFP. \"Every noise, we were worried that they were coming in to loot us.\"\n\nFor days, they monitored the latest news -- which brought alarming reports of six dead and hundreds injured -- while struggling to get help from Australian consular staff.\n\nWinchester received word around lunchtime Tuesday that Australia was finally sending two military evacuation planes.\n\n\"We are ecstatic,\" he said, even though the couple believe they may not be among the first evacuees.\n\nMore than 3,000 people are estimated to have been stranded by a week of unrest that has shuttered the Pacific archipelago's main international airport.\n\nIt is not known how many of those are tourists on holiday and how many are Caledonians stuck outside the islands.\n\nBut Australia has estimated at least 300 of its nationals have registered for rescue.\n\nFor those hundreds, the sight of a Royal Australian Air Force C130 Hercules landing at the city's Magenta airport on Tuesday will have brought overwhelming relief.\n\nA New Zealand Defence Force plane is also in the air, dispatched to pick up about \"50 passengers with the most pressing needs\", according to Foreign Minister Winston Peters.\n\nMore from this section NY: Nathans Famous Hot Dog Eating Qualifier in Times Square - 53291764 Man arrested for hate crime at Kingston synagogue DEC says it's monitoring oil slick found at Village of Piermont creek\n\n\"In cooperation with France and Australia, we are working on subsequent flights in coming days,\" he said.\n\nWinchester was sanguine about not being part of the first evacuees.\n\n\"We realise we probably won't get on these flights because those who have higher needs will get on them,\" he said.\n\n\"But we at least know we have a way out in the next few days.\"\n\nStill, for some, there will be an uneasy wait.\n\nAustralian tourists Meg Soutar and Caroline Tully were on a girls' trip to the remote west coast of New Caledonia.\n\nThey were unable to get to the airport for the evacuation flights on Tuesday, as their route would pass through some of the areas worst affected by the unrest.\n\nFor now, the women are staying put and hope they can get home to Brisbane soon. They have had very limited information or assistance from officials.\n\n\"We literally stay by the phone and WIFI to see what is going on,\" Soutar told AFP. \"We feel very isolated, we are not in a resort, it's just us.\"\n\n\"It's been nine days since the conflict started and we are no closer to getting home,\" she said.\n\narb-lec/cwl", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8133644680", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-18", "time": "07:13:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-18T07:13:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-18T07:12:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3294117748737335, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/conflict/a-no-mans-land-aussie-stuck-in-new-caledonia-unrest-c-14713782", "title": "'A no man's land': Aussie stuck in New Caledonia unrest", "body": "Australians stranded in riotous New Caledonia are begging the government to help them come home, describing the deteriorating unrest that has killed four people as a war zone.\n\nBrisbane woman Sophie Jones Bradshaw travelled to Noumea, the capital of the French-ruled Pacific island territory, for work on May 11.\n\nShe said her husband and three-year-old son were meant to come to meet her several days later, but the riots broke out.\n\nThe family is now separated with no idea when they will be reunited.\n\n\"It's getting really hard to see my son every day on the camera,\" Ms Jones Bradshaw told AAP.\n\n\"I'm crying because he wants me to go home.\n\n\"I'm telling him 'oh just one more sleep, one more sleep', but I don't know.\"\n\nMs Jones Bradshaw said there were explosions, fires and looting across the once beautiful capital that she has travelled to for 20 years.\n\n\"It's desolation, it's chaos - it's frightening,\" she said.\n\n\"It feels like a no man's land.\"\n\nShe claimed half of the capital has been burnt with homes and businesses razed as the unrest sparked over contested electoral reform continued.\n\n\"I hardly sleep at night as I go down in my street to help neighbours protecting it and when I am sleeping I wake to the slightest noise from the fear of fire or burglars,\" Ms Jones Bradshaw said.\n\n\"I feel exhausted and scared like any Caledonian.\"\n\nSupermarkets are bare and leaving home to get rations is a life-threatening endeavour amid periodic explosions and fires.\n\n\"There's a few corner stores I've tried yesterday and today and they are empty - maybe a few shampoos and deodorants left but there's no food,\" Ms Jones Bradshaw said.\n\n\"You have to go further and further out to find a shop that hasn't been burned or is not closed.\n\n\"In the middle of all that, you can still hear explosions every now and then.\"\n\nFinding a loaf of bread is near impossible, Ms Jones Bradshaw said, with supplies to grocers blocked by road barricades.\n\nIt was unclear when Ms Jones Bradshaw would be able to return to Brisbane.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs advised Ms Jones Bradshaw to register on a database so the agency was aware of who was in the country.\n\nIt told her to prepare to leave by packing her bags and charging all electronics but provided no timelines.\n\nMs Jones Bradshaw said she had slept fully dressed for the past five nights with her passport, phone and laptop in a bag ready to go at any moment.\n\nAll she wants is to be home with her family before her son's fourth birthday in several days.\n\n\"I'm really hoping that (the airport) will open on the 22nd and I'll be maintained on my flight which I doubt,\" she said.\n\n\"But I'm really hoping and it's hard not to know.\"\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Penny Wong said Australians in New Caledonia should limit their movement and follow the advice of authorities.\n\n\"We are working with authorities in France and New Caledonia and like-minded partners including New Zealand to assess options for Australians to safely depart,\" she posted on social media platform X on Saturday.\n\nTreasurer Jim Chalmers urged Australians stuck in New Caledonia to contact the foreign affairs department via the hotline for assistance.\n\n\"We're incredibly concerned about the developments in New Caledonia. We call for calm in that part of the world,\" he told reporters on Saturday.\n\n\"We know that there will be Australians, either in New Caledonia, or family members and loved ones here in Australia,
